questions.explanation: If you have to make a U-turn, slow down and ensure that the road is clear in both directions. Make sure that the road is wide enough for you to carry out the manoeuvre safely.

prashna.text: What should you do before making a U-turn?

options.description: A. Look over your shoulder for a final check
B. Give an arm signal as well as using your indicators
C. Select a higher gear than normal
D. Check signs to see that U-turns are permitted

questions.explanation: You should slow down and be cautious. The bridge is narrow and there may not be enough room for you to pass an oncoming vehicle at this point. Also, there's no footpath, so be aware of pedestrians in the road.

prashna.text: What should you do as you approach this bridge?

options.description: A. Change gear
B. Move to the right
C. Slow down
D. Keep to 30 mph

questions.explanation: As you begin to think about overtaking, ask yourself whether it’s really necessary. If you can’t see well ahead, stay back and wait for a safer place to pull out.

prashna.text: In which of these situations should you avoid overtaking?

options.description: A. In a one-way street
B. Just after a bend
C. Approaching a dip in the road
D. On a 30 mph road

questions.explanation: In this picture, the road marking shows that overtaking drivers or riders need to return to the left. These markings show the direction drivers must pass hatch markings or solid double white lines. They are also used to show the route that high vehicles should take under low arched bridge.

prashna.text: What does the curved arrow on the road mean?

options.description: A. The road ahead has a camber to the left
B. The road ahead bends to the left
C. Overtaking traffic should move back to the left
D. Heavy vehicles should take the next road on the left to avoid a weight limit

questions.explanation: It’s illegal to use a hand-held mobile or similar device when driving or riding, except in a genuine emergency. The safest option is to switch off your mobile phone before you set off, and use a message service. If you've forgotten to switch your phone off and it rings, you should ignore it. When you've stopped in a safe place, you can see who called and return the call if necessary.

prashna.text: Your mobile phone rings while you're travelling. What should you do?

options.description: A. Answer it immediately
B. Ignore it
C. Pull up at the nearest kerb
D. Stop immediately

questions.explanation: These lines are often found on the approach to a roundabout or a dangerous junction. They give you extra warning to adjust your speed. Look well ahead and do this in good time.

prashna.text: Why are these yellow lines painted across the road?

options.description: A. To help you keep the correct separation distance
B. To tell you the distance to the roundabout
C. To make you aware of your speed
D. To help you choose the correct lane

questions.explanation: The longer traffic lights have been on green, the sooner they'll change. Allow for this as you approach traffic lights that you know have been on green for a while. They're likely to change soon, so you should be prepared to stop.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're approaching traffic lights that have been on green for some time?

options.description: A. Accelerate hard
B. Maintain your speed
C. Be ready to stop
D. Brake hard

questions.explanation: Before pulling up, check the mirrors to see what's happening behind you. Also assess what's ahead and make sure you give the correct signal if it will help other road users.

prashna.text: What should you do before stopping?

options.description: A. Select a higher gear
B. Sound the horn
C. Flash the headlights
D. Use the mirrors

questions.explanation: If you're following a large vehicle but are so close to it that you can't see its exterior mirrors, the driver won't be able to see you. Keeping well back will also allow you to see the road ahead by looking past on either side of the large vehicle.

prashna.text: You're following a large vehicle. Why should you stay a safe distance behind it?

options.description: A. You'll be able to corner more quickly
B. You'll help the large vehicle to stop more easily
C. You'll allow the driver to see you in their mirrors
D. You'll keep out of the wind better

questions.explanation: You should be constantly scanning the road for clues about what's going to happen next. Check your mirrors regularly, particularly as soon as you spot a hazard. What's happening behind may affect your response to hazards ahead.

prashna.text: When you see a hazard ahead, you should use the mirrors. Why is this?

options.description: A. To check what's happening on the road ahead
B. Because you'll need to brake sharply to a stop
C. Because you'll need to accelerate out of danger
D. To assess how your actions will affect following traffic

questions.explanation: At junctions, your view is often restricted by buildings, trees or parked cars. You need to be able to see in order to judge a safe gap. Edge forward slowly and keep looking all the time. Don’t cause other road users to change speed or direction as you emerge.

prashna.text: You're waiting to turn right at the end of a road. Your view is obstructed by parked vehicles. What should you do?

options.description: A. Wait for a pedestrian to let you know when it's safe for you to emerge
B. Stop and then move forward slowly and carefully for a clear view
C. Turn your vehicle around immediately and find another junction to use
D. Move quickly to where you can see so you only block traffic from one direction

questions.explanation: Ensure that you can see clearly through the windscreen of your vehicle. Stickers or hanging objects could obstruct your view or draw your attention away from the road.

prashna.text: What may happen if you hang objects from your interior mirror?

options.description: A. Your sun visor might get tangled
B. Your view could be obstructed
C. Your radio reception might be affected
D. Your windscreen would mist up

questions.explanation: If you feel sleepy, you should leave the motorway at a service area or at the next exit and stop in a safe place to rest. A supply of fresh air can help to keep you alert before you reach the exit, but it isn't a substitute for stopping and resting.

prashna.text: You're on a long motorway journey. What should you do if you start to feel sleepy?

options.description: A. Drive faster to complete your journey sooner
B. Play some loud music
C. Leave the motorway and stop in a safe place
D. Stop on the hard shoulder for a rest

questions.explanation: Your headlights and tail lights help others on the road to see you. It may be necessary to turn on your lights during the day if visibility is reduced; for example, due to heavy rain. In these conditions, the light might fade before the street lights are timed to switch on. Be seen to be safe.

prashna.text: Why should you switch your lights on when it first starts to get dark?

options.description: A. So that you blend in with other drivers
B. Because the street lights are lit
C. So others can see you more easily
D. To make your dials easier to see

questions.explanation: It’s easy to be distracted. Planning your journey before you set off is important. A few sensible precautions are to tune your radio to stations in your area of travel, take planned breaks, and plan your route. Except for emergencies, it’s illegal to use a hand-held mobile phone while driving. Even using a hands-free kit can severely distract your attention.

prashna.text: What’s most likely to distract you while you’re driving?

options.description: A. Using the windscreen wipers
B. Using a mobile phone
C. Checking the mirrors
D. Using the demisters

questions.explanation: It's illegal to use a hand-held mobile phone while driving, except in a genuine emergency. Even using a hands-free kit can distract your attention. Park in a safe and convenient place before receiving or making a call or using text messaging. Then you'll also be free to take notes or refer to papers.

prashna.text: When may you use a hand-held mobile phone in your car?

options.description: A. When suitably parked
B. When driving an automatic vehicle
C. When driving at less than 30 mph
D. When receiving a call

questions.explanation: As you drive, look well ahead and all around so that you’re ready for any hazards that might develop. If you have to stop in an emergency, react as soon as you can while keeping control of the vehicle. Keep both hands on the steering wheel so you can control the vehicle's direction of travel.

prashna.text: You're driving on a wet road. You have to stop your vehicle in an emergency. What should you do?

options.description: A. Select reverse gear
B. Apply the handbrake and footbrake together
C. Give an arm signal
D. Keep both hands on the steering wheel

questions.explanation: Before moving off, you should use both the interior and exterior mirrors to check that the road is clear. Look around to check the blind spots and, if necessary, give a signal to warn other road users of your intentions.

prashna.text: What should you do when moving off from behind a parked car?

options.description: A. Look around after moving off
B. Give a signal after moving off
C. Check both interior and exterior mirrors
D. Use the exterior mirrors only

questions.explanation: Allow the cyclist plenty of room in case they wobble or swerve around a pothole or raised drain. Look well ahead before you start to overtake, because you'll need to use all of the road. Look for entrances to fields where tractors or other farm machinery could be waiting to pull out.

prashna.text: You're travelling along this narrow country road. How should you pass the cyclist?

options.description: A. Keep close to them as you pass
B. Leave them plenty of room as you pass
C. Sound your horn as you pass
D. Change down one gear before you pass

questions.explanation: Never attempt to use a hand-held phone while you're driving, except in a genuine emergency. It's illegal and will take your attention away from driving, putting you at greater risk of causing a collision.

prashna.text: Your vehicle is fitted with a hand-held telephone. What should you do to use the phone?

options.description: A. Reduce your speed
B. Be particularly careful at junctions
C. Find a safe place to stop
D. Steer the vehicle with one hand

questions.explanation: It’s easy to lose your way in an unfamiliar area. If you need to check a map or ask for directions, first find a safe place to stop.

prashna.text: You lose your way on a busy road. What's the best action to take?

options.description: A. Stop at traffic lights and ask pedestrians
B. Shout to other drivers to ask them the way
C. Check a map, and keep going with the traffic flow
D. Turn into a side road, stop and check a map

questions.explanation: Windscreen pillars can obstruct your view, particularly at bends and junctions. Look out for other road users – especially cyclists, motorcyclists and pedestrians – as they can easily be hidden by this obstruction.

prashna.text: When do windscreen pillars cause a serious obstruction to your view?

options.description: A. When you're driving on a motorway
B. When you're driving on a dual carriageway
C. When you're approaching bends and junctions
D. When you're approaching a one-way street

questions.explanation: If you want to turn your car around, try to find a place where you have good all-round vision. If this isn’t possible, and you’re unable to see clearly, then get someone to guide you.

prashna.text: You can't see clearly behind when reversing. What should you do?

options.description: A. Ask someone to guide you
B. Look in the nearside mirror
C. Open the door to look behind
D. Open the window to look behind

questions.explanation: Modern vehicles provide the driver with a good view of both the road ahead and behind using well-positioned mirrors. However, the mirrors can’t see every angle of the scene behind and to the sides of the vehicle. This is why it’s essential that you know when and how to check your blind spots, so that you’re aware of any hidden hazards.

prashna.text: What does the term ‘blind spot’ mean?

options.description: A. An area covered by your right-hand mirror
B. An area not covered by your headlights
C. An area not visible to the driver
D. An area covered by your left-hand mirror

questions.explanation: Talking to someone while you're driving can distract you and, unlike someone in the car with you, the person on the other end of a mobile phone is unable to see the traffic situations you're dealing with. They won't stop speaking to you even if you're approaching a hazardous situation. You need to concentrate on your driving all of the time, but especially so when dealing with a hazard.

prashna.text: What's likely to happen if you use a hands-free phone while you're driving?

options.description: A. It will reduce your view
B. It will improve your safety
C. It will increase your concentration
D. It will divert your attention

questions.explanation: Before emerging right onto a dual carriageway, make sure that the central reservation is deep enough to protect your vehicle. If it isn't, you should treat the dual carriageway as one road and check that it’s clear in both directions before pulling out. Neglecting to do this could place part or all of your vehicle in the path of approaching traffic and cause a collision.

prashna.text: You're turning right onto a dual carriageway. What should you do before emerging?

options.description: A. Position your vehicle well to the left of the side road
B. Make sure that you leave enough room for a vehicle behind
C. Check that the central reservation is wide enough for your vehicle
D. Stop, apply the handbrake and then select a low gear

questions.explanation: Windscreen pillars can completely block your view of pedestrians, motorcyclists and cyclists. You should make a particular effort to look for these road users; don’t just rely on a quick glance.

prashna.text: You're waiting to emerge from a junction. The windscreen pillar is restricting your view. What should you be particularly aware of?

options.description: A. Coaches
B. Motorcyclists
C. Buses
D. Lorries

questions.explanation: Vehicle navigation systems can be useful when driving on unfamiliar routes. However, they can also distract you and cause you to lose control if you look at or adjust them while driving. Pull up in a convenient and safe place before adjusting them.

prashna.text: How should you use a satellite navigation system so that it doesn't distract you when you're driving?

options.description: A. Turn it off while driving in built-up areas
B. Stop in a safe place before programming the system
C. Only set the destination when you're lost
D. Choose a voice that you find calming

questions.explanation: Pelican crossings are signal-controlled crossings operated by pedestrians. Push-button controls change the signals. Pelican crossings have no red-and-amber stage before green; instead, they have a flashing amber light. This means you must give way to pedestrians who are already on the crossing. If the crossing is clear, however, you can continue.

prashna.text: At a pelican crossing, what must you do when the amber light is flashing?

options.description: A. Stop and wait for the red light
B. Give way to pedestrians waiting to cross
C. Stop and wait for the green light
D. Give way to pedestrians already on the crossing

questions.explanation: If people are waiting to use a pedestrian crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don’t wave them across the road, because another driver may not have seen them, may not have seen your signal, and may not be able to stop safely.

prashna.text: Why should you never wave people across at pedestrian crossings?

options.description: A. It's safer for you to carry on
B. They may not be ready to cross
C. They may not be looking
D. Another vehicle may be coming

questions.explanation: ‘Tailgating’ is the term used when a driver or rider follows the vehicle in front too closely. It's dangerous because it restricts their view of the road ahead and leaves no safety margin if the vehicle in front needs to slow down or stop suddenly. Tailgating is often the underlying cause of rear-end collisions or multiple pile-ups.

prashna.text: What does 'tailgating' mean?

options.description: A. Driving with rear fog lights on
B. Reversing into a parking space
C. Following another vehicle too closely
D. Using the rear door of a hatchback car

questions.explanation: Staying back will increase your view of the road ahead. This will help you to see any hazards that might occur and give you more time to react.

prashna.text: Why is it unwise to follow this vehicle too closely?

options.description: A. Your view ahead will be reduced
B. Your engine will overheat
C. Your brakes will overheat
D. Your view ahead will be increased

questions.explanation: Water will reduce your tyres’ grip on the road. The safe separation gap of at least two seconds in dry conditions should be doubled, to at least four seconds, in wet weather.

prashna.text: What's the minimum time gap you should leave when following a vehicle on a wet road?

options.description: A. Three seconds
B. Four seconds
C. Two seconds
D. One second

questions.explanation: A long lorry with a heavy load will need more time to pass you than a car, especially on an uphill stretch of road. Slow down and allow the lorry to pass.

prashna.text: A long, heavily laden lorry is taking a long time to overtake you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Hold your speed
B. Change direction
C. Speed up
D. Slow down

questions.explanation: Emergency vehicles use blue flashing lights. If you see or hear one, move out of its way as soon as it's safe and legal to do so.

prashna.text: Which vehicle will use a blue flashing beacon?

options.description: A. Breakdown recovery
B. Snow plough
C. Bomb disposal
D. Motorway maintenance

questions.explanation: Pull over in a place where the ambulance can pass safely. Check that there are no bollards or obstructions in the road that will prevent it from passing.

prashna.text: You're being followed by an ambulance showing flashing blue lights. What should you do?

options.description: A. Brake harshly and stop well out into the road
B. Accelerate hard to get away from it
C. Pull over as soon as it's safe to do so
D. Maintain your speed and course

questions.explanation: A green flashing beacon on a vehicle means the driver or passenger is a doctor on an emergency call. Give way to them if it’s safe to do so. Be aware that the vehicle may be travelling quickly or may stop in a hurry.

prashna.text: What type of emergency vehicle is fitted with a green flashing beacon?

options.description: A. Fire engine
B. Doctor’s car
C. Road gritter
D. Ambulance

questions.explanation: These signs apply only to tram drivers, but you should know their meaning so that you’re aware of the priorities and are able to anticipate the actions of the driver.

prashna.text: Who should obey diamond-shaped traffic signs?

options.description: A. Lorry drivers
B. Tram drivers
C. Taxi drivers
D. Bus drivers

questions.explanation: The narrow wheels of a bicycle can become stuck in the tram rails, causing the cyclist to stop suddenly, wobble or even lose balance altogether. The tram lines are also slippery, which could cause a cyclist to slide or fall off.

prashna.text: On a road where trams operate, which of these vehicles will be most at risk from the tram rails?

options.description: A. Cars
B. Cycles
C. Buses
D. Lorries

questions.explanation: Your horn mustn't be used between 11.30 pm and 7 am in a built-up area or when you're stationary, unless a moving vehicle poses a danger. Its function is to alert other road users to your presence.

prashna.text: What should you use your horn for?

options.description: A. To greet other road users
B. To alert others to your presence
C. To signal your annoyance
D. To allow you right of way

questions.explanation: When you’re in a one-way street and want to turn right, you should take up a position in the right-hand lane. This will allow other road users, not wishing to turn, to pass on the left. Indicate your intention and take up the correct position in good time.

prashna.text: You're in a one-way street and want to turn right. There are two lanes. Where should you position your vehicle?

options.description: A. In either lane, depending on the traffic
B. In the left-hand lane
C. Just left of the centre line
D. In the right-hand lane

questions.explanation: If you wish to turn right into a side road, take up your position in good time. Move to the centre of the road when it’s safe to do so. This will allow vehicles to pass you on the left. Early planning will show other traffic what you intend to do.

prashna.text: You wish to turn right ahead. Why should you take up the correct position in good time?

options.description: A. To give a better view into the road that you’re joining
B. To allow drivers to pass you on the right
C. To allow other drivers to pull out in front of you
D. To help other road users know what you intend to do

questions.explanation: A toucan crossing is designed to allow pedestrians and cyclists to cross at the same time. Look out for cyclists approaching the crossing at speed.

prashna.text: At which type of crossing are cyclists allowed to ride across with pedestrians?

options.description: A. Zebra
B. Puffin
C. Toucan
D. Pelican

questions.explanation: Don’t enforce the speed limit by blocking another vehicle’s progress. This will only lead to the other driver becoming more frustrated. Allow the other vehicle to pass when you can do so safely.

prashna.text: You're driving at the legal speed limit. A vehicle comes up quickly behind you, flashing its headlights. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate to make a gap behind you
B. Touch the brakes sharply to show your brake lights
C. Allow the vehicle to overtake
D. Maintain your speed to prevent the vehicle from overtaking

questions.explanation: You should only flash your headlights to warn others of your presence. Don’t use them to greet others, show impatience or give priority to other road users, because they could misunderstand your signal.

prashna.text: When should you flash your headlights at other road users?

options.description: A. When showing that you're about to turn
B. When showing that you're giving way
C. When letting them know that you're there
D. When telling them that you have right of way

questions.explanation: Be cautious, especially when your view is restricted by hedges, bushes, walls, large vehicles, etc. In the summer months, these junctions can become more difficult to deal with, because growing foliage may further obscure your view.

prashna.text: You're approaching an unmarked crossroads. How should you deal with this type of junction?

options.description: A. Slow down and keep to the right
B. Accelerate and look to the left
C. Accelerate and keep to the middle
D. Slow down and look both ways

questions.explanation: In good conditions, the 'two-second rule' can be used to check the distance between your vehicle and the one in front. This technique works on roads carrying faster traffic. Choose a fixed object, such as a bridge, sign or tree. When the vehicle ahead passes this object, say to yourself ‘Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.’ If you reach the object before you finish saying this, you’re too close.

prashna.text: The conditions are good and dry. When should you use the 'two-second rule'?

options.description: A. When checking your gap from the vehicle in front
B. Before restarting the engine after it has stalled
C. When traffic lights change to green
D. Before using the ‘Mirrors – Signal – Manoeuvre’ routine

questions.explanation: Puffin crossings have infra-red sensors that detect when pedestrians are crossing and hold the red traffic signal until the crossing is clear. The use of a sensor means there's no flashing amber phase as there is with a pelican crossing.

prashna.text: At a puffin crossing, which colour follows the green signal?

options.description: A. Flashing amber
B. Steady red
C. Flashing green
D. Steady amber

questions.explanation: If the driver behind is following too closely, there’s a danger they’ll collide with the back of your vehicle if you stop suddenly. You can reduce this risk by slowing down and increasing the safety margin in front of you. This reduces the chance that you’ll have to stop suddenly and allows you to spread your braking over a greater distance. This is an example of defensive driving.

prashna.text: You're in a line of traffic. The driver behind you is following very closely. What action should you take?

options.description: A. Move over to a position just left of the centre line of the road
B. Ignore the following driver and continue to travel within the speed limit
C. Slow down, gradually increasing the gap between you and the vehicle in front
D. Signal left and wave the following driver past

questions.explanation: Use the full-beam headlights only when you can be sure that you won’t dazzle other road users.

prashna.text: You're driving on a clear night. There's a steady stream of oncoming traffic. The national speed limit applies. Which lights should you use?

options.description: A. Full-beam headlights
B. Dipped headlights
C. Sidelights
D. Fog lights

questions.explanation: Large, long vehicles need extra room when making turns at junctions. They may move out to the right in order to make a left turn. Keep well back and don’t attempt to pass them on their left.

prashna.text: You're driving behind a large goods vehicle. What should you do if it signals left but steers to the right?

options.description: A. Overtake on the right of it
B. Slow down and let the vehicle turn
C. Drive on, keeping to the left
D. Hold your speed and sound your horn

questions.explanation: There are times when other drivers make incorrect or ill-judged decisions. Be tolerant and try not to retaliate or react aggressively. Always consider the safety of other road users, your passengers and yourself.

prashna.text: You're driving along this road. The red van cuts in close in front of you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Drop back to leave the correct separation distance
B. Accelerate to get closer to the red van
C. Give a long blast on the horn
D. Flash your headlights several times

questions.explanation: In queuing traffic, your brake lights can dazzle drivers behind you. If you apply your parking brake, you can take your foot off the footbrake. This will deactivate the brake lights.

prashna.text: You're waiting in a traffic queue at night. How can you avoid dazzling drivers behind you?

options.description: A. Use the footbrake only
B. Use the clutch with the accelerator
C. Use the parking brake with the footbrake
D. Use the parking brake only

questions.explanation: Keep a steady course to give the driver behind an opportunity to overtake safely. If necessary, slow down. Reacting incorrectly to another driver’s impatience can lead to danger.

prashna.text: You're driving in traffic at the speed limit for the road. What should you do if the driver behind is trying to overtake?

options.description: A. Keep a steady course and allow the driver behind to overtake
B. Accelerate to get away from the driver behind
C. Wave the driver behind to overtake when it's safe
D. Move closer to the car ahead, so the driver behind has no room to overtake

questions.explanation: Bus-lane signs show the vehicles allowed to use the lane and also its times of operation. Where no times are shown, the bus lane is in operation 24 hours a day.

prashna.text: There's a bus lane on your left. The signs show no times of operation. What does this mean?

options.description: A. The lane is only in operation in daylight hours
B. The lane isn't in operation
C. The lane is only in operation at peak times
D. The lane is in operation 24 hours a day

questions.explanation: If someone in charge of animals asks you to stop, you should do so and switch off your engine. Animals are unpredictable and startle easily; they could turn and run into your path or into the path of another moving vehicle.

prashna.text: What should you do when a person herding sheep asks you to stop?

options.description: A. Ignore them as they have no authority
B. Stop and switch off your engine
C. Continue on but drive slowly
D. Try to get past quickly

questions.explanation: Horses can be startled by the sound of a car engine or the rush of air caused by a vehicle passing too closely. Keep well back and only pass when it's safe. Leave them plenty of room; you may have to use the other side of the road to go past safely.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're overtaking a horse and rider?

options.description: A. Sound your horn as a warning
B. Flash your headlights as a warning
C. Go past as quickly as possible
D. Go past slowly and carefully

questions.explanation: As you approach a zebra crossing, look for pedestrians waiting to cross. Where you can see them, slow down and prepare to stop. Be especially careful of children and older people, who may have difficulty judging when it's safe to cross.

prashna.text: You're approaching a zebra crossing. Pedestrians are waiting to cross. What should you do?

options.description: A. Give way to the elderly and infirm only
B. Slow down and prepare to stop
C. Use your headlights to indicate they can cross
D. Wave at them to cross the road

questions.explanation:
Try to be ready for the unexpected. Plan ahead and learn to anticipate hazards. You’ll then give yourself more time to react to any problems that might occur.
Be tolerant of other road users who don’t behave correctly.

prashna.text: A vehicle pulls out in front of you at a junction. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate past it immediately
B. Swerve past it and sound your horn
C. Slow down and be ready to stop
D. Flash your headlights and drive up close behind

questions.explanation: A sensor will automatically detect that the pedestrians have reached a safe position. Don’t drive on until the green light shows and it's safe for you to do so.

prashna.text: You're approaching a red light at a puffin crossing. Pedestrians are on the crossing. When will the red light change?

options.description: A. When you start to edge forward onto the crossing
B. When the pedestrians have cleared the crossing
C. When the pedestrians push the button on the far side of the crossing
D. When a driver from the opposite direction reaches the crossing

questions.explanation: You should be aware of all the warning lights and visual aids on the vehicle you're driving. If you're driving a vehicle for the first time, you should familiarise yourself with all the controls, warning lights and visual aids before you set off.

prashna.text: Which instrument-panel warning light would show that headlights are on full beam?

questions.explanation: In good, dry conditions, a driver needs to keep a distance of at least two seconds from the car in front. This should allow enough space for you to stop if the driver in front has to stop suddenly.

prashna.text: In which conditions should you leave at least a two-second gap between your vehicle and the one in front?

options.description: A. Dry
B. Wet
C. Foggy
D. Damp

questions.explanation: If you follow another vehicle with your headlights on full beam, they could dazzle the driver. Leave a safe distance and make sure that the light from your dipped beam falls short of the vehicle in front.

prashna.text: You're driving at night on an unlit road, following another vehicle. What should you do?

options.description: A. Switch off your headlights
B. Use dipped headlights
C. Use full-beam headlights
D. Flash your headlights

questions.explanation: If you’re driving a slow-moving vehicle along a narrow road, try not to hold up faster traffic. If you see vehicles following behind, pull over in a safe place and let the traffic pass before continuing. Don't wave other traffic past – this could be dangerous if you or they haven’t seen any hazard that's hidden from view.

prashna.text: You're driving a slow-moving vehicle on a narrow, winding road. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pull in when you can, to let following vehicles overtake
B. Wave following vehicles past you if you think they can overtake quickly
C. Give a left signal when it's safe for vehicles to overtake you
D. Keep well out to stop vehicles overtaking dangerously

questions.explanation: Diesel fuel can spill out if your filler cap isn't secured properly. This is most likely to occur on bends, junctions and roundabouts, where it will make the road slippery, especially if it's wet. At the end of a dry spell of weather, the road surfaces may have a high level of diesel spillage that hasn’t been washed away by rain.

prashna.text: What can a loose filler cap on your diesel fuel tank cause?

options.description: A. It can make the engine difficult to start
B. It can make the roads slippery for other road users
C. It can improve your vehicle’s fuel consumption
D. It can increase the level of exhaust emissions

questions.explanation: When learning to drive, it's a good idea to practise filling your car with fuel. Ask your instructor if you can use a petrol station and fill the fuel tank yourself. You need to know where the filler cap is on the car you're driving, so you know which side of the pump to park at. Take care not to overfill the tank and make sure you secure the filler cap correctly, so that no fuel leaks onto the road while you're driving.

prashna.text: After refuelling your vehicle, what should you do to avoid spillage?

options.description: A. Check that your fuel gauge is working
B. Check that your filler cap is securely fastened
C. Check that your tank is only three-quarters full
D. Check that you've used a locking filler cap

questions.explanation: Competitive driving increases the risks to everyone and is the opposite of responsible, considerate and defensive driving. Defensive driving is about questioning the actions of other road users and being prepared for the unexpected. Don’t be taken by surprise.

prashna.text: What style of driving causes increased risk to everyone?

options.description: A. Considerate
B. Responsible
C. Competitive
D. Defensive

questions.explanation: Your tyres are your only contact with the road. To prevent problems with braking and steering, keep your tyres free from defects; they must have sufficient tread depth and be correctly inflated. Correct tyre pressures help reduce the risk of skidding and provide a safer and more comfortable drive or ride.

prashna.text: What’s badly affected if the tyres are under-inflated?

options.description: A. Changing gear
B. Parking
C. Braking
D. Indicating

questions.explanation: Every effort must be made to prevent excessive noise, especially in built-up areas at night. Don’t rev your engine or sound the horn unnecessarily. It's illegal to sound your horn in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am, except when another road user poses a danger.

prashna.text: When mustn't you sound your vehicle's horn?

options.description: A. Between 11.30 pm and 6.00 am on any road
B. Between 10.00 pm and 6.00 am in a built-up area
C. At any time in a built-up area
D. Between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am in a built-up area

questions.explanation: Trams are powered by electricity and therefore don't emit exhaust fumes. They ease traffic congestion by offering drivers an alternative to using their car, particularly in busy cities and towns.

prashna.text: What makes the vehicle in the picture 'environmentally friendly'?

options.description: A. It's powered by electricity
B. It's powered by unleaded petrol
C. It's powered by gravity
D. It's powered by diesel

questions.explanation: Inconsiderate parking can obstruct the flow of traffic and so make traffic congestion worse. Red routes are designed to prevent this by enforcing strict parking restrictions. Driving slowly in traffic increases fuel consumption and causes a build-up of exhaust fumes.

prashna.text: Why have 'red routes' been introduced in major cities?

options.description: A. To raise the speed limits
B. To help the traffic flow
C. To provide better parking
D. To allow lorries to load more freely

questions.explanation: Traffic-calming measures help to keep vehicle speeds low in congested areas where there are pedestrians and children. A pedestrian is much more likely to survive a collision with a vehicle travelling at 20 mph than they are with a vehicle travelling at 40 mph.

prashna.text: What's the purpose of road humps, chicanes and narrowings?

options.description: A. To allow pedestrians to cross
B. To increase traffic speed
C. To reduce traffic speed
D. To separate lanes of traffic

questions.explanation: Catalytic converters reduce a large percentage of harmful exhaust emissions. They work more efficiently when the engine has reached its normal working temperature.

prashna.text: What's the purpose of a catalytic converter?

options.description: A. To reduce harmful exhaust gases
B. To reduce fuel consumption
C. To reduce engine wear
D. To reduce the risk of fire

questions.explanation: Check the tyre pressures when the tyres are cold. This will give you a more accurate reading. The heat generated on a long journey will raise the pressure inside the tyre.

prashna.text: It's essential that tyre pressures are checked regularly. When should this be done?

options.description: A. After any lengthy journey
B. After travelling at high speed
C. When tyres are cold
D. When tyres are hot

questions.explanation: Check your tyre pressures frequently – normally once a week. If they're lower than those recommended by the manufacturer, there will be more ‘rolling resistance’. The engine will have to work harder to overcome this, leading to increased fuel consumption.

prashna.text: When will your vehicle use more fuel?

options.description: A. When its tyres are of different makes
B. When its tyres are under-inflated
C. When its tyres are over-inflated
D. When its tyres are new

questions.explanation: Batteries contain acid, which is hazardous, and they must be disposed of safely. This means taking them to an appropriate disposal site.

prashna.text: How should you dispose of a used vehicle battery?

options.description: A. Bury it in your garden
B. Leave it on waste land
C. Put it in the dustbin
D. Take it to a local-authority site

questions.explanation: Accelerating and braking gently and smoothly will help to save fuel and reduce wear on your vehicle. This makes it better for the environment too.

prashna.text: What's most likely to cause high fuel consumption?

options.description: A. Harsh braking and accelerating
B. Accelerating around bends
C. Poor steering control
D. Staying in high gears

questions.explanation: Some modern batteries are maintenance-free. Check your vehicle handbook and, if necessary, make sure that the plates in each battery cell are covered with fluid.

prashna.text: The fluid level in your battery is low. What should you top it up with?

options.description: A. Distilled water
B. Engine oil
C. Battery acid
D. Engine coolant

questions.explanation: When parking at night, park in the direction of the traffic. This will enable other road users to see the reflectors on the rear of your vehicle. Use your parking lights if the speed limit is over 30 mph.

prashna.text: You're parked on the road at night. Where must you use parking lights?

options.description: A. Where the speed limit exceeds 30 mph
B. Where there are continuous white lines in the middle of the road
C. Where you're facing oncoming traffic
D. Where you're near a bus stop

questions.explanation: Engines that burn fossil fuels produce exhaust emissions that are harmful to health. The harder you make the engine work, the more emissions it will produce. Engines also use more fuel and produce higher levels of emissions when they're cold. Anything you can do to reduce your use of fossil fuels will help the environment.

prashna.text: How can you reduce the environmental harm caused by your motor vehicle?

options.description: A. Drive faster than normal
B. Only use it for short journeys
C. Keep engine revs low
D. Don't service it

questions.explanation: If you see that parts of the tread on your tyres are wearing before others, it may indicate a brake, steering or suspension fault. Regular servicing will help to detect faults at an early stage and this will avoid the risk of minor faults becoming serious or even dangerous.

prashna.text: What can cause excessive or uneven tyre wear?

options.description: A. A faulty electrical system
B. A faulty braking system
C. A faulty gearbox
D. A faulty exhaust system

questions.explanation: Top up the battery with distilled water and make sure each cell plate is covered.

prashna.text: You need to top up your battery. What level should you fill it to?

options.description: A. Just above the cell plates
B. Halfway up the battery
C. The top of the battery
D. Just below the cell plates

questions.explanation: Planning your journey before you set out can help to make it much easier and more pleasant, and may help to ease traffic congestion. Look at a map to help you do this. You may need maps of different scales, depending on where and how far you’re going. Printing or writing out the route can also help.

prashna.text: Before starting a journey, it's wise to plan your route. How can you do this?

options.description: A. Check your vehicle registration document
B. Contact your local garage
C. Look at a map
D. Look in your vehicle handbook

questions.explanation: No-one likes to spend time in traffic queues. Try to avoid busy times related to school or work travel.

prashna.text: Why is it a good idea to plan your journey to avoid busy times?

options.description: A. You'll have an easier journey
B. It will cause more traffic congestion
C. You'll have a more stressful journey
D. Your journey time will be longer

questions.explanation: If possible, avoid the early morning, late afternoon and early evening ‘rush hour’. Doing this should allow you to travel in a more relaxed frame of mind, concentrate solely on what you’re doing and arrive at your destination feeling less stressed.

prashna.text: You avoid busy times when travelling. How will this affect your journey?

options.description: A. Your journey time will be longer
B. You’ll travel a much shorter distance
C. You’re less likely to be delayed
D. You’re more likely to be held up

questions.explanation: It can be frustrating and worrying to find your planned route is blocked by roadworks or diversions. If you've planned an alternative, you'll feel less stressed and more able to concentrate fully on your driving or riding. If your original route is mostly on motorways, it’s a good idea to plan an alternative using non-motorway roads. Always carry a map with you just in case you need to refer to it.

prashna.text: It can be helpful to plan your route before starting a journey. Why should you also plan an alternative route?

options.description: A. You may get held up by a tractor
B. Your original route may be blocked
C. Your maps may have different scales
D. You may find you have to pay a congestion charge

questions.explanation: Always allow plenty of time for your journey in case of unforeseen problems. Anything can happen; for example, punctures, breakdowns, road closures, diversions and delays. You'll feel less stressed and less inclined to take risks if you aren't ‘pushed for time’.

prashna.text: You're making an appointment and will have to travel a long distance. How should you plan for the journey?

options.description: A. Plan to travel at busy times
B. Avoid roads with the national speed limit
C. Prevent other drivers from overtaking
D. Allow plenty of time for the trip

questions.explanation: Using the controls smoothly can reduce fuel consumption by about 15%, as well as reducing wear and tear on your vehicle. Plan ahead and anticipate changes of speed well in advance. This will reduce the need to accelerate rapidly or brake sharply.

prashna.text: What can rapid acceleration and heavy braking lead to?

options.description: A. Increased fuel consumption
B. Increased road safety
C. Reduced pollution
D. Reduced exhaust emissions

questions.explanation: You should carry out frequent checks on all fluid levels but particularly brake fluid. As the brake pads or shoes wear down, the brake fluid level will drop. If it drops below the minimum mark on the fluid reservoir, air could enter the hydraulic system and lead to a loss of braking efficiency or even complete brake failure.

prashna.text: Which of these, if allowed to get low, could cause you to crash?

options.description: A. Brake fluid level
B. Anti-freeze level
C. Battery water level
D. Radiator coolant level

questions.explanation: Uneven wear on your tyres can be caused by the condition of your vehicle. Having the vehicle serviced regularly will ensure that the brakes, steering, suspension and wheel alignment are maintained in good order.

prashna.text: What can cause excessive or uneven tyre wear?

options.description: A. Faults in the suspension
B. Faults in the exhaust system
C. Faults in the gearbox
D. Faults in the engine

questions.explanation: Brakes can overheat and lose efficiency when they’re used continually, such as on a long, steep, downhill stretch of road. Using a lower gear when you drive downhill can help prevent the vehicle from gaining speed.

prashna.text: What's the main cause of brake fade?

options.description: A. Oil on the brakes
B. The brakes overheating
C. The brakes out of adjustment
D. Air in the brake fluid

questions.explanation: Consult the vehicle handbook or a garage before driving the vehicle any further. Only drive to a garage if it's safe to do so. If you aren't sure, get expert help.

prashna.text: What should you do if your anti-lock brakes (ABS) warning light stays on?

options.description: A. Check the brake-fluid level
B. Check the footbrake free play
C. Check that the handbrake is released
D. Have the brakes checked immediately

questions.explanation: If this light comes on, you should have the brake system checked immediately. A faulty braking system could have dangerous consequences.

prashna.text: What does it mean if this light comes on while you’re driving?

options.description: A. The engine oil is low
B. Your seat belt isn't fastened
C. A fault in the braking system
D. A rear light has failed

questions.explanation:
When you’re going to drive, make sure that you’re wearing suitable clothing.
Comfortable shoes will ensure that you have proper control of the foot pedals.

prashna.text: It's important to wear suitable shoes when you're driving. Why is this?

options.description: A. To enable you to walk for assistance if you break down
B. To enable you to adjust your seat
C. To maintain control of the pedals
D. To prevent wear on the pedals

questions.explanation: If you’re involved in a collision, head restraints will reduce the risk of neck injury. They must be properly adjusted. Make sure they aren’t positioned too low: in a crash, this could cause damage to the neck.

prashna.text: What will reduce the risk of neck injury resulting from a collision?

options.description: A. A properly adjusted head restraint
B. A collapsible steering wheel
C. An air-sprung seat
D. Anti-lock brakes

questions.explanation: If you find that your vehicle bounces as you drive around a corner or bend in the road, the shock absorbers might be worn. Press down on the front wing and, if the vehicle continues to bounce, take it to be checked by a qualified mechanic.

prashna.text: You're testing your suspension. You notice that your vehicle keeps bouncing when you press down on the front wing. What does this mean?

options.description: A. Steering wheel not located centrally
B. Worn shock absorbers
C. Worn tyres
D. Tyres under-inflated

questions.explanation: A roof rack increases your car's wind resistance. This will cause an increase in fuel consumption, so you should remove it when it isn't being used. An aerodynamically designed roof rack or box will help reduce wind resistance to a minimum, but the rack or box should still be removed when it isn't in use.

prashna.text: How will a roof rack affect your car's performance?

options.description: A. The engine will use more oil
B. Fuel consumption will increase
C. The car will accelerate faster
D. There will be less wind noise

questions.explanation: Your tyres may be of different treads and makes. They can even be second-hand, as long as they're in good condition. They must, however, be intact, without cuts or tears. When checking the side walls for cuts and bulges, don’t forget to check the side of the tyre that's hidden from view, under the car.

prashna.text: Which of these makes your tyres illegal?

options.description: A. They have a large, deep cut in the side wall
B. They have different tread patterns
C. They were bought second-hand
D. They're of different makes

questions.explanation: Car tyres must have sufficient depth of tread to give them a good grip on the road surface. The legal minimum for cars is 1.6 mm. This depth should be across the central three-quarters of the breadth of the tyre and around the entire circumference.

prashna.text: What's the legal minimum depth of tread for car tyres?

options.description: A. 1 mm
B. 1.6 mm
C. 2.5 mm
D. 4 mm

questions.explanation: Seat belts save lives and reduce the risk of injury. If you're carrying passengers under 14 years old, it’s your responsibility as the driver to ensure that their seat belts are fastened or they're seated in an approved child restraint.

prashna.text: You're carrying two 13-year-old children and their parents in your car. Who's responsible for seeing that the children wear seat belts?

options.description: A. The front-seat passenger
B. You, the driver
C. The children
D. The children’s parents

questions.explanation:
Rapid acceleration and heavy braking lead to increased
• fuel consumption
• wear on your vehicle.
Having your vehicle serviced regularly will maintain its efficiency, produce cleaner emissions and reduce the risk of a breakdown.

prashna.text: How can drivers help the environment?

options.description: A. By driving faster
B. By accelerating gently
C. By using leaded fuel
D. By accelerating harshly

questions.explanation: If you don’t have your vehicle serviced regularly, the engine will gradually become less efficient. This will cause increased fuel consumption and, in turn, an increase in the amount of harmful emissions it produces.

prashna.text: How can you avoid wasting fuel?

options.description: A. By having your vehicle serviced regularly
B. By keeping an empty roof rack on your vehicle
C. By revving the engine in the lower gears
D. By driving at higher speeds where possible

questions.explanation: Try not to use your car as a matter of routine. For shorter journeys, consider walking or cycling instead – this is much better for both you and the environment.

prashna.text: What could you do to reduce the volume of traffic on the roads?

options.description: A. Drive in a bus lane
B. Walk or cycle on short journeys
C. Use a car with a smaller engine
D. Travel by car at all times

questions.explanation: Wasting fuel costs you money and also causes unnecessary pollution. Ensuring your tyres are correctly inflated, avoiding carrying unnecessary weight and removing a roof rack that's not in use will all help to reduce your fuel consumption.

prashna.text: What’s most likely to waste fuel?

options.description: A. Under-inflated tyres
B. Driving on motorways
C. Using different brands of fuel
D. Reducing your speed

questions.explanation: Unless exempt, you and your passengers must wear a seat belt (or suitable child restraint). The seat belts in your car must be in good condition and working properly; they’ll be checked during its MOT test.

prashna.text: What does the law require you to keep in good condition?

options.description: A. Seat belts
B. Transmission
C. Door locks
D. Gears

questions.explanation: Your vehicle will use less fuel if you avoid heavy acceleration. The higher the engine revs, the more fuel you'll use. Using the same gear, and covering the same distance, a vehicle travelling at 70 mph will use up to 30% more fuel than it would at 50 mph. However, don’t travel so slowly that you inconvenience or endanger other road users.

prashna.text: Up to how much more fuel will you use by driving at 70 mph, compared with driving at 50 mph?

questions.explanation: The brakes on your vehicle must be effective and properly adjusted. If your vehicle pulls to one side when braking, take it to be checked by a qualified mechanic as soon as you can.

prashna.text: When you use the brakes, your vehicle pulls to one side. What should you do?

options.description: A. Change gear and pump the brake pedal
B. Have the brakes checked as soon as possible
C. Use your parking brake at the same time
D. Increase the pressure in your tyres

questions.explanation: If your wheels are out of balance, it will cause the steering to vibrate at certain speeds. This isn't a fault that will put itself right, so take your vehicle to a garage or tyre fitter to have the wheels rebalanced.

prashna.text: What will happen if your car's wheels are unbalanced?

options.description: A. The tyres will deflate
B. The brakes will fail
C. The steering will vibrate
D. The steering will pull to one side

questions.explanation: Turning the steering wheel when the car isn't moving is known as dry steering. It can cause unnecessary wear to the tyres and steering mechanism.

prashna.text: Turning the steering wheel while stationary can cause damage to which part of your car?

options.description: A. Tyres
B. Engine
C. Brakes
D. Gearbox

questions.explanation: If you have to leave valuables in your car, lock them out of sight. This is the best way to deter an opportunist thief.

prashna.text: You have to leave valuables in your car. What’s the safest thing to do?

options.description: A. Put them in a carrier bag
B. Park near a school entrance
C. Park near a bus stop
D. Lock them out of sight

questions.explanation: Having your car registration number etched on all your windows is a cheap and effective way to deter professional car thieves.

prashna.text: Which of the following may help to deter a thief from stealing your car?

options.description: A. Etching the registration number on the windows
B. Always keeping the interior light on
C. Fitting reflective glass windows
D. Always keeping the headlights on

questions.explanation: Never leave the vehicle registration document inside your car. This document would help a thief to dispose of your car more easily.

prashna.text: Which of the following shouldn't be kept in your vehicle?

options.description: A. The service record
B. The vehicle registration document
C. The owner’s manual
D. The car dealer’s details

questions.explanation: An unlocked car is an open invitation to thieves. Leaving the keys in the ignition not only makes your car easy to steal but could also invalidate your insurance.

prashna.text: What should you do when leaving your vehicle parked and unattended?

options.description: A. Leave the left indicator on
B. Park near a busy junction
C. Lock it and remove the key
D. Park in a housing estate

questions.explanation:
Harsh braking, frequent gear changes and harsh acceleration increase fuel consumption. An engine uses less fuel when travelling at a constant low speed.
You need to look well ahead so you’re able to anticipate hazards early. Easing off the accelerator and timing your approach at junctions, for example, can reduce the fuel consumption of your vehicle.

prashna.text: What will improve fuel consumption?

options.description: A. Driving in lower gears
B. Reducing your speed
C. Late and harsh braking
D. Rapid acceleration

questions.explanation: It's illegal to pour engine oil down any drain. Oil is a pollutant and harmful to wildlife. Dispose of it safely at an authorised site.

prashna.text: You service your own vehicle. How should you get rid of the old engine oil?

options.description: A. Tip it into a hole in the ground
B. Take it to a local-authority site
C. Put it in your dustbin
D. Pour it down a drain

questions.explanation: Emission tests are carried out to make sure your vehicle’s engine is operating efficiently. This ensures the pollution produced by the engine is kept to a minimum. If your vehicle isn't serviced regularly, it may fail the annual MOT test.

prashna.text: Why do MOT tests include a strict exhaust emission test?

options.description: A. To discover which fuel supplier is used the most
B. To recover the cost of expensive garage equipment
C. To help protect the environment against pollution
D. To make sure diesel and petrol engines emit the same fumes

questions.explanation: By looking well ahead and recognising hazards in good time, you can avoid late and heavy braking. Watch the traffic flow and look well ahead for potential hazards so you can control your speed in good time. Avoid over-revving the engine and accelerating harshly, as this increases wear to the engine and uses more fuel.

prashna.text: How can you reduce the damage your vehicle causes to the environment?

options.description: A. Brake heavily
B. Anticipate well ahead
C. Use busy routes
D. Use narrow side streets

questions.explanation: All vehicles need to be serviced to keep working efficiently. An efficient engine uses less fuel and produces fewer harmful emissions than an engine that's running inefficiently. Keeping the vehicle serviced to the manufacturer's schedule should also make it more reliable and reduce the chance of it breaking down.

prashna.text: What will be the result of having your vehicle properly serviced?

options.description: A. Slower journey times
B. Better fuel economy
C. Reduced insurance premiums
D. Lower vehicle tax

questions.explanation: The humps are there for a reason – to protect vulnerable road users by reducing the speed of traffic. Don’t accelerate harshly between the humps. Put the safety of others first and maintain a reduced speed throughout the zone.

prashna.text: You enter a road where there are road humps. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate quickly between each one
B. Always keep to the maximum legal speed
C. Maintain a reduced speed throughout
D. Drive slowly at school times only

questions.explanation:
An engine can use more oil during long journeys than on shorter trips. Insufficient engine oil is potentially dangerous: it can lead to excessive wear, mechanical breakdown and expensive repairs.
Most cars have a dipstick to allow the oil level to be checked. If not, you should refer to the vehicle handbook.

prashna.text: When should you especially check the engine oil level?

options.description: A. When the engine is hot
B. Every 6000 miles
C. Before a long journey
D. Early in the morning

questions.explanation: It’s an offence to park on the zigzag lines of a zebra crossing. You'll be causing an obstruction by obscuring the view of both pedestrians and drivers.

prashna.text: You're having difficulty finding a parking space in a busy town. You can see there's space on the zigzag lines of a zebra crossing. Can you park there?

options.description: A. Yes, if you don't block people from crossing
B. No, not unless you stay with your car
C. Yes, in order to drop off a passenger
D. No, not under any circumstances

questions.explanation: Always switch off the engine, remove the key and lock your car, even if you're only leaving it for a few minutes.

prashna.text: What should you do when you leave your car unattended for a few minutes?

options.description: A. Leave the engine running
B. Park near a traffic warden
C. Switch the engine off but leave the key in
D. Lock it and remove the key

questions.explanation: Whenever possible, leave your car in a secure car park. This will help deter thieves.

prashna.text: When leaving your vehicle, where should you try to park?

options.description: A. At or near a taxi rank
B. In a secure car park
C. Opposite a traffic island
D. On a bend

questions.explanation: Don’t park your vehicle where it may obstruct access to a business or property. Think carefully before you slow down and stop. Look at road markings and signs to ensure that you aren’t parking illegally.

prashna.text: Where would parking your vehicle cause an obstruction?

options.description: A. On your driveway
B. In front of a property entrance
C. Alongside a parking meter
D. In a marked parking space

questions.explanation: In a collision, rapid deceleration will violently throw vehicle occupants forward and then backwards as the vehicle stops. Seat belts and airbags protect occupants against the forward movement. Head restraints should be adjusted so they give maximum protection to the head and neck during the backward movement.

prashna.text: What's the most important reason for having a properly adjusted head restraint?

options.description: A. To help you relax
B. To make you more comfortable
C. To help you avoid neck injury
D. To help you maintain your driving position

questions.explanation: Avoid using your car for short journeys. On a short journey, the engine is unlikely to warm up fully and will therefore be running less efficiently. This will result in the car using more fuel and producing higher levels of harmful emissions.

prashna.text: What causes the most damage to the environment?

options.description: A. Choosing a fuel-efficient vehicle
B. Driving in as high a gear as possible
C. Making a lot of short journeys
D. Having your vehicle serviced regularly

questions.explanation: Using a vehicle for short journeys means the engine doesn't have time to reach its normal operating temperature. When an engine is running below its normal operating temperature, it produces increased amounts of pollution. Walking and cycling don't create pollution and have health benefits as well.

prashna.text: What can people who live or work in towns and cities do to help reduce urban pollution levels?

options.description: A. Drive short journeys
B. Drive more quickly
C. Walk or cycle
D. Over-rev in a low gear

questions.explanation: When leaving your car, take all valuables with you if you can. Otherwise, lock them out of sight.

prashna.text: How can you reduce the chances of your car being broken into when leaving it unattended?

options.description: A. Take all valuables with you
B. Park near a fire station
C. Park near a taxi rank
D. Place any valuables on the floor

questions.explanation: A security-coded radio can deter thieves, as it's likely to be of little use when removed from the vehicle.

prashna.text: How can you help to prevent your car radio being stolen?

options.description: A. Install a security-coded radio
B. Park in an unlit area
C. Park near a busy junction
D. Leave the radio turned on

questions.explanation: Having your vehicle broken into or stolen can be very distressing and inconvenient. Avoid leaving your vehicle unattended in poorly-lit areas.

prashna.text: How can you lessen the risk of your vehicle being broken into at night?

options.description: A. Don’t engage the steering lock
B. Park in a quiet side road
C. Leave it in a well-lit area
D. Park in a poorly-lit area

questions.explanation: The vehicle watch scheme helps to reduce the risk of your car being stolen. By displaying high-visibility vehicle watch stickers in your car, you're inviting the police to stop your vehicle if it's seen in use between midnight and 5 am.

prashna.text: Which of these will help you to keep your car secure?

options.description: A. Advanced driver’s scheme
B. Vehicle breakdown organisation
C. Car maintenance class
D. Vehicle watch scheme

questions.explanation: Although carbon dioxide is still produced, a catalytic converter fitted to the exhaust system reduces the toxic and polluting gases by up to 90%.

prashna.text: On a vehicle, where would you find a catalytic converter?

options.description: A. On the cooling system
B. In the fuel tank
C. In the air filter
D. On the exhaust system

questions.explanation: By driving smoothly, you'll not only save about 15% of your fuel but will also reduce the amount of wear and tear on your vehicle and the level of pollution it produces. You're also likely to feel more relaxed and have a more pleasant journey.

prashna.text: What can driving smoothly achieve?

options.description: A. Reduction in journey times by about 15%
B. Reduction in fuel consumption by about 15%
C. Increase in fuel consumption by about 15%
D. Increase in journey times by about 15%

questions.explanation: Missing out intermediate gears, when appropriate, helps to reduce the amount of time spent accelerating and decelerating – the times when your vehicle uses the most fuel.

prashna.text: Which driving technique can help you save fuel?

options.description: A. Missing out some gears
B. Using lower gears as often as possible
C. Using each gear in turn
D. Accelerating sharply in each gear

questions.explanation: Ecosafe driving is all about becoming a more environmentally friendly driver. This will make your journeys more comfortable, as well as considerably reducing your fuel bills and reducing emissions that can damage the environment.

prashna.text: How can driving in an ecosafe manner help protect the environment?

options.description: A. By increasing the number of cars on the road
B. Through increased fuel bills
C. By reducing exhaust emissions
D. Through the legal enforcement of speed regulations

questions.explanation: The emphasis is on hazard awareness and planning ahead. By looking well ahead, you'll have plenty of time to deal with hazards safely and won’t need to brake sharply. This will also reduce damage to the environment.

prashna.text: What does ecosafe driving achieve?

options.description: A. Increased fuel consumption
B. Damage to the environment
C. Improved road safety
D. Increased exhaust emissions

questions.explanation: Trailers and caravans may be left in storage over the winter months, and tyres can deteriorate. It’s important to check their tread depth and also their pressures and general condition. The legal tread depth of 1.6 mm applies to the central three-quarters of a tyre's breadth, over its entire circumference.

prashna.text: You're checking your trailer tyres. What's the legal minimum tread depth over the central three-quarters of its breadth?

options.description: A. 2 mm
B. 1.6 mm
C. 2.6 mm
D. 1 mm

questions.explanation: Accelerating uses a lot of fuel, so always try to use the accelerator smoothly. Taking your foot off the accelerator allows the momentum of the car to take you forward, especially when going downhill. This can save a considerable amount of fuel without any loss of control over the vehicle.

prashna.text: Fuel consumption is at its highest when you're doing what?

options.description: A. Coasting
B. Steering
C. Accelerating
D. Braking

questions.explanation: If you have adult passengers, it's their responsibility to wear a seat belt, but you should still remind them to use one as they get in the car. It's your responsibility to make sure that all children in your car are secured with an appropriate restraint. Exemptions are allowed for those with a medical exemption certificate.

prashna.text: When is it acceptable for a passenger to travel in a car without wearing wearing a seat belt?

options.description: A. When they're under 1.5 metres (5 feet) in height
B. When they're exempt for medical reasons
C. When they're under 14 years old
D. When they're sitting in the rear seat

questions.explanation: Passengers should always be secured and safe. Children should be encouraged to fasten their seat belts or approved restraints themselves from an early age, so that it becomes a matter of routine. As the driver, you must check that they're fastened securely. It’s your responsibility.

prashna.text: You're driving a friend's children home from school. They're both under 14 years old. Who's responsible for making sure they wear a seat belt or approved child restraint where required?

options.description: A. You, the driver
B. An adult passenger
C. The children
D. Your friend

questions.explanation: Too much oil in the engine will create excess pressure and could damage engine seals and cause oil leaks. Any excess oil should be drained off.

prashna.text: You have too much oil in your engine. What could this cause?

options.description: A. Chain wear
B. Oil leaks
C. Low oil pressure
D. Engine overheating

questions.explanation: Usually, a correct child restraint must be used. In cases where one isn't available, an adult seat belt must be used instead. In a collision, unrestrained objects and people can cause serious injury or even death.

prashna.text: You're carrying a five-year-old child in the back seat of your car. They're under 1.35 metres (4 feet 5 inches) tall. A correct child restraint isn't available. How should you seat them?

options.description: A. Sharing a belt with an adult
B. Using an adult seat belt
C. Between two other children
D. Behind the passenger seat

questions.explanation: As the driver, it's your responsibility to make sure that children are secure and safe in your vehicle. Make yourself familiar with the rules. In a few very exceptional cases when a child restraint isn't available, an adult seat belt must be used.

prashna.text: You're carrying an 11-year-old child in the back seat of your car. They're under 1.35 metres (4 feet 5 inches) tall. What must you make sure of?

options.description: A. That they can fasten their own seat belt
B. That they sit between two belted people
C. That they can see clearly out of the front window
D. That a suitable child restraint is available

questions.explanation: If your vehicle is stationary and is likely to remain so for some time, switch off the engine. We should all try to reduce global warming and pollution.

prashna.text: You're parked at the side of the road. You'll be waiting some time for a passenger. What should you do?

options.description: A. Use your headlights
B. Switch off the engine
C. Switch off the radio
D. Apply the steering lock

questions.explanation: It's illegal to fit a rear-facing baby seat into a passenger seat protected by an active frontal airbag. If the airbag activates, it could cause serious injury or even death to the child. You must secure it in a different seat or deactivate the relevant airbag. Follow the manufacturer's advice when fitting a baby seat.

prashna.text: You want to put a rear-facing baby seat on the front passenger seat, which is protected by a frontal airbag. What must you do before setting off?

options.description: A. Deactivate the airbag
B. Turn the seat to face sideways
C. Ask a passenger to hold the baby
D. Put the child in an adult seat belt

questions.explanation: When you leave your vehicle parked on a road, switch off the engine and secure the vehicle. Make sure no valuables are visible, shut all the windows, lock the vehicle, and set the alarm the vehicle has one.

prashna.text: You're leaving your vehicle parked on a road and unattended. When may you leave the engine running?

options.description: A. Never if you're away from the vehicle
B. When parked in a 20 mph zone
C. If you'll be parking for less than five minutes
D. If the battery keeps going flat

questions.explanation: Tyre grip is greatly reduced in icy conditions. For this reason, you need to allow up to ten times the stopping distance you would allow on dry roads.

prashna.text: By how much can stopping distances increase in icy conditions?

options.description: A. Three times
B. Five times
C. Two times
D. Ten times

questions.explanation: Always give cyclists plenty of room when overtaking them. You need to give them even more room when it’s windy. A sudden gust could easily blow them off course and into your path.

prashna.text: In windy conditions, which activity requires extra care?

options.description: A. Moving off on a hill
B. Turning into a narrow road
C. Using the brakes
D. Passing pedal cyclists

questions.explanation: Doing this will give you an earlier view around the bend and enable you to see any hazards sooner. It also reduces the risk of collision with an oncoming vehicle that may have drifted over the centre line while taking the bend.

prashna.text: When approaching a right-hand bend, you should keep well to the left. Why is this?

options.description: A. To overcome the effect of the road’s slope
B. To let faster traffic from behind overtake
C. To be positioned safely if you skid
D. To improve your view of the road

questions.explanation: Water on the brakes will act as a lubricant, causing them to work less efficiently. Using the brakes lightly as you go along will quickly dry them out.

prashna.text: You’ve just gone through deep water. What should you do to make sure your brakes are working properly?

options.description: A. Avoid using the brakes at all for a few miles
B. Accelerate and keep to a high speed for a short time
C. Go slowly while gently applying the brakes
D. Stop for at least an hour to allow them time to dry

questions.explanation: If the road surface becomes very hot, it can soften. Tyres are unable to grip a soft surface as well as they can a firm dry one. Take care when cornering and braking.

prashna.text: In very hot weather the road surface can become soft. What will this affect?

options.description: A. The suspension
B. The exhaust emissions
C. The tyre grip
D. The fuel consumption

questions.explanation: In windy conditions, care must be taken on exposed roads. A strong gust of wind can blow you off course. Watch out for other road users who are particularly likely to be affected, such as cyclists, motorcyclists, high-sided lorries and vehicles towing trailers.

prashna.text: Where are you most likely to be affected by side winds?

options.description: A. On a busy stretch of road
B. On a long, straight road
C. On a narrow country lane
D. On an open stretch of road

questions.explanation: Note that this is the typical stopping distance. It will take at least this distance to think, brake and stop in good conditions. In poor conditions, it will take much longer.

prashna.text: In good conditions, what's the typical stopping distance at 70 mph?

options.description: A. 96 metres (315 feet)
B. 53 metres (175 feet)
C. 60 metres (197 feet)
D. 73 metres (240 feet)

questions.explanation: This distance is the equivalent of 18 car lengths. Try pacing out 73 metres and then look back. It’s probably further than you think.

prashna.text: What's the shortest overall stopping distance on a dry road at 60 mph?

options.description: A. 73 metres (240 feet)
B. 53 metres (175 feet)
C. 58 metres (190 feet)
D. 96 metres (315 feet)

questions.explanation: Wet weather will affect the time it takes for you to stop and can affect your control. Your speed should allow you to stop safely and in good time. If another vehicle pulls into the gap you’ve left, ease back until you’ve regained your stopping distance.

prashna.text: You're following a vehicle at a safe distance on a wet road. Another driver overtakes you and pulls into the gap you've left. What should you do?

options.description: A. Flash your headlights as a warning
B. Drop back to regain a safe distance
C. Try to overtake safely as soon as you can
D. Stay close to the other vehicle until it moves on

questions.explanation: Even in good conditions, it will usually take you further than you think to stop. Don’t just learn the figures; make sure you understand how far the distance is.

prashna.text: You're travelling at 50 mph on a good, dry road. What's your typical overall stopping distance?

options.description: A. 53 metres (175 feet)
B. 96 metres (315 feet)
C. 36 metres (118 feet)
D. 75 metres (245 feet)

questions.explanation: Stopping distances are affected by a number of variables. These include the type, model and condition of your vehicle, the road and weather conditions, and your reaction time. Look well ahead for hazards and leave enough space between you and the vehicle in front. This should allow you to pull up safely if you have to, without braking sharply.

prashna.text: You're on a good, dry road surface. Your brakes and tyres are good. What's the typical overall stopping distance at 40 mph?

options.description: A. 23 metres (75 feet)
B. 36 metres (118 feet)
C. 53 metres (175 feet)
D. 96 metres (315 feet)

questions.explanation: In strong winds, riders of two-wheeled vehicles are particularly vulnerable. When you overtake them, allow plenty of room. Always check to the left as you pass.

prashna.text: What should you do when overtaking a motorcyclist in strong winds?

options.description: A. Pass immediately
B. Pass very slowly
C. Pass wide
D. Pass closely

questions.explanation: Be aware that this is just the braking distance. You need to add the thinking distance to this to give the overall stopping distance. At 50 mph, the typical thinking distance will be 15 metres (50 feet), plus a braking distance of 38 metres (125 feet), giving an overall stopping distance of 53 metres (175 feet). The stopping distance could be greater than this, depending on your attention and response to any hazards. These figures are a general guide.

prashna.text: Overall stopping distance is made up of thinking distance and braking distance. You're on a good, dry road surface, with good brakes and tyres. What's the typical braking distance from 50 mph?

options.description: A. 24 metres (80 feet)
B. 38 metres (125 feet)
C. 55 metres (180 feet)
D. 14 metres (46 feet)

questions.explanation: On busy roads, traffic may still travel at high speeds despite being close together. Don’t follow the vehicle in front too closely. If a driver behind seems to be ‘pushing’ you, gradually increase your distance from the vehicle in front by slowing down gently. This will give you more space in front if you have to brake, and will reduce the risk of a collision involving several vehicles.

prashna.text: In heavy motorway traffic, the vehicle behind you is following too closely. How can you lower the risk of a collision?

options.description: A. Switch on your hazard warning lights
B. Increase your distance from the vehicle in front
C. Move onto the hard shoulder and stop
D. Brake sharply

questions.explanation: When it’s foggy, use dipped headlights. This will help you see and be seen by other road users. If visibility is seriously reduced, consider using front and rear fog lights if you have them. Keep to a sensible speed and don’t follow the vehicle in front too closely. If the road is wet and slippery, you’ll need to allow twice the normal stopping distance.

prashna.text: You're following other vehicles in fog. You have your lights on. What else can you do to reduce the chances of being in a collision?

options.description: A. Keep close to the vehicle in front
B. Use your main beam instead of dipped headlights
C. Keep up with the faster vehicles
D. Reduce your speed and increase the gap in front

questions.explanation: In a contraflow system, you'll be travelling close to oncoming traffic and sometimes in narrow lanes. You should get into the correct lane in good time, obey any temporary speed-limit signs and keep a safe separation distance from the vehicle ahead.

prashna.text: You're using a contraflow system. What should you do?
