options.description: A. Follow other motorists closely to avoid long queues
B. Switch lanes at any time to make progress
C. Choose an appropriate lane in good time
D. Increase speed to pass through quickly

questions.explanation: If you’re travelling on an icy road, extra caution will be required to avoid loss of control. Keeping your speed down and using the highest gear possible will reduce the risk of the tyres losing their grip on this slippery surface.

prashna.text: You're driving on an icy road. How can you avoid wheelspin?

options.description: A. Drive in a low gear at all times
B. Use the handbrake if the wheels start to slip
C. Brake gently and repeatedly
D. Drive at a slow speed in as high a gear as possible

questions.explanation: Skidding is usually caused by driver error. You should always adjust your driving to take account of the road and weather conditions.

prashna.text: What's the main cause of skidding?

options.description: A. The driver
B. The weather
C. The vehicle
D. The road

questions.explanation: Harsh use of the accelerator, brakes or steering is likely to lead to skidding, especially on slippery surfaces. Avoid steering and braking at the same time. In icy conditions it’s very important that you constantly assess what’s ahead, so that you can take appropriate action in plenty of time.

prashna.text: You're driving in freezing conditions. What should you do when approaching a sharp bend?

options.description: A. Slow down before you reach the bend
B. Coast into the bend
C. Firmly use your footbrake
D. Gently apply your handbrake

questions.explanation: To correct a skid, you need to steer into it. However, be careful not to overcorrect with too much steering, as this may cause a skid in the opposite direction. Skids don’t just happen; they're caused – usually by the driver. Factors increasing the likelihood of a skid include the condition of the vehicle (especially its tyres) and the road and weather conditions.

prashna.text: You're turning left on a slippery road. What should you do if the back of your vehicle slides to the right?

options.description: A. Steer carefully to the left
B. Steer carefully to the right
C. Brake firmly and steer to the left
D. Brake firmly and don't turn the steering wheel

questions.explanation: Driving in bad weather increases your risk of having a collision. If you absolutely have to travel, clear your lights, mirrors, number plates and windows of any snow or ice, so that you can see and be seen.

prashna.text: What should you clear of ice and snow before starting a journey in freezing weather?

options.description: A. The boot
B. The windows
C. The aerial
D. The bumper

questions.explanation: If you attempt to move off in a low gear, there will be more torque (turning force) at the driven wheels than if you use a higher gear. More torque makes it easier for the tyres to lose grip and so spin the wheels.

prashna.text: What will help when you're trying to move off on snow?

options.description: A. Use the handbrake and footbrake together
B. Use a high engine speed
C. Use a higher gear than normal
D. Use the car's lowest gear

questions.explanation: In snowy conditions, be careful with the steering, accelerator and brakes. Braking sharply while you're driving on snow is likely to make your car skid.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're driving in snowy conditions?

options.description: A. Brake gently in plenty of time
B. Use sidelights only
C. Brake firmly and quickly
D. Be ready to steer sharply

questions.explanation: By driving all four wheels, the vehicle has maximum grip on the road. This grip is especially helpful when travelling on slippery or uneven surfaces. However, having four-wheel drive doesn't replace the skills you need to drive safely.

prashna.text: What's the main benefit of driving a four-wheel-drive vehicle?

options.description: A. Shorter stopping distances
B. Improved grip on the road
C. Improved passenger comfort
D. Lower fuel consumption

questions.explanation: When driving down a steep hill, gravity will cause your vehicle to speed up. This will make it more difficult for you to stop. To help keep your vehicle's speed under control, select a lower gear to give you more engine braking and make careful use of the brakes.

prashna.text: You're about to go down a steep hill. What should you do to control the speed of your vehicle?

options.description: A. Select a low gear and avoid using the brakes
B. Select a high gear and use the brakes carefully
C. Select a high gear and use the brakes firmly
D. Select a low gear and use the brakes carefully

questions.explanation: Turning the wheels towards the kerb will allow them to act as a chock, preventing any forward movement of the vehicle. It will also help to leave your car in gear, or select ‘Park’ if you have an automatic.

prashna.text: What should you do when parking your vehicle facing downhill?

options.description: A. Park with two wheels on the kerb
B. Park close to the bumper of another car
C. Turn the steering wheel towards the kerb
D. Turn the steering wheel away from the kerb

questions.explanation: Many towns have road humps as part of traffic-calming measures, designed to slow down traffic. Reduce your speed when driving over them. If you go too fast, you could lose control or damage your car. Look out for pedestrians or cyclists while you're driving in these areas.

prashna.text: You're driving in a built-up area that has traffic-calming measures. What should you do when you approach a road hump?

options.description: A. Move across to the left-hand side of the road
B. Stop and check both pavements
C. Check your mirror and slow down
D. Wait for any pedestrians to cross

questions.explanation: The anti-lock braking system (ABS) will operate when the brakes have been applied harshly and the wheels are about to lock, such as during an emergency. ABS will reduce the likelihood of your car skidding, but it isn't a substitute for safe and responsible driving.

prashna.text: Anti-lock brakes reduce the chances of skidding. When is this particularly important?

options.description: A. When you're driving down steep hills
B. When you're braking during normal driving
C. When you're driving on good road surfaces
D. When you're braking in an emergency

questions.explanation: Poor contact with the road surface could cause one or more of the tyres to lose grip on the road. This is more likely to happen when braking in poor weather conditions and when the road has a loose, slippery or uneven surface.

prashna.text: On what type of road surface may anti-lock brakes not work effectively?

options.description: A. Firm
B. Smooth
C. Loose
D. Dry

questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes won't be needed when you're braking normally. Looking well down the road and anticipating possible hazards could prevent you from having to brake late and harshly. Knowing that you have anti-lock brakes isn't an excuse to drive in a careless or reckless way.

prashna.text: When are anti-lock brakes of most use to you?

options.description: A. When you’re braking on a motorway
B. When you’re braking on rural roads
C. When you’re braking harshly
D. When you’re braking gently

questions.explanation: If the wheels of your vehicle lock, they won't grip the road and you'll lose steering control. In good conditions, the anti-lock braking system (ABS) will prevent the wheels from locking and you'll keep control of your steering. In poor weather conditions or on loose surfaces, the ABS may be less effective.

prashna.text: What does driving a vehicle with anti-lock brakes allow you to do?

options.description: A. Brake harder because it's impossible to skid
B. Steer and brake harshly at the same time
C. Pay less attention to the road ahead
D. Drive at higher speeds

questions.explanation: You may have to stop in an emergency due to a misjudgement by another driver or a hazard arising suddenly, such as a child running out into the road. If your vehicle has anti-lock brakes, you should apply the brakes immediately and keep them firmly applied until you stop.

prashna.text: You're driving a vehicle that has anti-lock brakes. How should you apply the footbrake when you need to stop in an emergency?

options.description: A. Rapidly and gently
B. Slowly but firmly
C. Rapidly and firmly
D. Slowly and gently

questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes may be ineffective on gravel or loose surfaces. They may also be ineffective in very wet weather, when water can build up between the tyre and the road surface; this is known as aquaplaning.

prashna.text: In which conditions are your anti-lock brakes most unlikely to prevent skidding?

options.description: A. On loose road surfaces
B. At night on unlit roads
C. On dry tarmac
D. In foggy conditions

questions.explanation: If your brakes have been thoroughly soaked, you should check that they’re working properly before you build up speed again. Before you do this, remember to check your mirrors and consider what’s behind you.

prashna.text: You're driving along a country road. You see this sign. What should you do after dealing safely with the hazard?

options.description: A. Accelerate briskly
B. Check your tyre pressures
C. Switch on your hazard warning lights
D. Test your brakes

questions.explanation:
Drive extremely carefully when the roads are icy. When travelling on ice, tyres make virtually no noise and the steering feels light and unresponsive.
In icy conditions, be very gentle when braking, accelerating and steering.

prashna.text: What would suggest you're driving on ice?

options.description: A. There's less transmission noise
B. There's less tyre noise
C. There's less wind noise
D. There's less engine noise

questions.explanation: If you drive at speed in very wet conditions, your steering may suddenly feel lighter than usual. This means that the tyres have lifted off the surface of the road and are skating on the surface of the water. This is known as aquaplaning. Reduce speed but don’t brake until your steering returns to normal.

prashna.text: You're driving along a wet road. How can you tell if your vehicle’s tyres are losing their grip on the surface?

options.description: A. The steering will feel very light
B. The engine will stall
C. The steering will feel very heavy
D. The engine noise will increase

questions.explanation: Extra care should be taken in wet weather. On wet roads, your stopping distance could be double that in dry conditions.

prashna.text: In which conditions will your overall stopping distance increase?

options.description: A. In the rain
B. In fog
C. In strong winds
D. At night

questions.explanation: One way of checking there's a safe distance between you and the vehicle in front is to use the two-second rule. To check for a two-second time gap, choose a stationary object ahead, such as a bridge or road sign. When the car in front passes the object, say 'Only a fool breaks the two-second rule'. If you reach the object before you finish saying the phrase, you're too close and need to increase the gap.

prashna.text: You're driving on an open road in dry weather. What should the distance be between you and the vehicle in front?

options.description: A. A two-second time gap
B. Two metres (6 feet 6 inches)
C. Two car lengths
D. One car length

questions.explanation: When driving on downhill stretches of road, selecting a lower gear gives increased engine braking. This will prevent excessive use of the brakes, which become less effective if they overheat.

prashna.text: How can you use your vehicle’s engine as a brake?

options.description: A. By changing to a higher gear
B. By changing to a lower gear
C. By selecting reverse gear
D. By selecting neutral gear

questions.explanation: If you have ABS and need to stop in an emergency, keep your foot firmly on the brake pedal until the vehicle has stopped. When the ABS operates, you may hear a grating sound and feel vibration through the brake pedal. This is normal and you should maintain pressure on the brake pedal until the vehicle stops.

prashna.text: When are anti-lock brakes (ABS) most effective?

options.description: A. When you keep pumping the foot brake to prevent skidding
B. When you brake promptly and firmly until you've stopped
C. When you brake normally but grip the steering wheel tightly
D. When you apply the handbrake to reduce the stopping distance

questions.explanation: If your car is fitted with anti-lock brakes, they'll only activate when they sense that the wheels are about to lock. By preventing the wheels from locking, you'll be able to steer to avoid the hazard, while maximum braking is also applied.

prashna.text: When will anti-lock brakes take effect?

options.description: A. When you don't brake quickly enough
B. When you haven't seen a hazard ahead
C. When the wheels are about to lock
D. When you're speeding on a slippery road surface

questions.explanation: When surface spray reduces visibility, switch on your dipped headlights. This will help other road users to see you.

prashna.text: You're driving on a wet motorway with surface spray. What lights should you use?

options.description: A. Sidelights
B. Rear fog lights
C. Hazard warning lights
D. Dipped headlights

questions.explanation: Coasting is the term used when the clutch is held down, or the gear lever is in neutral, and the vehicle is allowed to freewheel. This reduces the driver’s control of the vehicle. When you coast, the engine can’t drive the wheels to stabilise you through a corner, or give the assistance of engine braking to help slow the car.

prashna.text: What can result when you travel for long distances in neutral (known as coasting)?

options.description: A. Improvement in control
B. Easier steering
C. Reduction in control
D. Increased fuel consumption

questions.explanation: Don’t venture out if your journey isn’t necessary. If you have to travel and someone is expecting you at the other end, let them know that you’ll be taking longer than usual for your journey. This will stop them worrying if you don’t turn up on time and will also take the pressure off you, so you don’t feel you have to rush.

prashna.text: What should you do when driving in fog?

options.description: A. Use sidelights only
B. Keep close to the car in front
C. Position close to the centre line
D. Allow more time for your journey

questions.explanation: These markers must be fitted to vehicles over 13 metres long, large goods vehicles, and rubbish skips placed in the road. They’re reflective to make them easier to see in the dark.

prashna.text: Where would you expect to see these markers?

options.description: A. On a large goods vehicle
B. On a railway bridge
C. On a diversion sign
D. On a motorway sign

questions.explanation: Look at the picture carefully and try to imagine you’re there. The cyclist in this picture appears to be trying to cross the road. You must be able to deal with the unexpected, especially when you’re approaching a hazardous junction. Look well ahead to give yourself time to deal with any hazards.

prashna.text: What's the main hazard shown in this picture?

options.description: A. Vehicles turning right
B. The cyclist crossing the road
C. Vehicles doing U-turns
D. Parked cars around the corner

questions.explanation:
The car arrowed A is parked within the area marked by zigzag lines at the pedestrian crossing. Parking here is illegal. It also
• blocks the view for pedestrians wishing to cross the road
• restricts the view of the crossing for approaching traffic.

prashna.text: Which road user has caused a hazard?

options.description: A. The pedestrian waiting to cross (arrowed B)
B. The car turning (arrowed D)
C. The parked car (arrowed A)
D. The moving car (arrowed C)

questions.explanation: Look well ahead to see whether any hazards are developing. This will give you more time to deal with them in the correct way. The man in the picture is clearly intending to cross the road. You should be travelling at a speed that allows you to check your mirror, slow down and stop in good time. You shouldn’t have to brake harshly.

prashna.text: What should the driver of the car approaching the crossing do?

options.description: A. Slow down and get ready to stop
B. Drive through quickly
C. Sound the horn
D. Continue at the same speed

questions.explanation: When passing parked cars, there's a risk that a driver or passenger may not check before opening the door into the road. A defensive driver will drive slowly and be looking for people who may be about to get out of their car.

prashna.text: What should the driver of the grey car (arrowed) be especially aware of?

options.description: A. Empty parking spaces
B. Traffic following behind
C. The uneven road surface
D. Doors opening on parked cars

questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road will bend sharply to the left. Slow down in plenty of time and select the correct gear before you start to turn. Braking hard and late, while also sharply changing direction, is likely to cause a skid.

prashna.text: You see this sign ahead. What should you expect?

options.description: A. The road will bend sharply to the right
B. The road will go steeply uphill
C. The road will go steeply downhill
D. The road will bend sharply to the left

questions.explanation: Keep well back and give the cyclist time and room to turn safely. Don’t intimidate them by getting too close or trying to squeeze past.

prashna.text: You're approaching this cyclist. What should you do?

options.description: A. Flash your headlights at the cyclist
B. Slow down and allow the cyclist to turn
C. Overtake the cyclist on the left-hand side
D. Overtake before the cyclist gets to the junction

questions.explanation: You may have to pull forward slowly until you can see up and down the road. Be aware that the traffic approaching the junction can’t see you either. If you don’t know that it’s clear, don’t go.

prashna.text: Why must you take extra care when turning right at this junction?

options.description: A. The footpaths are narrow
B. The road surface is poor
C. The view is restricted
D. The road markings are faint

questions.explanation: A double-deck bus or high-sided lorry will have to take a position in the centre of the road to clear the bridge. There's normally a sign to show this. Look well ahead, past the bridge and be ready to stop and give way to large oncoming vehicles.

prashna.text: Which type of vehicle should you be ready to give way to as you approach this bridge?

options.description: A. Buses
B. Motorcycles
C. Cars
D. Bicycles

questions.explanation: The highest point of the bridge is in the centre, so a large vehicle might have to move to the centre of the road to have enough room to pass under the bridge.

prashna.text: What type of vehicle could you expect to meet in the middle of the road?

options.description: A. Lorry
B. Motorcycle
C. Car
D. Bicycle

questions.explanation: The ‘stop’ sign has been put here because the view into the main road is poor. You must stop because it won't be possible to take proper observation while you're moving.

prashna.text: What must you do at this junction?

options.description: A. Stop behind the line, then edge forward to see clearly
B. Stop beyond the line, at a point where you can see clearly
C. Stop only if there's traffic on the main road
D. Stop only if you're turning right

questions.explanation: Be tolerant if a vehicle emerges and you have to brake quickly. Anyone can make a mistake, so don’t react aggressively. Be alert where there are side roads and be especially careful where there are parked vehicles, because these can make it difficult for emerging drivers to see you.

prashna.text: A driver pulls out of a side road in front of you, causing you to brake hard. What should you do?

options.description: A. Sound your horn to show your annoyance
B. Ignore the error and stay calm
C. Overtake as soon as possible
D. Flash your lights to show your annoyance

questions.explanation: Be tolerant of older drivers. They may take longer to react to a hazard and they may be hesitant in some situations – for example, at a junction.

prashna.text: How would age affect an elderly person's driving ability?

options.description: A. They won't be able to obtain car insurance
B. They'll need glasses to read road signs
C. They won't signal at junctions
D. They'll take longer to react to hazards

questions.explanation: These lights warn that children may be crossing the road to a nearby school. Slow down so that you’re ready to stop if necessary.

prashna.text: You've just passed these warning lights. What hazard would you expect to see next?

options.description: A. An ambulance station
B. A level crossing with no barrier
C. A school crossing patrol
D. An opening bridge

questions.explanation: Try to plan your journey so that you can take rest stops. It’s recommended that you take a break of at least 15 minutes after every two hours of driving or riding. This should help to maintain your concentration.

prashna.text: You’re planning a long journey. Do you need to plan rest stops?

options.description: A. No, only fuel stops will be needed
B. Yes, you should plan to stop every half an hour
C. Yes, regular stops help concentration
D. No, you’ll be less tired if you get there as soon as possible

questions.explanation: At level crossings, the red lights flash before and while the barrier is down. At most crossings, an amber light will precede the red lights. You must stop behind the white line unless you've already crossed it when the amber light comes on. Never zigzag around half-barriers.

prashna.text: The red lights are flashing. What should you do when approaching this level crossing?

options.description: A. Switch on hazard warning lights
B. Go through carefully
C. Stop before the barrier
D. Go through quickly

questions.explanation: When approaching a junction where the traffic lights have failed, you should proceed with caution. Treat the situation as an unmarked junction and be prepared to stop.

prashna.text: You're approaching a crossroads. The traffic lights have failed. What should you do?

options.description: A. Brake and stop only for large vehicles
B. Be prepared to brake sharply to a stop
C. Brake sharply to a stop before looking
D. Be prepared to stop for any traffic

questions.explanation: Some people might take a long time to cross the road. They may be older or have a disability. Be patient and don’t hurry them by showing your impatience. If pedestrians are standing at the side of the road, don’t signal or wave them to cross. Other road users might not have seen your signal and this could lead the pedestrians into a hazardous situation.

prashna.text: What should the driver of the red car (arrowed) do?

options.description: A. Quickly drive behind the pedestrian in the road
B. Wave towards the pedestrians who are waiting to cross
C. Tell the pedestrian in the road she shouldn't have crossed
D. Wait for the pedestrian in the road to cross

questions.explanation: You should never overtake as you approach a junction. If a vehicle emerged from the junction while you were overtaking, a dangerous situation could develop very quickly.

prashna.text: You're following a slower-moving vehicle on a narrow country road. There's a junction just ahead on the right. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate quickly to pass before the junction
B. Only consider overtaking when you're past the junction
C. Overtake after checking your mirrors and signalling
D. Slow down and prepare to overtake on the left

questions.explanation: Oncoming large vehicles may need to move to the middle of the road to pass safely under the bridge. There won't be enough room for you to continue, so you should be ready to stop and wait.

prashna.text: What should you do as you approach this overhead bridge?

options.description: A. Move out to the centre of the road before going through
B. Find another route; this one is only for high vehicles
C. Be prepared to give way to large vehicles in the middle of the road
D. Move across to the right-hand side before going through

questions.explanation: Although a convex mirror gives a wide view of the scene behind, you should be aware that it won't show you everything behind or to the side of your vehicle. Before you move off, you'll need to look over your shoulder to check for anything not visible in the mirrors.

prashna.text: Why are mirrors often slightly curved (convex)?

options.description: A. They make it easier to judge the speed of following traffic
B. They give a wider field of vision
C. They make following traffic look bigger
D. They totally cover blind spots

questions.explanation: This sign is found on slow-moving or stationary works vehicles. If you wish to overtake, do so on the left, as indicated. Be aware that there might be workmen in the area.

prashna.text: A slow-moving lorry showing this sign is travelling in the middle lane of a three-lane motorway. How should you pass it?

options.description: A. Don't pass the lorry and leave the motorway at the next exit
B. Cautiously approach the lorry, then pass on either side
C. Approach with care and pass on the left of the lorry
D. Use the right-hand lane and pass the lorry normally

questions.explanation: Be cautious and don’t attempt to overtake. The driver may be unsure of the location of a junction and may turn suddenly.

prashna.text: You think the driver of the vehicle in front has forgotten to cancel their right indicator. What should you do?

options.description: A. Sound your horn before overtaking
B. Flash your lights to alert the driver
C. Stay behind and don't overtake
D. Overtake on the left if there's room

questions.explanation: If you can do so safely, give way to buses signalling to move off at bus stops. Try to anticipate the actions of other road users around you. The driver of the red car should be prepared for the bus pulling out. As you approach a bus stop, look to see how many passengers are waiting to board. If the last one has just got on, the bus is likely to move off.

prashna.text: What's the main hazard the driver of the red car (arrowed) should be aware of?

options.description: A. Glare from the sun may affect the driver’s vision
B. Oncoming vehicles will assume the driver is turning right
C. The bus may move out into the road
D. The black car may stop suddenly

questions.explanation: Buses which carry children to and from school may stop at places other than scheduled bus stops. Be aware that they might pull over at any time to allow children to get on or off. This will normally be when traffic is heavy during rush hour.

prashna.text: What type of vehicle displays this yellow sign?

options.description: A. A school bus
B. An ice-cream van
C. A broken-down vehicle
D. A private ambulance

questions.explanation: On roads where there are many parked vehicles, you might not be able to see children between parked cars and they may run out into the road without looking.

prashna.text: What hazard should you be aware of when travelling along this street?

options.description: A. Lack of road markings
B. Glare from the sun
C. Large goods vehicles
D. Children running out between vehicles

questions.explanation: When following a cyclist, be aware that they have to deal with the hazards around them. They may wobble or swerve to avoid a pothole in the road or see a potential hazard and change direction suddenly. Don’t follow them too closely or rev your engine impatiently.

prashna.text: What's the main hazard you should be aware of when following this cyclist?

options.description: A. The cyclist may move to the left and dismount
B. The contents of the cyclist’s carrier may fall onto the road
C. The cyclist may wish to turn right at the end of the road
D. The cyclist may swerve into the road

questions.explanation: If you feel yourself becoming tense or upset, stop in a safe place and take a break. Tiredness can make things worse and may cause a different reaction to upsetting situations.

prashna.text: A driver’s behaviour has upset you. What can you do to safely get over this incident?

options.description: A. Follow them, flashing your headlights
B. Gesture to them with your hand
C. Shout abusive language
D. Stop and take a break

questions.explanation: Traffic-calming measures such as road humps, chicanes and narrowings are intended to slow drivers down to protect vulnerable road users. Don't speed up until you reach the end of the traffic-calmed zone.

prashna.text: How should you drive in areas with traffic-calming measures?

options.description: A. In the centre of the road
B. At the speed limit
C. With headlights on dipped beam
D. At a reduced speed

questions.explanation: You should be slowing down and selecting the correct gear in case you have to stop at the level crossing. Look for the signals and be prepared to stop if necessary.

prashna.text: When approaching this hazard, why should you slow down?

options.description: A. Because it’s hard to see to the right
B. Because of approaching traffic
C. Because of the level crossing
D. Because of animals crossing

questions.explanation: The names of towns and cities may be painted on the road at busy junctions and complex road systems. Their purpose is to let you move into the correct lane in good time, allowing traffic to flow more freely.

prashna.text: Why are place names painted on the road surface?

options.description: A. To enable you to change lanes early
B. To prevent you changing lanes
C. To warn you of oncoming traffic
D. To restrict the flow of traffic

questions.explanation: If you intend to overtake, you must consider that approaching traffic could be planning the same manoeuvre. When you've considered the situation and decided it's safe, indicate your intentions early. This will show the approaching traffic that you intend to pull out.

prashna.text: Some two-way roads are divided into three lanes. Why are these particularly dangerous?

options.description: A. Traffic in both directions can use the middle lane to overtake
B. Traffic can travel faster in poor weather conditions
C. Traffic uses the middle lane for emergencies only
D. Traffic can overtake on the left

questions.explanation: An amber flashing light on a vehicle indicates that it's slow-moving. Battery-powered vehicles used by disabled people are limited to 8 mph. It isn't advisable for them to be used on dual carriageways where the speed limit exceeds 50 mph. If they are, then an amber flashing light must be used.

prashna.text: You're on a dual carriageway. Ahead, you see a vehicle with an amber flashing light. What could this be?

options.description: A. An ambulance
B. A doctor on call
C. A fire engine
D. A disabled person’s vehicle

questions.explanation: Police officers may need to direct traffic; for example, at a junction where the traffic lights have broken down. Check your copy of The Highway Code for the signals that they use.

prashna.text: What does this signal from a police officer mean to oncoming traffic?

options.description: A. Go ahead
B. Stop
C. Turn left
D. Turn right

questions.explanation: A stationary bus at a bus stop can hide pedestrians who might try to cross the road just in front of it. Drive at a speed that will enable you to respond safely if you have to.

prashna.text: Why should you be cautious when going past this stationary bus?

options.description: A. There is traffic approaching in the distance
B. The driver may open the door
C. People may cross the road in front of it
D. The road surface will be slippery

questions.explanation: You should overtake only when it's really necessary and you can see it’s clear ahead. Look out for road signs and markings that show it's illegal or would be unsafe to overtake; for example, approaching junctions or bends. In many cases, overtaking is unlikely to significantly improve your journey time.

prashna.text: Where shouldn't you overtake?

options.description: A. Travelling up a long hill
B. On a one-way street
C. On a single carriageway
D. Approaching a junction

questions.explanation:
Alcohol will severely reduce your ability to drive or ride safely and there are serious consequences if you’re caught over the drink-drive limit. It's known that alcohol can
•  affect your judgement
•  cause overconfidence
•  reduce coordination and control.

prashna.text: What’s an effect of drinking alcohol?

options.description: A. Faster reactions
B. Greater awareness of danger
C. A loss of confidence
D. Poor judgement of speed

questions.explanation: The continuous white line shows the edge of the carriageway. It can be especially useful when visibility is restricted, such as at night or in bad weather. It's discontinued in some places; for example, at  junctions, lay-bys, entrances or other openings.

prashna.text: What does the solid white line at the side of the road indicate?

options.description: A. Footpath on the left
B. Cycle path
C. Traffic lights ahead
D. Edge of the carriageway

questions.explanation: The steady amber light will be followed by twin flashing red lights that mean you must stop. An alarm will also sound to alert you to the fact that a train is approaching.

prashna.text: You're driving towards this level crossing. What would be the first warning of an approaching train?

options.description: A. A steady amber light
B. Twin flashing red lights
C. One half-barrier down
D. Both half-barriers down

questions.explanation: Hold back and allow the cyclist to move off. Some junctions have special areas marked across the front of the traffic lane. These allow cyclists to wait for the lights to change and move off ahead of other traffic.

prashna.text: You're behind this cyclist. When the traffic lights change, what should you do?

options.description: A. Allow the cyclist time and room
B. Try to move off before the cyclist
C. Tap your horn and drive through first
D. Turn right but give the cyclist room

questions.explanation: If you're waiting at traffic lights, check all around you before you move away, as cyclists often filter through waiting traffic. Allow the cyclist to move off safely.

prashna.text: What should the white car do when the traffic lights change to green?

options.description: A. Move up close to the cyclist to beat the lights
B. Sound their horn to warn the cyclist
C. Wait for the cyclist to pull away
D. Move off quickly and turn in front of the cyclist

questions.explanation: Check your nearside for cyclists before moving away. This is especially important if you've been in a queue of traffic and are about to move off, as cyclists often filter past on the nearside of stationary vehicles.

prashna.text: You intend to turn left at the traffic lights. What should you do just before turning?

options.description: A. Check your right mirror
B. Move up close to the white car
C. Check for bicycles on your left
D. Straddle the lanes

questions.explanation: Traffic could be turning off or pulling out ahead of you, to the left or right. Vehicles turning left will be slowing down before the junction, and any vehicles turning right may have to stop to allow oncoming traffic to clear. Be prepared for this, as you might have to slow down or stop behind them.

prashna.text: Why should you reduce your speed when driving along this road?

options.description: A. The road narrows ahead
B. A staggered junction is ahead
C. A low bridge is ahead
D. The road surface changes ahead

questions.explanation: Be courteous and allow the traffic to merge into the left-hand lane.

prashna.text: What might you expect to happen in this situation?

options.description: A. Traffic will move into the right-hand lane
B. Traffic won't need to change position
C. Traffic speed will increase
D. Traffic will move into the left-hand lane

questions.explanation: If you see a red cross above your lane, it means that there's an obstruction ahead. You'll have to move into one of the lanes that's showing a green light. If all the lanes are showing a red cross, then you must stop.

prashna.text: You're driving on a road with several lanes. You see these signs above the lanes. What do they mean?

options.description: A. The two left lanes are open
B. The two right lanes are open
C. Traffic in the right lanes should stop
D. Traffic in the left lanes should stop

questions.explanation: Alcohol will stay in your body for several hours and may make you unfit to drive later in the day. Drinking during the day will also affect your performance at work or study.

prashna.text: You're invited to a pub lunch. You know that you'll have to drive in the evening. What's your best course of action?

options.description: A. Eat a hot meal with your alcoholic drinks
B. Avoid mixing your alcoholic drinks
C. Have some milk before drinking alcohol
D. Don't drink any alcohol at all

questions.explanation: You've shown that you're a risk to yourself and others on the road. For this reason, insurance companies may charge you a higher premium.

prashna.text: You've been convicted of driving while unfit through drink or drugs. You'll find this is likely to cause the cost of one of the following to rise considerably. Which one?

options.description: A. Insurance premiums
B. Road fund licence
C. Vehicle test certificate
D. Driving licence

questions.explanation:
Drinking black coffee or waiting a few hours won’t make any difference. Alcohol takes time to leave the body.
A driver who has been drinking should go home by public transport or taxi. They might even be unfit to drive the following morning.

prashna.text: What advice should you give to a driver who has had a few alcoholic drinks at a party?

options.description: A. Drive home carefully and slowly
B. Go home by public transport
C. Have a strong cup of coffee and then drive home
D. Wait a short while and then drive home

questions.explanation: You aren't fit to drive if you're taking medicine that makes you drowsy. Check with your doctor if you're unsure. You mustn't put other road users, your passengers or yourself at risk.

prashna.text: You've been taking medicine that causes drowsiness. You begin to feel better, but you still need to take the medicine. What should you do about driving?

options.description: A. Ask someone to come with you
B. Drive on quiet roads
C. Only drive if your journey is necessary
D. Avoid driving and check with your doctor

questions.explanation: You shouldn't drive if you're taking medicine that could cause you to feel drowsy at the wheel. Ask someone else to drive or, if that isn't possible, find another way to get home.

prashna.text: You're about to drive home from holiday when you become ill. A doctor prescribes drugs that are likely to affect your driving. What should you do?

options.description: A. Get someone else to drive
B. Never drive at more than 30 mph
C. Avoid driving on motorways
D. Only drive if someone is with you

questions.explanation: Only drive if you're fit to do so. Driving when you're ill or taking some medicines can affect your concentration and judgement. It may also cause you to become drowsy or even fall asleep.

prashna.text: During periods of illness, your ability to drive may be impaired. What must you do?

options.description: A. Make sure you're medically fit to drive
B. See your doctor each time before you drive
C. Take all your medicines with you when you drive
D. Take smaller doses of any medicines

questions.explanation: You’ll be putting other road users at risk if you continue to drive when you're drowsy. Pull over and stop in a safe place for a rest. Caffeinated drinks and a short nap can temporarily help counter sleepiness. If you’re driving a long distance, think about finding some accommodation so you can rest for longer before continuing your journey.

prashna.text: What should you do if you begin to feel drowsy while you're driving?

options.description: A. Stop and rest as soon as possible
B. Close the car windows to help you concentrate
C. Continue with your journey but drive more slowly
D. Turn the heater up to keep you warm and comfortable

questions.explanation: If you feel yourself becoming tired or sleepy, you should leave the motorway at the next exit or services and stop for a rest. If you have to drive a long way, leave earlier and plan your journey to include rest stops. That way, you're less likely to become tired while driving and you'll still arrive in good time.

prashna.text: What should you do if you become tired while you're driving on a motorway?

options.description: A. Increase your speed and turn up the radio volume
B. Close all your windows and set the heating to warm
C. Leave the motorway at the next exit and rest
D. Pull up on the hard shoulder and change drivers

questions.explanation: All of your concentration should be on your driving. Any pain you feel will distract you, and you should avoid driving when drowsy. The safest course of action is to wait until you've rested and are feeling better before starting your journey.

prashna.text: You're about to drive home. You feel very tired and have a severe headache. What should you do?

options.description: A. Drive home if you can stay awake for the journey
B. Wait for a short time, then drive home slowly
C. Drive home, but take a tablet for headaches
D. Wait until you're fit and well before driving

questions.explanation: Long-distance driving can be boring. This, coupled with a stuffy, warm vehicle, can make you feel tired and sleepy. Make sure you take rest breaks to help you stay awake and alert. Stop in a safe place before you get to the stage of fighting sleep.

prashna.text: You’re driving on a long journey. What can you do to help prevent tiredness?

options.description: A. Eat a large meal before driving
B. Play loud music in the car
C. Take regular refreshment breaks
D. Complete the journey without stopping

questions.explanation: If you've taken medicine, never drive without first checking what the side effects might be; they might affect your judgement and perception, and therefore endanger lives.

prashna.text: You take some cough medicine given to you by a friend. What should you do before driving?

options.description: A. Check the label to see if the medicine will affect your driving
B. Drive a short distance to see if the medicine is affecting your driving
C. Drink some strong coffee one hour before driving
D. Ask your friend if taking the medicine affected their driving

questions.explanation: Never reverse or turn your vehicle around in a one-way street. It's illegal and could even cause a collision. If you've taken a wrong turn, carry on along the one-way street and find another route, checking the direction signs as you drive. Stop in a safe place if you need to check a map.

prashna.text: You take the wrong route and find you're on a one-way street. What should you do?

options.description: A. Reverse into a driveway
B. Continue to the end of the road
C. Turn around in a side road
D. Reverse out of the road

questions.explanation: Looking at road maps while driving is very dangerous. If you aren’t sure of your route, stop in a safe place and check the map. You must not allow anything to take your attention away from the road while you’re driving.

prashna.text: What will be a serious distraction from driving?

options.description: A. Looking in your door mirror
B. Using your windscreen washers
C. Switching on your demister
D. Looking at road maps

questions.explanation: White lights at the rear of a car show that the driver has selected reverse gear. Sound your horn to warn the other driver of your presence, and reduce your speed as a precaution.

prashna.text: You're driving along this road. The driver on the left is reversing from a driveway. What should you do?

options.description: A. Drive through as you have priority
B. Sound your horn and be prepared to stop
C. Move to the opposite side of the road
D. Speed up and drive through quickly

questions.explanation: If you're feeling upset or angry, you'll find it much more difficult to concentrate on your driving. You should wait until you've calmed down before starting a journey.

prashna.text: You've been involved in an argument that has made you feel angry. What should you do before starting your journey?

options.description: A. Turn on your radio
B. Open a window
C. Calm down
D. Have an alcoholic drink

questions.explanation:
Look well ahead and read any road signs as you drive. They're there to inform you of what's ahead. In this case, you may need to slow down and change direction.
Check your mirrors so you know what's happening around you before you change speed or direction.

prashna.text: You're driving on this dual carriageway. Why may you need to slow down?

options.description: A. There are roadworks ahead of you
B. There are no footpaths
C. There's a broken white line in the centre
D. There are solid white lines on either side

questions.explanation: If another vehicle cuts in sharply, ease off the accelerator and drop back to allow a safe separation distance. Try not to overreact by braking sharply or swerving, as you could lose control. If vehicles behind you are too close or unprepared, it could lead to a crash.

prashna.text: You've just been overtaken by this motorcyclist, who has cut in sharply. What should you do?

options.description: A. Flash your lights
B. Sound the horn
C. Brake firmly
D. Keep a safe gap

questions.explanation: If you need to wear glasses for driving, it's illegal to drive without them. You must be able to see clearly when you're driving.

prashna.text: You're about to drive home. You can't find the glasses you need to wear. What should you do?

options.description: A. Drive home at night, so that the lights will help you
B. Drive home slowly, keeping to quiet roads
C. Borrow a friend’s glasses and use those
D. Find a way of getting home without driving

questions.explanation: Alcohol can increase confidence to a point where a driver’s behaviour might become ‘out of character’. Someone who normally behaves sensibly might suddenly enjoy taking risks. Never let yourself or your friends get into this situation.

prashna.text: What’s a common effect of drinking alcohol?

options.description: A. Faster reactions
B. Increased concentration
C. Increased confidence
D. Colour blindness

questions.explanation: Always check the label or information leaflet for any medication you take. The medicine might affect your driving. If you aren’t sure, ask your doctor or pharmacist.

prashna.text: Your doctor has given you a course of medicine. Why should you ask how it will affect you?

options.description: A. Some types of medicine can cause your reactions to slow down
B. Drugs make you a better driver by quickening your reactions
C. The medicine you take may affect your hearing
D. You'll have to let your insurance company know about the medicine

questions.explanation: Have your eyesight tested before you start your practical training. Then, throughout your driving life, have checks periodically, as your vision may change.

prashna.text: You find that you need glasses to read vehicle number plates at the required distance. When must you wear them?

options.description: A. Only when you think it's necessary
B. Only in bad weather conditions
C. Only in bad light or at night time
D. At all times when driving

questions.explanation: If you're driving at night or in poor visibility, tinted lenses will reduce the efficiency of your vision by reducing the amount of light reaching your eyes.

prashna.text: Which of the following types of glasses shouldn't be worn when driving at night?

options.description: A. Bifocal
B. Tinted
C. Half-moon
D. Round

questions.explanation: Both recreational drugs and prescribed medicine can affect your concentration. It's also now an offence to drive with certain drugs in your body and a positive test could lead to a conviction.

prashna.text: What can seriously affect your ability to concentrate?

options.description: A. Busy roads
B. Drugs
C. Tinted windows
D. Contact lenses

questions.explanation: Having very poor eyesight will have a serious effect on your ability to drive safely. If you can't meet the driver's eyesight requirements, you must tell DVLA (or DVA in Northern Ireland).

prashna.text: You find that your eyesight has become very poor and your optician cannot help you. By law, who should you tell?

options.description: A. The driver licensing authority
B. Another optician
C. The local police
D. Your own doctor

questions.explanation: Hazard warning lights are an important safety feature and should be used if you've broken down and are causing an obstruction. Don’t use them as an excuse to park illegally. You may also use them on motorways to warn traffic behind you of danger ahead.

prashna.text: When should you use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When your vehicle has broken down and is causing an obstruction
B. When your direction indicators aren't working
C. When you're double-parked on a two-way road
D. When warning oncoming traffic that you intend to stop

questions.explanation: You should slow right down, and stop if necessary, at any junction where your view is restricted. Edge forward until you can see properly. Only then can you decide whether it's safe to go.

prashna.text: You want to turn left at this junction. Your view of the main road is restricted. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stay well back and wait to see if anything comes
B. Stop and apply the handbrake even if the road is clear
C. Approach slowly and edge out until you can see more clearly
D. Build up your speed so that you can emerge quickly

questions.explanation: ‘Kick down’ selects a lower gear, enabling the vehicle to accelerate faster.

prashna.text: When driving a car fitted with automatic transmission, what would you use ‘kick down’ for?

options.description: A. Fuel economy
B. Quick acceleration
C. Cruise control
D. Slow braking

questions.explanation:
The usual two-second time gap increases to four seconds when the roads are wet. If you stay well back, you’ll
• be able to see past the vehicle
• be out of the spray thrown up by the lorry’s tyres
• give yourself more time to stop if the need arises
• increase your chances of being seen by the lorry driver.

prashna.text: You’re driving along this motorway. It’s raining. What should you do when following this lorry?

options.description: A. Be aware of spray reducing your vision
B. Allow at least a two-second gap
C. Move right and stay in the right-hand lane
D. Move left and drive on the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: Pedestrians walking on a road with no pavement should walk against the direction of the traffic. You can’t see around this bend: there may be hidden dangers. Always keep this in mind and give yourself time to react if a hazard does appear.

prashna.text: You're driving towards this left-hand bend. What dangers should you be aware of?

options.description: A. Pedestrians walking towards you
B. No sign to warn you of the bend
C. A vehicle overtaking you
D. No white lines in the centre of the road

questions.explanation: Allow the traffic to merge into the left-hand lane. Leave enough room so that you can maintain a safe separation distance, even if vehicles pull in ahead of you.

prashna.text: Ahead of you, traffic in the left-hand lane is slowing. What should you do?

options.description: A. Slow down, keeping a safe separation distance
B. Accelerate past the vehicles in the left-hand lane
C. Pull up on the left-hand verge
D. Move across and continue in the right-hand lane

questions.explanation:
Hazard warning lights are an important safety feature. Use them when driving on a motorway to warn traffic behind you of danger ahead.
You should also use them if your vehicle has broken down and is causing an obstruction.

prashna.text: In which circumstances may you use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When you're double-parked on a two-way road
B. When your direction indicators aren't working
C. When warning oncoming traffic that you intend to stop
D. When driving on a motorway to warn traffic behind of a hazard ahead

questions.explanation: You must be completely sure it's safe to emerge. Try to look for traffic through the windows of the parked cars or in the reflections in shop windows. Keep looking in all directions as you slowly edge forwards until you can see it's safe.

prashna.text: You're waiting to emerge at a junction. Your view is restricted by parked vehicles. What can help you to see traffic on the road you're joining?

options.description: A. Making eye contact with other road users
B. Reflections of traffic in shop windows
C. Checking for traffic in your interior mirror
D. Looking for traffic behind you

questions.explanation: You must tell DVLA (or DVA in Northern Ireland) if your health is likely to affect your ability to drive. The licensing authority will investigate your situation and then make a decision on whether or not to take away your licence.

prashna.text: After passing your driving test, you suffer from ill health. This affects your driving. What must you do?

options.description: A. Avoid using motorways
B. Always drive accompanied
C. Inform the licensing authority
D. Inform your local police

questions.explanation: You should always try to keep junctions clear. If you're in queuing traffic, make sure that when you stop you leave enough space for traffic to flow into and out of the junction.

prashna.text: Why should the junction on the left be kept clear?

options.description: A. To allow the bus to reverse
B. To allow vehicles to make a U-turn
C. To allow vehicles to park
D. To allow vehicles to enter and emerge

questions.explanation: Never stop on the hard shoulder to rest. If there's no service area for several miles, leave the motorway at the next exit and find somewhere safe and legal to pull over.

prashna.text: Your motorway journey is boring and you feel drowsy. What should you do?

options.description: A. Open a window and stop as soon as it’s safe and legal
B. Slow down and let other drivers overtake
C. Stop on the hard shoulder for a sleep
D. Speed up to arrive at your destination sooner

questions.explanation: Always check the road signs. Triangular signs are warning signs: they inform you about hazards ahead and help you to anticipate any problems. There are a number of different signs showing pedestrians. Learn the meaning of each one.

prashna.text: Which sign means that there may be people walking along the road?

questions.explanation: When you’re turning into a side road, pedestrians who are crossing have priority. You should wait to allow them to finish crossing safely. Be patient if they're slow or unsteady. Don't try to rush them by sounding your horn, flashing your lights, revving your engine or giving any other inappropriate signal.

prashna.text: You're turning left at a junction where pedestrians have started to cross. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stop and wave at them to cross
B. Go around them, leaving plenty of room
C. Give way to them
D. Sound your horn and proceed

questions.explanation: Make sure that you've reduced your speed and are in the correct gear for the turn. Look into the road before you turn and always give way to any pedestrians who are crossing.

prashna.text: You're turning left into a side road. What hazard should you be especially aware of?

options.description: A. One-way street
B. Pedestrians
C. Traffic congestion
D. Parked vehicles

questions.explanation: Never attempt to change direction to the right without first checking your right-hand mirror and blind spot. A motorcyclist might not have seen your signal and could be hidden by other traffic. This observation should become a matter of routine.

prashna.text: You intend to turn right into a side road. Why should you check for motorcyclists just before turning?

options.description: A. They may be following you closely
B. They may be overtaking on your left
C. They may be emerging from the side road
D. They may be overtaking on your right

questions.explanation: Toucan crossings are shared by pedestrians and cyclists, who are permitted to cycle across. They're shown the green light together. The signals are push-button-operated and there's no flashing amber phase.

prashna.text: Why is a toucan crossing different from other crossings?

options.description: A. It's controlled by two flashing lights
B. It's controlled by a traffic warden
C. Cyclists can use it
D. Moped riders can use it

questions.explanation: If a school crossing patrol steps out into the road with a 'stop' sign, you must stop. Don’t wave anyone across the road and don’t get impatient or rev your engine.

prashna.text: How will a school crossing patrol signal you to stop?

options.description: A. By displaying a red light
B. By pointing to children on the opposite pavement
C. By displaying a 'stop' sign
D. By giving you an arm signal

questions.explanation: Vehicles that are used to carry children to and from school will be travelling at busy times of the day. If you’re following a vehicle with this sign, be prepared for it to make frequent stops. It might pick up or set down passengers in places other than normal bus stops.

prashna.text: Where would you see this sign?

options.description: A. In the window of a car taking children to school
B. On the rear of a school bus or coach
C. At the side of the road
D. At playground areas

questions.explanation: This sign shows a shared route for pedestrians and cyclists: when it ends, the cyclists will be rejoining the main road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. A route for pedestrians and cyclists
B. No route for pedestrians and cyclists
C. A route for cyclists only
D. A route for pedestrians only

questions.explanation: When someone is deaf as well as blind, they may carry a white stick with a red reflective band. They may not be aware that you're approaching and they may not be able to hear anything; so, for example, your horn would be ineffective as a warning to them.

prashna.text: You see a pedestrian carrying a white stick with a red band. What does this tell you?

options.description: A. They're deaf and blind
B. They have limited mobility
C. They're deaf
D. They're blind

questions.explanation: Be aware that older people might take a long time to cross the road. They might also be hard of hearing and not hear you approaching. Don’t hurry older people across the road by getting too close to them or revving your engine.

prashna.text: What action would you take when elderly people are crossing the road?

options.description: A. Rev the engine to let them know that you're waiting
B. Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time
C. Tap the horn in case they're hard of hearing
D. Wave them across so they know that you've seen them

questions.explanation: Older people may have impaired hearing, vision, concentration and judgement. They may also walk slowly and so could take a long time to cross the road.

prashna.text: What should you do when you see two elderly pedestrians about to cross the road ahead?

options.description: A. Be careful; they may misjudge your speed
B. Speed up to get past them quickly
C. Stop and wave them across the road
D. Expect them to wait for you to pass

questions.explanation: If you’re following a cyclist who’s signalling to turn right at a roundabout, leave plenty of room. Give them space and time to get into the correct lane.

prashna.text: You're coming up to a roundabout. A cyclist is signalling to turn right. What should you do?

options.description: A. Overtake on the right
B. Give a warning with your horn
C. Signal the cyclist to move across
D. Give the cyclist plenty of room

questions.explanation:
Don’t pass cyclists too closely, as they may
• need to veer around a pothole or other obstacle
• be buffeted by side wind
• be made unsteady by your vehicle.
Always leave as much room as you would for a car, and don’t cut in front of them.

prashna.text: Which of these should you allow extra room when overtaking?

options.description: A. Bicycle
B. Tractor
C. Road-sweeping vehicle
D. Lorry

questions.explanation: Cyclists and motorcyclists are smaller than other vehicles and so are more difficult to see. They can easily be hidden from your view by cars parked near a junction.

prashna.text: Why should you look particularly for motorcyclists and cyclists at junctions?

options.description: A. They may want to turn into the side road
B. They're harder to see
C. They might not see you turn
D. They may slow down to let you turn

questions.explanation: If you’re waiting to emerge from a side road, look carefully for motorcycles: they can be difficult to see. Be especially careful if there are parked vehicles or other obstructions restricting your view.

prashna.text: You’re waiting to come out of a side road. Why should you look carefully for motorcycles?

options.description: A. Motorcycles are usually faster than cars
B. Motorcycles have right of way
C. Police patrols often use motorcycles
D. Motorcycles can easily be hidden behind obstructions

questions.explanation: A motorcycle can be lost from sight behind another vehicle. The use of the headlights helps to make it more conspicuous and therefore more easily seen.

prashna.text: In daylight, an approaching motorcyclist is using dipped headlights. Why?

options.description: A. To improve the rider’s vision
B. So that the rider can be seen more easily
C. The rider is inviting you to proceed
D. To stop the battery overcharging

questions.explanation: Motorcycles and scooters are generally smaller than other vehicles and can be difficult to see. Wearing bright clothing makes it easier for other road users to see a motorcyclist approaching, especially at junctions.

prashna.text: Why should motorcyclists wear bright clothing?

options.description: A. The colours are popular
B. Drivers often do not see them
C. It helps keep them cool in summer
D. They must do so by law

questions.explanation: When a motorcyclist is travelling slowly, it's likely that they're looking for a turning or entrance. Be patient and stay behind them in case they stop or change direction suddenly.

prashna.text: You're unsure what a slow-moving motorcyclist ahead of you is going to do. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pass on the left
B. Pass on the right
C. Stay behind
D. Move closer

questions.explanation: When you see a motorcyclist take a glance over their shoulder, they're probably about to change direction. Recognising a clue like this helps you to anticipate their next action. This can improve road safety for you and others.

prashna.text: Why will a motorcyclist look round over their right shoulder just before turning right?

options.description: A. To check for traffic in their blind area
B. To listen for following traffic
C. It helps them balance as they turn
D. Motorcycles don't have mirrors

questions.explanation: Pedestrians and riders on two wheels can be harder to see than other road users. Make sure you look for them, especially at junctions. Effective observation, coupled with appropriate action, can save lives.

prashna.text: Which is the most vulnerable road user at road junctions?

options.description: A. Lorry driver
B. Tractor driver
C. Motorcyclist
D. Car driver

questions.explanation: Horse riders often keep to the outside of the roundabout even if they're turning right. Give them plenty of room and remember that they may have to cross lanes of traffic.

prashna.text: You're approaching a roundabout. There are horses just ahead of you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Accelerate past as quickly as possible
B. Sound your horn as a warning
C. Treat them like any other vehicle
D. Give them plenty of room

questions.explanation: If the lights turn to green, wait for any pedestrians to clear the crossing. Allow them to finish crossing the road in their own time, and don’t try to hurry them by revving your engine.

prashna.text: As you approach a pelican crossing, the lights change to green. What should you do if elderly people are halfway across?

options.description: A. Rev your engine to make them hurry
B. Wait patiently because they'll probably take longer to cross
C. Wave them to cross as quickly as they can
D. Flash your lights in case they haven't noticed you

questions.explanation: The flashing amber lights are switched on to warn you that children may be crossing near a school. Slow down and take extra care, as you may have to stop.

prashna.text: There are flashing amber lights under a school warning sign. What action should you take?

options.description: A. Reduce speed until you're clear of the area
B. Keep up your speed and sound the horn
C. Wait at the lights until they change to green
D. Increase your speed to clear the area quickly

questions.explanation:
The markings are there to show that the area must be kept clear. This is to allow an unrestricted view for
• approaching drivers and riders
• children wanting to cross the road.

prashna.text: Why must these road markings be kept clear?

options.description: A. To allow schoolchildren to be picked up
B. To allow a clear view of the crossing area
C. To allow teachers to park
D. To allow schoolchildren to be dropped off

questions.explanation: Watch out for children crossing the road from the other side of the bus.

prashna.text: Where would you see this sign?

options.description: A. On a school bus
B. Near a school crossing
C. At a ‘pedestrians only’ area
D. At a playground entrance

questions.explanation: Cyclists approaching a roundabout in the left-hand lane may be turning right but may not have been able to get into the correct lane due to heavy traffic. They may also feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Be aware of them and give them plenty of room.

prashna.text: You're following two cyclists. They approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane. In which direction should you expect the cyclists to go?

options.description: A. Left
B. Any direction
C. Right
D. Straight ahead

questions.explanation: Passing the moped and turning into the junction could mean that you cut across the front of the rider. This might force them to slow down, stop or even lose control. Stay behind the moped until it has passed the junction and then you can turn without affecting the rider.

prashna.text: You're travelling behind a moped. What should you do when you want to turn left just ahead?

options.description: A. Overtake the moped before the junction
B. Sound your horn as a warning and pull in front of the moped
C. Stay behind until the moped has passed the junction
D. Pull alongside the moped and stay level until just before the junction

questions.explanation: Allow the horse rider to enter and exit the roundabout in their own time. They may feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Don’t get up close behind or alongside them, because that would probably upset the horse and create a dangerous situation.

prashna.text: You see a horse rider as you approach a roundabout. What should you do if they're signalling right but keeping well to the left?

options.description: A. Cut in front of them
B. Keep close to them
C. Stay well back
D. Proceed as normal

questions.explanation: Learners might not have confidence when they first start to drive. Allow them plenty of room and don’t react adversely to their hesitation. We all learn from experience, but new drivers will have had less practice in dealing with all the situations that might occur.

prashna.text: How would you react to drivers who appear to be inexperienced?

options.description: A. Flash your headlights to indicate that it's safe for them to proceed
B. Sound your horn to warn them of your presence
C. Overtake them as soon as possible
D. Be patient and prepare for them to react more slowly

questions.explanation: Learning to drive is a process of practice and experience. Try to understand this and tolerate those who make mistakes while they’re learning.

prashna.text: What should you do when you’re following a learner driver who stalls at a junction?

options.description: A. Immediately steer around them and drive on
B. Be patient, as you expect them to make mistakes
C. Start to rev your engine if they take too long to restart
D. Stay very close behind and flash your headlights

questions.explanation: On a quiet country road, always be aware that there may be a hazard just around the next bend, such as a slow-moving vehicle or pedestrians. Pedestrians are advised to walk on the right-hand side of the road if there's no pavement, so they may be walking towards you on your side of the road.

prashna.text: You're on a country road. What should you expect to see coming towards you on your side of the road?

options.description: A. Bicycles
B. Horse riders
C. Motorcycles
D. Pedestrians

questions.explanation: You must show consideration to other road users. The reactions of older drivers may be slower and they might need more time to deal with a situation. Be tolerant and don’t lose patience or show annoyance.

prashna.text: What should you do when following a car driven by an elderly driver?

options.description: A. Stay very close behind but be careful
B. Expect the driver to drive badly
C. Be aware that their reactions may be slower than yours
D. Flash your lights and overtake

questions.explanation: Make allowances for cyclists, and give them plenty of room. Don’t overtake and then immediately turn left. Be patient and turn behind them when they've passed the junction.

prashna.text: You're following a cyclist. What should you do when you wish to turn left just ahead?

options.description: A. Pull alongside the cyclist and stay level until after the junction
B. Go around the cyclist on the junction
C. Hold back until the cyclist has passed the junction
D. Overtake the cyclist before you reach the junction

questions.explanation: Horses and their riders move more slowly than other road users. They might not have time to cut across heavy traffic to take up a position in the right-hand lane. For this reason, a horse and rider may approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane even though they’re turning right.

prashna.text: A horse rider is in the left-hand lane approaching a roundabout. Where should you expect the rider to go?

options.description: A. To the right
B. Straight ahead
C. In any direction
D. To the left

questions.explanation: Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small, low, hard to see and travel very slowly. On a dual carriageway, a flashing amber light will warn other road users.

prashna.text: Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small and hard to see. How do they give early warning when on a dual carriageway?

options.description: A. They'll have a flashing blue light
B. They'll have a flashing red light
C. They'll have a flashing green light
D. They'll have a flashing amber light

questions.explanation: If you want to turn left and there’s a cyclist in front of you, hold back. Wait until the cyclist has passed the junction and then turn left behind them. Don't try to intimidate them by driving too closely.

prashna.text: Where should you never overtake a cyclist?

options.description: A. On a one-way street
B. On a dual carriageway
C. Just before you turn left
D. On a left-hand bend

questions.explanation: Different coloured beacons warn of different types of vehicle needing special attention. Blue beacons are used on emergency vehicles that need priority. Green beacons are found on doctors' cars. Amber beacons generally denote slower moving vehicles, which are often large. These vehicles are usually involved in road maintenance or local amenities and make frequent stops.

prashna.text: What does a flashing amber beacon mean when it's on a moving vehicle?

options.description: A. The vehicle has broken down
B. The vehicle belongs to a school crossing patrol
C. The vehicle is slow moving
D. The vehicle is a doctor's car

questions.explanation: Usually, a picture of a cycle will also be painted on the road, and sometimes the lane will have a different coloured surface. Leave these areas clear for cyclists and don’t pass too closely when you overtake.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. With-flow cycle lane
B. Contraflow cycle lane
C. Cycles and buses only
D. No cycles or buses

questions.explanation: Be particularly careful when approaching horse riders – slow down and be prepared to stop. Always pass wide and slowly, and look out for signals given by the riders. Horses are unpredictable: always treat them as potential hazards and take great care when passing them.

prashna.text: You notice horse riders in front. What should you do first?

options.description: A. Slow down and be ready to stop
B. Signal right
C. Pull out to the middle of the road
D. Accelerate around them

questions.explanation: These markings are found on the road outside schools. Don't stop or park on them, even to set down or pick up children. The markings are there to ensure that drivers, riders, children and other pedestrians have a clear view of the road in all directions.

prashna.text: What's the purpose of these road markings?

options.description: A. To enable teachers to have clear access to the school
B. To enable parents to pick up or drop off children safely
C. To ensure children can see and be seen when crossing the road
D. To ensure delivery vehicles have easy access to the school

questions.explanation: Where street repairs have closed off pavements, proceed carefully and slowly, as pedestrians might have to walk in the road.

prashna.text: The left-hand pavement is closed due to street repairs. What should you do?

options.description: A. Position close to the left-hand kerb
B. Use your right-hand mirror more often
C. Watch out for pedestrians walking in the road
D. Speed up to get past the roadworks more quickly

questions.explanation: To avoid being unbalanced, a motorcyclist might swerve to avoid potholes and bumps in the road. Be prepared for this and allow them extra space.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're following a motorcyclist along a road that has a poor surface?

options.description: A. Allow extra room in case they swerve to avoid potholes
B. Overtake immediately to avoid delays
C. Follow closely so they can see you in their mirrors
D. Allow the same room as normal to avoid wasting road space

questions.explanation:
With people’s concern today for the environment, cycle routes are being extended in our towns and cities.
Respect the presence of cyclists on the road and give them plenty of room if you need to pass.

prashna.text: What does this sign tell you?

options.description: A. No cycling
B. End of cycle route
C. Cycle route ahead
D. Cycle parking only

questions.explanation: Cycling in today’s heavy traffic can be hazardous. Some cyclists may not feel happy about crossing the path of traffic to take up a position in an outside lane. Be aware of this and understand that, although they're in the left-hand lane, the cyclist might be turning right.

prashna.text: You're approaching this roundabout and see the cyclist signal right. Why is the cyclist keeping to the left?

options.description: A. It's a quicker route for the cyclist
B. The cyclist is slower and more vulnerable
C. The cyclist thinks The Highway Code doesn't apply to bicycles
D. The cyclist is going to turn left instead

questions.explanation: Be courteous and prepare to stop. Don't wave people across, because this could be dangerous if another vehicle is approaching the crossing.

prashna.text: What should you do when approaching this crossing?

options.description: A. Speed up and pass by quickly
B. Prepare to slow down and stop
C. Stop and wave the pedestrians across
D. Continue unless the pedestrians step out

questions.explanation: Dogs trained to help deaf people have a yellow or burgundy coat. If you see one, you should take extra care, as the pedestrian may not be aware of vehicles approaching.

prashna.text: You see a pedestrian with a dog wearing a yellow or burgundy coat. What does this indicate?

options.description: A. The pedestrian is deaf
B. The pedestrian is elderly
C. The pedestrian is colour-blind
D. The pedestrian is a dog trainer

questions.explanation: There are some crossings where cycle routes lead cyclists to cross at the same place as pedestrians. These are called toucan crossings. Always look out for cyclists, as they’re likely to be approaching faster than pedestrians.

prashna.text: Who may use toucan crossings?

options.description: A. Motorcyclists and pedestrians
B. Cyclists and pedestrians
C. Only cyclists
D. Motorcyclists and cyclists

questions.explanation: These are known as advanced stop lines. When the lights are red (or about to become red), you should stop at the first white line. However, if you've crossed that line as the lights change, you must stop at the second line even if it means you're in the area reserved for cyclists.

prashna.text: Some junctions controlled by traffic lights have a marked area between two stop lines. What's this for?

options.description: A. To allow taxis to position in front of other traffic
B. To allow people with disabilities to cross the road
C. To allow cyclists to position in front of other traffic
D. To allow cyclists and pedestrians to cross the road together

questions.explanation: Before overtaking, assess the situation. Look well ahead to see whether the cyclist will need to change direction. Be especially aware of a cyclist approaching parked vehicles, as they'll need to alter course. Don't pass too closely or cut in sharply.

prashna.text: When you're overtaking a cyclist, you should leave as much room as you would give to a car. What's the main reason for this?

options.description: A. The cyclist might have to make a left turn
B. The cyclist might get off their bike
C. The cyclist might speed up
D. The cyclist might swerve

questions.explanation: Slow down and be ready to stop if you see animals in the road ahead. Animals are easily frightened by noise and vehicles passing too close to them. Stop if signalled to do so by the person in charge.

prashna.text: What should you do when passing sheep on a road?

options.description: A. Herd them to the side of the road
B. Briefly sound your horn
C. Pass quickly but quietly
D. Go very slowly

questions.explanation: The people on the walk should be keeping to the left, but don’t assume this. Pass carefully, making sure you have time to do so safely. Be aware that the pedestrians have their backs to you and may not know that you’re there.

prashna.text: At night, you see a pedestrian wearing reflective clothing and carrying a bright red light. What does this mean?

options.description: A. You're approaching roadworks
B. You're approaching an organised walk
C. You're approaching a traffic danger spot
D. You're approaching a slow-moving vehicle

questions.explanation: New drivers and riders are often involved in a collision or incident early in their driving career. Due to a lack of experience, they may not react to hazards appropriately. Approved training courses are offered by driver and rider training schools for people who have passed their test but want extra training.

prashna.text: You’ve just passed your test. How can you reduce your risk of being involved in a collision?

options.description: A. By never going over 40 mph
B. By taking further training
C. By staying in the left-hand lane on all roads
D. By always staying close to the vehicle in front
