questions.explanation: If you can't tell whether there's anything behind you, it's always safest to check before reversing. There may be a small child or a low obstruction close behind your car.

prashna.text: You want to reverse into a side road, but you aren't sure that the area behind your car is clear. What should you do?

options.description: A. Look through the rear window only
B. Carry on, assuming it's clear
C. Check the mirrors only
D. Get out and check

questions.explanation: If you need to reverse into a side road, try to find a place that’s free from traffic and pedestrians. Look all around before and during the manoeuvre. Stop and give way to any pedestrians who want to cross behind you. Avoid waving them across, sounding the horn, flashing your lights or giving any signals that could mislead them and create a dangerous situation.

prashna.text: You're about to reverse into a side road. A pedestrian is waiting to cross behind you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Wave to the pedestrian to stop
B. Give way to the pedestrian
C. Reverse before the pedestrian starts to cross
D. Sound your horn to warn the pedestrian

questions.explanation: It may not be possible to see a small child through the rear windscreen of your vehicle. Be aware of this before you reverse. If there are children about, get out and check that it's clear before reversing.

prashna.text: Who's especially in danger of not being seen as you reverse your car?

options.description: A. Car drivers
B. Children
C. Cyclists
D. Motorcyclists

questions.explanation:
If you want to turn right from a junction and your view is restricted, stop. Ease forward until you can see – something might be approaching.
If you don't know, don't go.

prashna.text: You want to turn right from a junction but your view is restricted by parked vehicles. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stop, get out and look along the main road to check
B. Move out quickly, but be prepared to stop
C. Stop, then move forward slowly until you have a clear view
D. Sound your horn and pull out if there's no reply

questions.explanation: A motorcyclist could be riding along the outside of the queue. Always check your mirror before turning, as situations behind you can change in the time you've been waiting to turn.

prashna.text: You're at the front of a queue of traffic waiting to turn right into a side road. Why is it important to check your right mirror just before turning?

options.description: A. To make sure the side road is clear
B. To look for pedestrians about to cross
C. To check for emerging traffic
D. To check for overtaking vehicles

questions.explanation: The flashing amber light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side before a green light shows to the traffic. Be aware that some pedestrians, such as elderly people and young children, need longer to cross. Let them do this at their own pace.

prashna.text: What must a driver do at a pelican crossing when the amber light is flashing?

options.description: A. Signal the pedestrian to cross
B. Wait for the red-and-amber light before proceeding
C. Give way to any pedestrians on the crossing
D. Always wait for the green light before proceeding

questions.explanation: At a pelican crossing, the green light means you may proceed as long as the crossing is clear. If someone hasn’t finished crossing, be patient and wait for them, whether they're disabled or not.

prashna.text: You've stopped at a pelican crossing. A disabled person is crossing slowly in front of you when the lights change to green. What should you do?

options.description: A. Edge forward slowly
B. Sound your horn
C. Wait for them to finish crossing
D. Drive in front of them

questions.explanation: Beware of children playing in the street and running out into the road. If a ball bounces out from the pavement, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don’t encourage anyone to retrieve it. Other road users may not see your signal and you might lead a child into a dangerous situation.

prashna.text: You're driving past a line of parked cars. You notice a ball bouncing out into the road ahead. What should you do?

options.description: A. Continue driving at the same speed and flash your headlights
B. Slow down and be prepared to stop for children
C. Continue driving at the same speed and sound your horn
D. Stop and wave the children across to fetch their ball

questions.explanation: In some circumstances, your indicators may be difficult to see and another road user may not realise you're about to turn. A final check in your mirror and blind spot can help you to see an overtaking vehicle, so that you can avoid turning across their path.

prashna.text: You want to turn right from a main road into a side road. What should you do just before turning?

options.description: A. Cancel your right-turn signal
B. Select first gear
C. Check for traffic overtaking on your right
D. Stop and set the handbrake

questions.explanation: In queuing traffic, motorcyclists could be passing you on either side. Use your mirrors and check your blind area before changing lanes or changing direction.

prashna.text: You're driving in a slow-moving queue of traffic. Just before changing lane, what should you do?

options.description: A. Look for motorcyclists filtering through the traffic
B. Give a ‘slowing down’ arm signal
C. Change down to first gear
D. Sound the horn and flash your lights

questions.explanation: If you see a bus ahead, watch out for pedestrians. They might not be able to see you if they’re crossing from behind the bus.

prashna.text: You're driving in town. There's a bus at the bus stop on the other side of the road. Why should you be careful?

options.description: A. The bus might remain stationary
B. The bus might move off suddenly
C. Pedestrians might come from behind the bus
D. The bus might have broken down

questions.explanation: When you decide to overtake a horse rider, make sure you can do so safely before you move out. Leave them plenty of room and pass slowly. Passing too closely at speed could startle the horse and unseat the rider.

prashna.text: How should you overtake horse riders?

options.description: A. Drive slowly and leave plenty of room
B. Drive up close and overtake as soon as possible
C. Use your horn just once to warn them
D. Speed isn't important but allow plenty of room

questions.explanation: If you’re driving in high winds, be aware that the conditions might force a motorcyclist or cyclist to swerve or wobble. Take this into consideration if you’re following or wish to overtake a two-wheeled vehicle.

prashna.text: Why should you allow extra room when overtaking a motorcyclist on a windy day?

options.description: A. The rider may be travelling faster than normal
B. The rider may be blown across in front of you
C. The rider may stop suddenly
D. The rider may turn off suddenly to get out of the wind

questions.explanation: Motorcyclists and cyclists are often more difficult to see at junctions. They’re easily hidden from view and you may not be able to see them approaching a junction if your view is partially blocked; for example, by other traffic.

prashna.text: Where should you take particular care to look for motorcyclists and cyclists?

options.description: A. On dual carriageways
B. At junctions
C. At zebra crossings
D. On one-way streets

questions.explanation: Parking here would block other road users' view of the school entrance and would endanger the lives of children on their way to and from school.

prashna.text: The road outside this school is marked with yellow zigzag lines. What do these lines mean?

options.description: A. You mustn't wait or park your vehicle here at all
B. You must stay with your vehicle if you park here
C. You may park on the lines when picking up schoolchildren
D. You may park on the lines when dropping off schoolchildren

questions.explanation: Scan the road as you drive. Try to anticipate hazards by being aware of the places where they're likely to occur. You’ll then be able to react in good time.

prashna.text: You're driving past parked cars. You notice a bicycle wheel sticking out between them. What should you do?

options.description: A. Brake sharply and flash your headlights
B. Slow down and wave the cyclist across
C. Accelerate past quickly and sound your horn
D. Slow down and be prepared to stop for a cyclist

questions.explanation: The interior mirror of most vehicles can be set to an anti-dazzle position. You'll still be able to see the lights of the traffic behind you, but the dazzle will be greatly reduced.

prashna.text: You're dazzled at night by a vehicle behind you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Switch your rear lights on and off
B. Brake sharply to a stop
C. Set your mirror to dazzle the other driver
D. Set your mirror to the anti-dazzle position

questions.explanation: You should slow down and be prepared to stop, as you would for an able-bodied person. Don’t wave them across, as other traffic may not stop.

prashna.text: You're driving towards a zebra crossing. A person in a wheelchair is waiting to cross. What should you do?

options.description: A. Wave to the person to wait
B. Be prepared to stop
C. Wave to the person to cross
D. Continue on your way

questions.explanation: In windy weather, watch out for motorcyclists and also cyclists, as they can be blown sideways into your path. When you pass them, leave plenty of room and check their position in your mirror before pulling back in.

prashna.text: You're about to overtake a slow-moving motorcyclist. Which one of these signs would make you take special care?

questions.explanation: Large vehicles can hide other vehicles that are overtaking – especially motorcycles, which may be filtering past queuing traffic. You need to be aware of the possibility of hidden vehicles and not assume that it's safe to emerge.

prashna.text: You're waiting to emerge left from a minor road. A large vehicle is approaching from the right. You have time to turn, but you should wait. Why?

options.description: A. The large vehicle can turn suddenly
B. The large vehicle can easily hide an overtaking vehicle
C. The large vehicle can easily hide vehicles from the left
D. The large vehicle is difficult to steer in a straight line

questions.explanation: A long vehicle may need to swing out in the opposite direction as it approaches a turn, to allow the rear wheels to clear the kerb. Don’t try to filter through if you see a gap; as the lorry turns, the gap will close.

prashna.text: You're following a long vehicle. As it approaches a crossroads, it signals left but moves out to the right. What should you do?

options.description: A. Overtake it as it starts to slow down
B. Stay well back and give it room
C. Assume the signal is wrong and that it's turning right
D. Get closer in order to pass it quickly

questions.explanation: When a long vehicle is going to turn right, it may need to keep close to the left-hand kerb. This is to prevent the rear end of the trailer cutting the corner. You need to be aware of how long vehicles behave in such situations. Don’t overtake the lorry, because it could turn as you’re alongside. Stay behind and wait for it to turn.

prashna.text: You're following a long vehicle approaching a crossroads. The driver signals right but moves close to the left-hand kerb. What should you do?

options.description: A. Overtake on the right-hand side
B. Wait behind the long vehicle
C. Warn the driver about the wrong signal
D. Report the driver to the police

questions.explanation: At mini-roundabouts, there isn’t much room for a long vehicle to manoeuvre. It will have to swing out wide so that it can complete the turn safely. Keep well back and don’t try to move up alongside it.

prashna.text: You’re approaching a mini-roundabout. What should you do when you see the long vehicle in front signalling left but positioned over to the right?

options.description: A. Keep well back
B. Follow the same course as the lorry
C. Sound your horn
D. Overtake on the left

questions.explanation: When following a large vehicle, keep well back. If you’re too close, you won’t be able to see the road ahead and the driver of the long vehicle might not be able to see you in their mirrors.

prashna.text: Before overtaking a large vehicle, you should keep well back. Why is this?

options.description: A. To get the best view of the road ahead
B. To offer other drivers a safe gap if they want to overtake you
C. To give acceleration space to overtake quickly on blind bends
D. To leave a gap in case the vehicle stops and rolls back

questions.explanation:
There might be pedestrians crossing from in front of the bus. Look out for them if you intend to pass. Consider how many people are waiting to get on the bus - check the queue if you can. The bus might move off straight away if no-one is waiting to get on.
If a bus is signalling to pull out, give it priority if it’s safe to do so.

prashna.text: You're travelling behind a bus that pulls up at a bus stop. What should you do?

options.description: A. Watch carefully for pedestrians
B. Pull in closely behind the bus
C. Accelerate past the bus
D. Sound your horn

questions.explanation: Large vehicles throw up a lot of spray when it's wet. This makes it difficult for following drivers to see the road ahead. You'll be able to see more by dropping back further, out of the spray. This will also increase your separation distance, giving you more room to stop if you have to.

prashna.text: You're following a lorry on a wet road. What should you do when spray makes it difficult to see the road ahead?

options.description: A. Drop back until you can see better
B. Keep close to the lorry, away from the spray
C. Speed up and overtake quickly
D. Put your headlights on full beam

questions.explanation: Sometimes your separation distance is shortened by a driver moving into the gap you've allowed. When this happens, react positively, stay calm and drop further back to re-establish a safe following distance.

prashna.text: You keep well back while waiting to overtake a large vehicle. What should you do if a car moves into the gap?

options.description: A. Sound your horn
B. Drop back further
C. Flash your headlights
D. Start to overtake

questions.explanation: Try to give way to buses if you can do so safely, especially when the driver signals to pull away from a bus stop. Look out for people getting off the bus or running to catch it, because they may cross the road without looking. Don’t accelerate to get past the bus, and don't flash your lights, as this could mislead other road users.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're approaching a bus that's signalling to move away from a bus stop?

options.description: A. Flash your headlights as you approach
B. Allow it to pull away, if it's safe to do so
C. Signal left and wave the bus on
D. Get past before it moves

questions.explanation: When you're following a long vehicle, stay well back so that you can get a better view of the road ahead. The closer you get, the less you'll be able to see of the road. Be patient and don't take a gamble. Only overtake when you're certain that you can complete the manoeuvre safely.

prashna.text: How should you overtake a long, slow-moving vehicle on a busy road?

options.description: A. Keep well back until you can see that it's clear
B. Flash your headlights for the oncoming traffic to give way
C. Stay behind until the driver waves you past
D. Follow it closely and keep moving out to see the road ahead

questions.explanation: Although cars are the least likely to be affected, side winds can take anyone by surprise. This is most likely to happen after overtaking a large vehicle, when passing gaps between hedges or buildings, and on exposed sections of road.

prashna.text: Which of these is least likely to be affected by side winds?

options.description: A. Cyclists
B. High-sided vehicles
C. Cars
D. Motorcyclists

questions.explanation: When turning, long vehicles need much more room on the road than other vehicles. At junctions, they may take up the whole of the road space, so be patient and allow them the room they need.

prashna.text: What should you do as you approach this lorry?

options.description: A. Move to the right-hand side of the road
B. Make the lorry wait for you
C. Flash your lights at the lorry
D. Slow down and be prepared to wait

questions.explanation: Hold back and wait until the vehicle has turned before proceeding. Don't overtake, because the vehicle turning left could hide a vehicle emerging from the same junction.

prashna.text: You're following a large vehicle approaching a crossroads. The driver signals to turn left. What should you do?

options.description: A. Don't overtake as you approach or at the junction
B. Don't overtake until the vehicle begins to turn
C. Overtake if you can leave plenty of room
D. Overtake only if there are no oncoming vehicles

questions.explanation: Some powered wheelchairs and mobility scooters are designed for use on the pavement only and cannot exceed 4 mph (6 km/h). Others can go on the road as well, and this category cannot exceed 8 mph (12 km/h). Take great care around these vehicles. They're extremely vulnerable because of their low speed and small size.

prashna.text: What's the maximum speed of powered wheelchairs or scooters used by disabled people?

options.description: A. 16 mph
B. 12 mph
C. 20 mph
D. 8 mph

questions.explanation: Depending on relative speed, it will usually take you longer to pass a lorry than other vehicles. Hazards to watch for include oncoming traffic, junctions ahead, bends or dips that could restrict your view, and signs or road markings that prohibit overtaking. Make sure you can see that it’s safe to complete the manoeuvre before you start to overtake.

prashna.text: Why is it more difficult to overtake a large vehicle than a car?

options.description: A. It will be slow climbing hills
B. It will have air brakes
C. It will take longer to pass one
D. It will be fitted with a speed limiter

questions.explanation: Windy weather affects motorcyclists more than other vehicles. In windy conditions, high-sided vehicles cause air turbulence. You should keep well back, as the motorcyclist could be blown off course.

prashna.text: It's very windy. You're behind a motorcyclist who's overtaking a high-sided vehicle. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stay level with the motorcyclist
B. Overtake the motorcyclist immediately
C. Keep close to the motorcyclist
D. Keep well back

questions.explanation: As you approach, look out for any signal the driver might make. If you pass the vehicle, watch out for pedestrians attempting to cross the road from behind the bus. They’ll be hidden from view until the last moment.

prashna.text: You're driving in town. Ahead of you a bus is at a bus stop. Which of the following should you do?

options.description: A. Watch carefully for the sudden appearance of pedestrians
B. Continue at the same speed but sound your horn as a warning
C. Pass the bus as quickly as you possibly can
D. Flash your lights to warn the driver of your presence

questions.explanation: Sometimes, large vehicles may need more space than other road users. If a vehicle needs more time and space to turn, be prepared to stop and wait.

prashna.text: You're driving along this road. What should you be prepared to do?

options.description: A. Slow down and give way
B. Report the driver to the police
C. Sound your horn and continue
D. Squeeze through the gap

questions.explanation:
You should take extra care when you first encounter trams. You'll have to get used to dealing with a different traffic system.
Be aware that trams can accelerate and travel very quickly, and they can't change direction to avoid obstructions.

prashna.text: As a driver, why should you be more careful where trams operate?

options.description: A. Because they can't steer to avoid you
B. Because they don't have lights
C. Because they don't have a horn
D. Because they can't stop for cars

questions.explanation: Towing a large trailer or caravan can greatly reduce your view of the road behind. You may need to fit extended-arm side mirrors so that you can see clearly behind and down both sides of the caravan or trailer.

prashna.text: You're towing a caravan. Which is the safest type of rear-view mirror to use?

options.description: A. Interior wide-angle mirror
B. Ordinary door mirrors
C. Extended-arm side mirrors
D. Ordinary interior mirror

questions.explanation: You must make sure that other road users can see you, but you don't want to dazzle them. Use your dipped headlights during the day if visibility is poor. If visibility falls below 100 metres (328 feet), you may use your rear fog lights, but don’t forget to turn them off when the visibility improves.

prashna.text: You're driving in heavy traffic on a wet road. Spray makes it difficult to be seen. What lights should you use?

options.description: A. Full-beam headlights
B. Rear fog lights if visibility is more than 100 metres (328 feet)
C. Dipped headlights
D. Sidelights only

questions.explanation: Cyclists, and motorcyclists, are very vulnerable in high winds. They can easily be blown well off course and veer into your path. Always allow plenty of room when overtaking them. Passing too close could cause a draught and unbalance the rider.

prashna.text: It's a very windy day and you're about to overtake a cyclist. What should you do?

options.description: A. Sound your horn repeatedly
B. Allow extra room
C. Keep close as you pass
D. Overtake very slowly

questions.explanation: You may pass slower vehicles on their left while travelling along a one-way street. Be aware of drivers who may need to change lanes and may not expect faster traffic passing on their left.

prashna.text: When may you overtake another vehicle on the left?

options.description: A. When approaching a motorway slip road where you’ll be turning off
B. When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn left
C. When a slower vehicle is travelling in the right-hand lane of a dual carriageway
D. When you’re in a one-way street

questions.explanation: The road will be very wet and spray from other vehicles will reduce your visibility. Tyre grip will also be reduced, increasing your stopping distance. You should at least double your separation distance.

prashna.text: You're travelling in very heavy rain. How is this likely to affect your overall stopping distance?

options.description: A. It will be no different
B. It will be ten times greater
C. It will be doubled
D. It will be halved

questions.explanation: Don't overtake if there’s a possibility of a road junction, bend or brow of a bridge or hill ahead. There are many hazards that are difficult to see in the dark. Only overtake if you’re certain that the road ahead is clear. Don’t take a chance.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're overtaking at night?

options.description: A. Wait until a bend so that you can see oncoming headlights
B. Beware of bends in the road ahead
C. Sound your horn twice before moving out
D. Put your headlights on full beam

questions.explanation:
The purpose of a box junction is to keep the junction clear by preventing vehicles from stopping in the path of crossing traffic.
You mustn't enter a box junction unless your exit is clear. However, you may enter the box and wait if you want to turn right and are only prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic.

prashna.text: When may you wait in a box junction?

options.description: A. When oncoming traffic prevents you turning right
B. When approaching a zebra crossing
C. When approaching a pelican crossing
D. When you're stationary in a queue of traffic

questions.explanation:
Road humps are used to slow down traffic. They're found in places where there are often pedestrians, such as
• shopping areas
• near schools
• residential areas.
Watch out for people close to the kerb or crossing the road.

prashna.text: Which of these plates normally appears with this road sign?

questions.explanation: Traffic-calming measures make the roads safer for vulnerable road users, such as cyclists, pedestrians and children. These can be designed as chicanes, road humps or other obstacles that encourage drivers and riders to slow down.

prashna.text: What do traffic-calming measures do?

options.description: A. Stop road rage
B. Make parking easier
C. Make overtaking easier
D. Slow traffic down

questions.explanation:
Be especially careful if you’re on a motorway in fog. Reflective studs are there to help you in poor visibility. Different colours are used so that you’ll know which lane you're in. These are
• red on the left-hand edge of the carriageway
• white between lanes
• amber on the right-hand edge of the carriageway
• green between the carriageway and slip roads.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway in fog. The left-hand edge of the motorway can be identified by reflective studs. What colour are they?

options.description: A. Red
B. White
C. Green
D. Amber

questions.explanation: A rumble device consists of raised markings or strips across the road, designed to give drivers an audible, visual and tactile warning. These devices are used in various locations, including in the line separating the hard shoulder and the left-hand lane on the motorway and on the approach to some hazards, to alert drivers to the need to slow down.

prashna.text: What's a rumble device designed to do?

options.description: A. Prevent cattle escaping
B. Alert you to a hazard
C. Give directions
D. Alert you to low tyre pressure

questions.explanation: If you’re planning to make a journey when it’s foggy, listen to the weather reports. If visibility is very poor, avoid making unnecessary journeys. If you do travel, leave plenty of time – and if someone is waiting for you to arrive, let them know that your journey will take longer than normal. This will also take off any pressure you may feel to rush.

prashna.text: What should you do when making a journey in foggy conditions?

options.description: A. Keep two seconds behind the vehicle ahead
B. Leave plenty of time for your journey
C. Follow other vehicles’ tail lights closely
D. Avoid using dipped headlights

questions.explanation: To prevent your lights from dazzling the driver of the car in front, wait until you’ve passed them before switching to full beam.

prashna.text: What must you do when overtaking a car at night?

options.description: A. Flash your headlights before overtaking
B. Select a higher gear
C. Switch your lights to full beam before overtaking
D. Make sure you don't dazzle other road users

questions.explanation: Be patient and stay behind the car in front. You shouldn't normally overtake other vehicles in areas subject to traffic calming. If you overtake here, you may easily exceed the speed limit, defeating the purpose of the traffic-calming measures.

prashna.text: You're travelling on a road that has speed humps. What should you do when the driver in front is travelling more slowly than you?

options.description: A. Overtake as soon as you can
B. Sound your horn
C. Flash your headlights
D. Slow down and stay behind

questions.explanation: These lines may be painted on the road on the approach to a roundabout, a village or a particular hazard. The lines are raised and painted yellow, and their purpose is to make you aware of your speed. Reduce your speed in good time so that you avoid having to brake harshly over the last few metres before reaching the junction.

prashna.text: You see these markings on the road. Why are they there?

options.description: A. To make you aware of your speed
B. To keep the area clear of traffic
C. To show a safe distance between vehicles
D. To warn you to change direction

questions.explanation: Trams may run on roads used by other vehicles and pedestrians. The section of road used by trams is known as the reserved area and should be kept clear. It usually has a different surface, edged with white lane markings.

prashna.text: How would you identify a section of road used by trams?

options.description: A. There would be a different surface texture
B. There would be metal studs around it
C. There would be zigzag markings alongside it
D. There would be yellow hatch markings around it

questions.explanation: Take care when using single-track roads. It can be difficult to see around bends, because of hedges or fences, so expect to meet oncoming vehicles. Drive carefully and be ready to pull into or stop opposite a passing place, where you can pass each other safely.

prashna.text: What should you do when you meet an oncoming vehicle on a single-track road?

options.description: A. Carry out an emergency stop
B. Reverse back to the main road
C. Switch on your hazard warning lights
D. Stop at a passing place

questions.explanation: Other drivers or riders may have to change course due to the size or characteristics of their vehicle. Understanding this will help you to anticipate their actions. Motorcyclists and cyclists will be checking the road ahead for uneven or slippery surfaces, especially in wet weather. They may need to move across their lane to avoid surface hazards such as potholes and drain covers.

prashna.text: The road is wet. Why might a motorcyclist steer round drain covers on a bend?

options.description: A. To help judge the bend using the drain covers as marker points
B. To avoid puncturing the tyres on the edge of the drain covers
C. To prevent the motorcycle sliding on the metal drain covers
D. To avoid splashing pedestrians on the pavement

questions.explanation: A ford is a crossing over a stream that’s shallow enough to drive or ride through. After you’ve gone through a ford or deep puddle, your brakes will be wet and they won't work as well as usual. To dry them out, apply a light brake pressure while moving slowly. Don’t travel at normal speeds until you're sure your brakes are working properly again.

prashna.text: After this hazard you should test your brakes. Why is this?

options.description: A. You'll have just crossed a long bridge
B. You'll be on a slippery road
C. Your brakes will be soaking wet
D. You'll be going down a long hill

questions.explanation:
You won’t be able to see as far ahead in fog as you can on a clear day. You'll need to reduce your speed so that, if a hazard looms out of the fog, you have the time and space to take avoiding action.
Travelling in fog is hazardous. If you can, try to delay your journey until it has cleared.

prashna.text: Why should you always reduce your speed when travelling in fog?

options.description: A. The engine will take longer to warm up
B. It's more difficult to see what's ahead
C. You'll be dazzled by other headlights
D. The brakes don't work as well

questions.explanation: The engine will need more power to pull the vehicle up the hill. When approaching a steep hill you should select a lower gear to help maintain your speed. You should do this without hesitation, so that you don’t lose too much speed before engaging the lower gear.

prashna.text: How will your vehicle be affected when you drive up steep hills?

options.description: A. The higher gears will pull better
B. The engine will work harder
C. The steering will feel heavier
D. Overtaking will be easier

questions.explanation: The draught caused by other vehicles – particularly those with high sides – could be strong enough to push you out of your lane. Be prepared for a sudden gust of wind as you pass large vehicles. Keep both hands on the steering wheel to help you keep full control.

prashna.text: You're driving on the motorway in windy conditions. What should you do as you pass a high-sided vehicle?

options.description: A. Expect normal conditions
B. Drive alongside very closely
C. Be wary of a sudden gust
D. Increase your speed

questions.explanation: If your car skids and the rear wheels slide to the right, you need to steer into the skid (ie to the right), until the front and rear wheels are brought into line. Don’t oversteer or you'll cause a skid in the opposite direction and this will make the situation worse.

prashna.text: What should you do to correct a rear-wheel skid?

options.description: A. Not steer at all
B. Steer away from it
C. Steer into it
D. Apply your handbrake

questions.explanation: If you’re following another road user in fog, stay well back. The driver in front won’t be able to see hazards until they’re close and might need to brake suddenly. Also, the road surface is likely to be wet and could be slippery.

prashna.text: You're driving in fog. Why should you keep well back from the vehicle in front?

options.description: A. In case its brake lights dazzle you
B. In case it stops suddenly
C. In case its fog lights dazzle you
D. In case it changes direction suddenly

questions.explanation: If you have to park your vehicle in foggy conditions, try to find a place to park off the road. If this isn’t possible, park on the road facing in the same direction as the traffic. Leave your sidelights switched on and make sure they're clean.

prashna.text: What should you do if you park on the road when it's foggy?

options.description: A. Leave sidelights switched on
B. Leave dipped headlights and fog lights switched on
C. Leave dipped headlights switched on
D. Leave main-beam headlights switched on

questions.explanation: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle dazzle you, slow down or, if necessary, stop. Don’t close your eyes or swerve, as you'll increase your chances of having a collision. Don't flash your headlights either, as this could dazzle other drivers and make the situation worse.

prashna.text: You're driving at night and are dazzled by vehicle headlights coming towards you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Slow down or stop
B. Shade your eyes with your hand
C. Pull down your sun visor
D. Flash your main-beam headlights

questions.explanation: Your fog lights must only be used when visibility is reduced to 100 metres (328 feet) or less. You need to be familiar with the layout of your dashboard so you're aware if your fog lights have been switched on in error, or you've forgotten to switch them off.

prashna.text: When may front fog lights be used?

options.description: A. When an audible warning device is used
B. When they're fitted above the bumper
C. When they aren't as bright as the headlights
D. When visibility is seriously reduced

questions.explanation: Switch off your fog lights if the weather improves, but be prepared to use them again if visibility reduces to less than 100 metres (328 feet).

prashna.text: You're driving with your front fog lights switched on. Earlier fog has now cleared. What should you do?

options.description: A. Leave them on if other drivers have their lights on
B. Flash them to warn oncoming traffic that it's foggy
C. Switch them off as long as visibility remains good
D. Drive with them on instead of your headlights

questions.explanation: Don’t forget to switch off your fog lights when the weather improves. You could be prosecuted for driving with them on in good visibility. The high intensity of rear fog lights can dazzle following drivers and make your brake lights difficult to notice.

prashna.text: Why should you switch off your rear fog lights when the fog has cleared?

options.description: A. To allow your headlights to work
B. To prevent dazzling following drivers
C. To stop draining the battery
D. To stop the engine losing power

questions.explanation: Rear fog lights shine more brightly than normal rear lights, so that they show up in reduced visibility. When the visibility improves, you must switch them off; this stops them dazzling the driver behind.

prashna.text: What will happen if you use rear fog lights in good conditions?

options.description: A. They'll make it safer when towing a trailer
B. They'll make following drivers keep back
C. They'll dazzle other drivers
D. They'll protect you from larger vehicles

questions.explanation: Chains can be fitted to your wheels in snowy conditions. They can help you to move off without wheelspin, or to keep moving in deep snow. You'll still need to adjust your driving to suit these conditions.

prashna.text: What can fitting chains to your wheels help to prevent?

options.description: A. Wear to the tyres
B. Skidding in deep snow
C. The brakes locking
D. Damage to the road surface

questions.explanation: You should brake and slow down before selecting a lower gear. The gear can then be used to keep the speed low and help you control the vehicle. This is particularly helpful on long downhill stretches, where brake fade can occur if the brakes overheat.

prashna.text: How can you use your vehicle's engine to control your speed?

options.description: A. By selecting neutral
B. By selecting reverse gear
C. By changing to a lower gear
D. By changing to a higher gear

questions.explanation: Letting your vehicle roll or coast in neutral reduces your control over steering and braking. This can be dangerous on downhill slopes, where your vehicle could pick up speed very quickly.

prashna.text: Why could it be dangerous to keep the clutch down, or select neutral, for long periods of time while you're driving?

options.description: A. It will wear tyres out more quickly
B. Fuel spillage will occur
C. Engine damage may be caused
D. You'll have less steering and braking control

questions.explanation:
Don’t travel in icy or snowy weather unless your journey is essential.
Drive extremely carefully when roads are or may be icy. Stopping distances can be ten times greater than on dry roads.

prashna.text: You're driving on an icy road. What distance from the car in front should you drive?

options.description: A. Six times the normal distance
B. Ten times the normal distance
C. Eight times the normal distance
D. Four times the normal distance

questions.explanation: If you’re driving on a motorway at night or in poor visibility, you must always use your headlights, even if the road is well lit. Other road users must be able to see you, but you should avoid causing dazzle.

prashna.text: You're driving on a well-lit motorway on a clear night. What must you do?

options.description: A. Use your headlights
B. Use only your sidelights
C. Use front fog lights
D. Use rear fog lights

questions.explanation: If you’re driving behind other traffic on the motorway at night, use dipped headlights. Main-beam headlights will dazzle the other drivers. Your headlights’ dipped beam should fall short of the vehicle in front.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway at night, with other vehicles just ahead of you. Which lights should you have on?

options.description: A. Front fog lights
B. Dipped headlights
C. Main-beam headlights
D. Sidelights only

questions.explanation: Having tyres correctly inflated and in good condition will ensure they have maximum grip on the road; how well your tyres grip the road has a significant effect on your car's stopping distance.

prashna.text: What will affect your vehicle's stopping distance?

options.description: A. The time of day
B. The speed limit
C. The condition of the tyres
D. The street lighting

questions.explanation: Always use your headlights at night on a motorway unless you've had to stop on the hard shoulder. If you break down and have to use the hard shoulder, switch off your headlights but leave your sidelights on, so that other road users can see your vehicle.

prashna.text: You're driving on a motorway at night. When may you switch off your  headlights?

options.description: A. When there are vehicles close in front of you
B. When your vehicle is broken down on the hard shoulder
C. When you're travelling below 50 mph
D. When the motorway is lit

questions.explanation: When you take your foot off the accelerator, engines have a natural resistance to turn, caused mainly by the cylinder compression. Changing to a lower gear requires the engine to turn faster and so it will have greater resistance than when it's made to turn more slowly. When going downhill, changing to a lower gear will therefore help to keep the vehicle's speed in check.

prashna.text: When will you feel the effects of engine braking?

options.description: A. When you only use the handbrake
B. When you change to a lower gear
C. When you're in neutral
D. When you change to a higher gear

questions.explanation: Only use your fog lights when visibility is seriously reduced. Use dipped headlights in poor conditions because this helps other road users to see you without the risk of causing dazzle.

prashna.text: Daytime visibility is poor but not seriously reduced. Which lights should you switch on?

options.description: A. Rear fog lights
B. Headlights and fog lights
C. Front fog lights
D. Dipped headlights

questions.explanation: Rear fog lights make it easier to spot a vehicle ahead in foggy conditions. Avoid the temptation to use other vehicles’ lights as a guide, as they may give you a false sense of security.

prashna.text: Why are vehicles fitted with rear fog lights?

options.description: A. To show when they've broken down in a dangerous position
B. To make them more visible when driving at high speed
C. To warn drivers following closely to drop back
D. To make them more visible in thick fog

questions.explanation: It's illegal to use your fog lights in conditions other than when visibility is seriously reduced; that is, less than 100 metres (328 feet). Fog lights are very bright and, if you use them when visibility has improved, you could dazzle other drivers.

prashna.text: While you're driving in fog, it becomes necessary to use front fog lights. What should you remember?

options.description: A. Only use them in heavy traffic conditions
B. Only use them on dual carriageways
C. Don't use them on motorways
D. Switch them off when visibility improves

questions.explanation: Consider whether the increased risk is worth it. If the weather conditions are bad and your journey isn’t essential, then don't drive.

prashna.text: What should you do when there's been a heavy fall of snow?

options.description: A. Don't drive unless you have a mobile phone
B. Drive with your hazard warning lights on
C. Only drive when your journey is short
D. Don't drive unless it's essential

questions.explanation: This is more likely to happen on vehicles fitted with drum brakes, but it can apply to disc brakes as well. Using a lower gear will assist the braking and help you to keep control of your vehicle.

prashna.text: You're driving down a long, steep hill. You suddenly notice that your brakes aren't working as well as normal. What's the usual cause of this?

options.description: A. Oil on the brakes
B. The brakes overheating
C. Air in the brake fluid
D. Badly adjusted brakes

questions.explanation: If you have to drive in fog, switch your dipped-beam headlights on and keep your windscreen clear. You should always be able to pull up within the distance you can see ahead.

prashna.text: You have to make a journey in fog. What should you do before you set out?

options.description: A. Make sure that the windows are clean
B. Top up the radiator with anti-freeze
C. Check the battery
D. Make sure that you have a warning triangle in the vehicle

questions.explanation: You must turn off your fog lights if visibility is more than 100 metres (328 feet). Be prepared for the fact that the fog may be patchy and you may need to turn them on again if the fog returns.

prashna.text: You've just driven out of fog. What must you do now that visibility has improved?

options.description: A. Keep your rear fog lights switched on
B. Leave your fog lights switched on in case the fog returns
C. Keep your front fog lights switched on
D. Switch off your fog lights

questions.explanation: If your rear fog lights are left on when it isn’t foggy, the glare they cause makes it difficult for road users behind to know whether you’re braking or you’ve just forgotten to turn off your rear fog lights. This can be a particular problem on wet roads and on motorways. If you leave your rear fog lights on at night, road users behind you are likely to be dazzled and this could put them at risk.

prashna.text: Why is it dangerous to leave rear fog lights on when they’re not needed?

options.description: A. They may be confused with brake lights
B. Electrical systems could be overloaded
C. The bulbs would fail
D. Direction indicators may not work properly

questions.explanation: Holding the clutch down or staying in neutral for too long will cause your vehicle to freewheel. This is known as ‘coasting’ and it's dangerous because it reduces your control of the vehicle.

prashna.text: What will happen if you hold the clutch pedal down or roll in neutral for too long?

options.description: A. It will use more fuel
B. It will improve tyre wear
C. It will cause the engine to overheat
D. It will reduce your control

questions.explanation: Driving in neutral or with the clutch down for long periods is known as ‘coasting’. There will be no engine braking and your vehicle will pick up speed on downhill slopes. Coasting can be very dangerous because it reduces steering and braking control.

prashna.text: You're driving down a steep hill. Why could it be dangerous to keep the clutch down or roll in neutral for too long?

options.description: A. It will damage the engine
B. It will wear tyres out more quickly
C. Your vehicle will pick up speed
D. Fuel consumption will be higher

questions.explanation: Coasting is when you allow the vehicle to freewheel in neutral or with the clutch pedal depressed. Speed will increase as you lose the benefits of engine braking and have less control. You shouldn't coast, especially when approaching hazards such as junctions or bends and when travelling downhill.

prashna.text: Why is it bad technique to coast when driving downhill?

options.description: A. The fuel consumption will increase
B. The engine will overheat
C. The vehicle will gain speed
D. The tyres will wear more quickly

questions.explanation: In normal conditions, a ford can be crossed quite safely by driving through it slowly. The water may affect your brakes, so when you're clear of the ford, test them before you resume normal driving.

prashna.text: What should you do when dealing with this hazard?

options.description: A. Use a high gear to prevent wheelspin
B. Use a low gear and drive slowly
C. Switch on your hazard warning lights
D. Switch on your windscreen wipers

questions.explanation:
Try to look ahead and read the road. Plan your approach to junctions and select the correct gear in good time. This will give you the control you need to deal with any hazards that occur.
You’ll coast a little every time you change gear. This can’t be avoided, but it should be kept to a minimum.

prashna.text: Why is travelling in neutral for long distances (known as coasting) wrong?

options.description: A. The engine will run faster
B. It will make the engine stall
C. It will cause the car to skid
D. There won't be any engine braking

questions.explanation: You must use dipped headlights when daytime visibility is seriously reduced, generally to 100 metres (328 feet) or less. You may also use front or rear fog lights, but they must be switched off when visibility improves.

prashna.text: When must you use dipped headlights during the day?

options.description: A. On narrow streets
B. When parking
C. All the time
D. In poor visibility

questions.explanation: If the skid has been caused by braking too hard for the conditions, release the brake. You may then need to reapply and release the brake again. You may need to do this a number of times. This will allow the wheels to turn and so some steering should also be possible.

prashna.text: You're braking on a wet road. Your vehicle begins to skid. It doesn't have anti-lock brakes. What's the first thing you should do?

options.description: A. Gently use the accelerator
B. Push harder on the brake pedal
C. Release the footbrake
D. Quickly pull up the handbrake

questions.explanation: You should give way to traffic already on the motorway. Where possible, traffic may move over to let you in, but don’t force your way into the traffic stream. Traffic could be travelling at high speed, so try to match your speed to filter in without affecting the traffic flow.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're joining a motorway?

options.description: A. Give way to traffic already on the motorway
B. Stop at the end of the acceleration lane
C. Slow to a stop before joining the motorway
D. Use the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: Travelling at the national speed limit doesn’t allow you to hog the right-hand lane. Always use the left-hand lane whenever possible. When leaving a motorway, get into the left-hand lane well before your exit. Reduce your speed on the slip road and look out for sharp bends or curves and traffic queuing at roundabouts.

prashna.text: What's the national speed limit on motorways for cars and motorcycles?

options.description: A. 30 mph
B. 70 mph
C. 50 mph
D. 60 mph

questions.explanation: On a motorway, all traffic should use the left-hand lane unless overtaking. When overtaking a number of slower vehicles, move back to the left-hand lane when you’re safely past. Check your mirrors frequently and don’t stay in the middle or right-hand lane if the left-hand lane is free.

prashna.text: Which vehicles should use the left-hand lane on a three-lane motorway?

options.description: A. Slow vehicles only
B. Emergency vehicles only
C. Large vehicles only
D. Any vehicle

questions.explanation: A vehicle with a trailer is restricted to 60 mph. For this reason, it isn’t allowed in the right-hand lane, as it might hold up faster-moving traffic that wishes to overtake in that lane.

prashna.text: Which of these isn't allowed to travel in the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway?

options.description: A. A small delivery van
B. A motorcycle
C. A vehicle towing a trailer
D. A motorcycle and sidecar

questions.explanation: On a motorway, it's best to use a roadside emergency telephone so that the emergency services are able to find you easily. The location of the nearest telephone is shown by an arrow on marker posts at the edge of the hard shoulder. If you use a mobile, the operator will need to know your exact location. Before you call, find out the number on the nearest marker post. This number will identify your exact location.

prashna.text: You break down on a motorway. You need to call for help. Why may it be better to use an emergency roadside telephone rather than a mobile phone?

options.description: A. Mobile phones don't work on motorways
B. It connects you to a local garage
C. It allows easy location by the emergency services
D. Using a mobile phone will distract other drivers

questions.explanation: Signal your intention and build up sufficient speed on the hard shoulder so that you can filter into a safe gap in the traffic. Don't push your way in, causing other traffic to alter speed or direction.

prashna.text: You've had a breakdown on the hard shoulder of a motorway. When the problem has been fixed, how should you rejoin the main carriageway?

options.description: A. Wait on the hard shoulder until someone flashes their headlights at you
B. Move out onto the carriageway, then build up your speed
C. Move out onto the carriageway using your hazard warning lights
D. Gain speed on the hard shoulder before moving out onto the carriageway

questions.explanation: Large, slow-moving vehicles can hinder the progress of other traffic. On a steep gradient, an extra crawler lane may be provided for slow-moving vehicles to allow faster-moving traffic to flow more easily.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a motorway. Where would you find a crawler or climbing lane?

options.description: A. Before a junction
B. Before a service area
C. Along the hard shoulder
D. On a steep gradient

questions.explanation: The exit from a motorway is indicated by countdown markers. These are positioned 90 metres (100 yards) apart, the first being 270 metres (300 yards) from the start of the slip road. Move into the left-hand lane well before you reach the start of the slip road.

prashna.text: What do these motorway signs show?

options.description: A. They're distance markers to the next telephone
B. They warn of a police control ahead
C. They're countdown markers to the next exit
D. They're countdown markers to a bridge

questions.explanation: On motorways, reflective studs of various colours are fixed in the road between the lanes. These help you to identify which lane you're in when it's dark or in poor visibility. Amber-coloured studs are found on the right-hand edge of the main carriageway, next to the central reservation.

prashna.text: On which part of a motorway are amber reflective studs found?

options.description: A. Between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
B. Between the acceleration lane and the carriageway
C. Between the central reservation and the carriageway
D. Between each pair of lanes

questions.explanation: White studs are found between the lanes on motorways. They reflect back the light from your headlights. This is especially useful in bad weather, when visibility is restricted.

prashna.text: What colour are the reflective studs between the lanes on a motorway?

options.description: A. Red
B. Green
C. Amber
D. White

questions.explanation: The studs between the carriageway and the hard shoulder are normally red. These change to green where there's a slip road, helping you to identify slip roads when visibility is poor or when it's dark.

prashna.text: What colour are the reflective studs between a motorway and its slip road?

options.description: A. White
B. Green
C. Red
D. Amber

questions.explanation: Along the hard shoulder there are marker posts at 100-metre intervals. These will direct you to the nearest emergency telephone.

prashna.text: You've broken down on a motorway. In which direction should you walk to find the nearest emergency telephone?

options.description: A. Facing oncoming traffic
B. In the direction shown on the marker posts
C. With the traffic flow
D. In the direction of the nearest exit

questions.explanation: Try to join the motorway without affecting the progress of the traffic already travelling on it. Always give way to traffic already on the motorway. At busy times you may have to slow down to merge into slow-moving traffic.

prashna.text: You’re joining a motorway. Why is it important to make full use of the slip road?

options.description: A. To build up a speed similar to traffic on the motorway
B. Because you can continue on the hard shoulder
C. Because there is space available to turn round if you need to
D. To allow you direct access to the overtaking lanes

questions.explanation: Traffic is passing you at speed. If the draught from a large lorry catches you by surprise, it could blow you off balance and even onto the carriageway. By facing the oncoming traffic, you can see approaching lorries and so be prepared for their draught. You'll also be in a position to see other hazards approaching.

prashna.text: How should you use the emergency telephone on a motorway?

options.description: A. Keep your back to the traffic
B. Stand on the hard shoulder
C. Stay close to the carriageway
D. Face the oncoming traffic

questions.explanation: Red studs are placed between the edge of the carriageway and the hard shoulder. Where slip roads leave or join the motorway, the studs are green.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. What colour are the reflective studs on the left of the carriageway?

options.description: A. Amber
B. Green
C. Red
D. White

questions.explanation: On a three-lane motorway, you should travel in the left-hand lane unless you’re overtaking. This applies regardless of the speed at which you’re travelling.

prashna.text: On a three-lane motorway, which lane should you normally use?

options.description: A. Either the right or centre
B. Right
C. Centre
D. Left

questions.explanation:
At roadworks, and especially where a contraflow system is operating, a speed restriction is likely to be in place. Keep to the lower speed limit and don’t
• switch lanes
• get too close to the vehicle in front of you.
Be aware that there will be no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic.

prashna.text: What should you do when going through a contraflow system on a motorway?

options.description: A. Stay close to the vehicle ahead to reduce queues
B. Switch lanes to keep the traffic flowing
C. Keep a good distance from the vehicle ahead
D. Ensure that you don't exceed 30 mph

questions.explanation:
The colours of the reflective studs on the motorway and their locations are
• red – between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
• white – between lanes
• amber – between the carriageway and the central reservation
• green – along slip-road exits and entrances
• bright green/yellow – at roadworks and contraflow systems.

prashna.text: You're on a three-lane motorway. There are red reflective studs on your left and white ones to your right. Which lane are you in?

options.description: A. In the left-hand lane
B. On the hard shoulder
C. In the middle lane
D. In the right-hand lane

questions.explanation: Collisions often happen at roadworks. Be aware of the speed limits, slow down in good time and keep your distance from the vehicle in front.

prashna.text: You're approaching roadworks on a motorway. What should you do?

options.description: A. Speed up to clear the area quickly
B. Stay very close to the vehicle in front
C. Obey all speed limits
D. Always use the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: Motorways mustn’t be used by pedestrians, cyclists, motorcycles under 50 cc, certain slow-moving vehicles without permission, and powered wheelchairs/mobility scooters.

prashna.text: Which vehicles are prohibited from using the motorway?

options.description: A. Powered mobility scooters
B. Motorcycles over 50 cc
C. Double-deck buses
D. Cars with automatic transmission

questions.explanation: Traffic on motorways usually travels faster than on other roads. You need to be looking further ahead to give yourself more time to react to any hazard that may develop.

prashna.text: What should you do when driving or riding along a motorway?

options.description: A. Maintain a shorter separation distance than you would on other roads
B. Look much further ahead than you would on other roads
C. Travel much faster than you would on other roads
D. Concentrate more than you would on other roads

questions.explanation: Stay in the left-hand lane long enough to get used to the higher speeds of motorway traffic before considering overtaking.

prashna.text: What should you do immediately after joining a motorway?

options.description: A. Keep in the left-hand lane
B. Position your vehicle in the centre lane
C. Try to overtake
D. Re-adjust your mirrors

questions.explanation: You should keep to the left and only use the right-hand lane if you’re passing slower-moving traffic.

prashna.text: What's the right-hand lane used for on a three-lane motorway?

options.description: A. Coaches only
B. Vehicles towing trailers
C. Emergency vehicles only
D. Overtaking

questions.explanation: Don’t use the hard shoulder for stopping unless it's an emergency. If you want to stop for any other reason, go to the next exit or service station.

prashna.text: What should you use the hard shoulder of a motorway for?

options.description: A. Stopping when you're tired
B. Stopping in an emergency
C. Leaving the motorway
D. Joining the motorway

questions.explanation: You must obey these signs even if there appear to be no problems ahead. There could be queuing traffic or another hazard which you can't yet see.

prashna.text: You're in the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway. What do these overhead signs mean?

options.description: A. Use the hard shoulder until you've passed the hazard
B. Move to the left and reduce your speed to 50 mph
C. Leave the motorway at the next exit
D. There are roadworks 50 metres (55 yards) ahead

questions.explanation: You must stop if overhead gantry signs show flashing red lights above every lane on the motorway. If any of the other lanes doesn't show flashing red lights or a red cross, you may move into that lane and continue if it's safe to do so.

prashna.text: When are you allowed to stop on a motorway?

options.description: A. When you wish to pick up hitchhikers
B. When you need to use a mobile telephone
C. When you need to walk and get fresh air
D. When you're signalled to do so by flashing red lights

questions.explanation: Plan well ahead when approaching a slip road. If you see traffic joining the motorway, move to another lane if it's safe to do so. This can help the flow of traffic joining the motorway, especially at peak times.

prashna.text: You're travelling in the left-hand lane of a three-lane motorway. How should you react to traffic joining from a slip road?

options.description: A. Race the other vehicles
B. Maintain a steady speed
C. Move to another lane
D. Switch on your hazard warning lights

questions.explanation: You should normally travel in the left-hand lane unless you're overtaking a slower-moving vehicle. When you've finished overtaking, move back into the left-hand lane, but don’t cut across in front of the vehicle that you’ve overtaken.

prashna.text: What basic rule applies when you're using a motorway?

options.description: A. Use the lane that has the least traffic
B. Overtake on the side that’s clearest
C. Try to keep above 50 mph to prevent congestion
D. Keep to the left-hand lane unless overtaking

questions.explanation: Never overtake on the left, unless the traffic is moving in queues and the queue on your right is moving more slowly than the one you’re in.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a motorway. When are you allowed to overtake on the left?

options.description: A. When you warn drivers behind by signalling left
B. When you can see well ahead that the hard shoulder is clear
C. When the traffic in the right-hand lane is signalling right
D. When in queues and traffic to your right is moving more slowly than you are

questions.explanation: Emergency refuge areas are built at the side of the hard shoulder. If you break down, try to get your vehicle into the refuge, where there's an emergency telephone. The phone connects directly to a control centre. Remember to take care when rejoining the motorway, especially if the hard shoulder is being used as a running lane.

prashna.text: On a motorway, what's an emergency refuge area used for?

options.description: A. For a police patrol to park and watch traffic
B. If you think you'll be involved in a road rage incident
C. In cases of emergency or breakdown
D. For construction and road workers to store emergency equipment

questions.explanation: Traffic officers don't have enforcement powers but are able to stop and direct people on motorways and some ‘A’ class roads. They only operate in England and work in partnership with the police at incidents, providing a highly trained and visible service. They're recognised by an orange-and-yellow jacket and their vehicle has yellow-and-black markings.

prashna.text: Traffic officers operate on motorways and some primary routes in England. What are they authorised to do?

options.description: A. Stop and direct anyone on a motorway
B. Repair broken-down vehicles on the motorway
C. Stop and arrest drivers who break the law
D. Issue fixed penalty notices

questions.explanation: Active traffic management operates on some motorways. Within these areas, at certain times, the hard shoulder will be used as a running lane. A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that this lane should only be used for emergencies and breakdowns.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. A red cross is displayed above the hard shoulder. What does this mean?

options.description: A. Pull up in this lane to answer your mobile phone
B. This lane can be used if you need a rest
C. Use this lane as a running lane
D. You shouldn't travel in this lane

questions.explanation: A mandatory speed-limit sign above the hard shoulder shows that this part of the road can be used as a running lane between junctions. You must stay within the speed limit. Look out for vehicles that may have broken down and could be blocking the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: You're on a smart motorway. A mandatory speed limit is displayed above the hard shoulder. What does this mean?

options.description: A. You can pull up in this lane to answer a mobile phone
B. The hard shoulder can be used as a running lane
C. You can park on the hard shoulder if you feel tired
D. You shouldn't travel in this lane

questions.explanation: Smart motorway schemes are intended to reduce congestion and make journey times more reliable. In these areas, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane to ease congestion at peak times or in the event of an incident. Variable speed limits are used to help keep the traffic moving and to avoid bunching.

prashna.text: What's the aim of a smart motorway?

options.description: A. To prevent tailgating
B. To reduce congestion
C. To prevent overtaking
D. To reduce rest stops

questions.explanation: When a smart motorway is operating, you must follow the mandatory signs on the gantries above each lane, including the hard shoulder. Variable speed limits help keep the traffic moving and also help to prevent bunching.

prashna.text: You're using a smart motorway. What happens when it's operating?

options.description: A. Speed limits above lanes are advisory
B. The national speed limit will apply
C. The speed limit is always 30 mph
D. You must obey the speed limits shown

questions.explanation: When traffic travels at a constant speed over a longer distance, journey times normally improve. You may feel that you could travel faster for short periods, but this generally leads to bunching and increased overall journey time.

prashna.text: Why can it be an advantage for traffic speed to stay constant over a longer distance?

options.description: A. Your overall journey time will normally improve
B. You'll do more stop–start driving
C. You'll use far more fuel
D. You'll be able to use more direct routes

questions.explanation: Normally, you should only use the hard shoulder for emergencies and breakdowns, and at roadworks when signs direct you to do so. Smart motorways use active traffic management to ease congestion. In these areas, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane when speed-limit signs are shown directly above.

prashna.text: You shouldn't normally travel on the hard shoulder of a motorway. When can you use it?

options.description: A. When traffic is stopped
B. When taking the next exit
C. When signs direct you to
D. When traffic is slow moving

questions.explanation: Congestion can be reduced by keeping traffic at a constant speed. At busy times, maximum speed limits are displayed on overhead gantries. These can be varied quickly, depending on the amount of traffic. By keeping to a constant speed on busy sections of motorway, overall journey times are normally improved.

prashna.text: What's used to reduce traffic bunching on a motorway?

options.description: A. Variable speed limits
B. Lane closures
C. Contraflow systems
D. National speed limits

questions.explanation: You shouldn't normally stop on a motorway, but there may be occasions when you need to do so. If you're unfortunate enough to break down, make every effort to pull up on the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: When may you stop on a motorway?

options.description: A. When you're tired and need a rest
B. If your mobile phone rings
C. In an emergency or breakdown
D. If you have to read a map

questions.explanation: The national speed limit for a car or motorcycle on a motorway is 70 mph. Lower speed limits may be in force; for example, at roadworks. Variable speed limits also operate in some areas when the motorway is very busy. Cars or motorcycles towing trailers are subject to a lower speed limit.

prashna.text: Unless signs show otherwise, what's the national speed limit for a car or motorcycle on a motorway?

options.description: A. 60 mph
B. 50 mph
C. 80 mph
D. 70 mph

questions.explanation: Red flashing lights above all lanes mean you must stop and wait. You'll also see a red cross lit up. Don't change lanes, don't continue and don't pull onto the hard shoulder (unless in an emergency).

prashna.text: You're on a motorway and there are red flashing lights above every lane. What must you do?

options.description: A. Leave at the next exit
B. Pull onto the hard shoulder
C. Slow down and watch for further signals
D. Stop and wait

questions.explanation: A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it's closed as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies or breakdowns. On a smart motorway, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane at busy times. This will be shown by a mandatory speed limit on the gantry above the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: You're on a three-lane motorway. A red cross is showing above the hard shoulder and mandatory speed limits above all other lanes. What does this mean?

options.description: A. The hard shoulder is for emergency or breakdown use only
B. The hard shoulder can be used as a normal running lane
C. The hard shoulder has a speed limit of 50 mph
D. The hard shoulder can be used as a rest area if you feel tired

questions.explanation: You must obey mandatory speed-limit signs above motorway lanes, including the hard shoulder. In this case, you can use the hard shoulder as a running lane but you should look for any vehicles that may have broken down and may be blocking the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: On a three-lane motorway, what does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Use any lane except the hard shoulder
B. Use the hard shoulder only
C. Use all the lanes, including the hard shoulder
D. Use the three right-hand lanes only

questions.explanation: If you feel tired, stop at the nearest service area. If that's too far away, leave the motorway at the next exit and find a safe place to stop. You mustn't stop on the carriageway or hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency, when in a traffic queue, or when signalled to do so by a police officer, a traffic officer or traffic signals. Plan your journey so that you have regular rest stops.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a motorway and feel tired. Where should you stop to rest?

options.description: A. On the hard shoulder
B. On the central reservation
C. At the nearest service area
D. On a slip road

questions.explanation: Don’t forget that you’re towing a trailer. If you’re towing a small, light trailer, it won’t reduce your vehicle’s performance by very much. However, strong winds or buffeting from large vehicles might cause the trailer to snake from side to side. Be aware of your speed and don’t exceed the reduced speed limit imposed on vehicles towing trailers.

prashna.text: You're towing a trailer on a motorway. What's the speed limit for a car towing a trailer on this road?

options.description: A. 40 mph
B. 50 mph
C. 70 mph
D. 60 mph

questions.explanation: You should drive in the left-hand lane whenever possible. Only use the other lanes for overtaking or when directed to do so by signals. Using other lanes when the left-hand lane is empty can frustrate drivers behind you.

prashna.text: What should the left-hand lane of a motorway be used for?

options.description: A. Breakdowns and emergencies only
B. Slow vehicles only
C. Overtaking slower traffic in the other lanes
D. Normal driving

questions.explanation: Using your hazard warning lights, as well as your brake lights, will give following traffic an extra warning of the problem ahead. Only use them for long enough for your warning to be seen.

prashna.text: You're driving on a motorway and have to slow down quickly due to a hazard ahead. How can you warn drivers behind of the hazard?

options.description: A. Switch on your headlights
B. Switch on your hazard warning lights
C. Flash your headlights
D. Sound your horn

questions.explanation: Park as far to the left as you can and leave the vehicle by the nearside door. Don't attempt even simple repairs. Instead, walk to an emergency telephone on your side of the road and phone for help. While waiting for help to arrive, stay by your car, keeping well away from the carriageway and hard shoulder.

prashna.text: Your car gets a puncture while you're driving on the motorway. You get it onto the hard shoulder. What should you do?

options.description: A. Try to wave down another vehicle for help
B. Use an emergency telephone and call for help
C. Only change the wheel if you have a passenger to help you
D. Carefully change the wheel yourself

questions.explanation: It's illegal to reverse, cross the central reservation or drive against the traffic flow on a motorway. If you miss your exit, carry on until you reach the next one. Ask yourself why you missed your exit – if you think that your concentration is fading, take a break before completing your journey.

prashna.text: You're driving on a motorway. By mistake, you go past the exit that you wanted to take. What should you do?

options.description: A. Carry on to the next exit
B. Carefully reverse on the hard shoulder
C. Make a U-turn at a gap in the central reservation
D. Carefully reverse in the left-hand lane

questions.explanation: If you can’t get your vehicle onto the hard shoulder, use your hazard warning lights to warn others. Leave your vehicle only when you can safely get clear of the carriageway. Don't try to repair the vehicle or attempt to place any warning device on the carriageway.

prashna.text: Your vehicle has broken down on a motorway. You aren't able to stop on the hard shoulder. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stand behind your vehicle to warn others
B. Switch on your hazard warning lights
C. Attempt to repair your vehicle quickly
D. Stop following traffic and ask for help

questions.explanation: Before you start your journey, make sure that your vehicle can cope with the demands of high-speed driving. You should check a number of things, the main ones being oil, water and tyres. You also need to plan rest stops if you’re making a long journey.

prashna.text: Why is it particularly important to carry out a check on your vehicle before making a long motorway journey?

options.description: A. Motorway service stations don't deal with breakdowns
B. The road surface will wear down the tyres faster
C. You'll have to do more harsh braking on motorways
D. Continuous high speeds increase the risk of your vehicle breaking down

questions.explanation: If the vehicle in front shows its hazard warning lights, there may be an incident, stopped traffic or queuing traffic ahead. By keeping a safe distance from the vehicle in front, you're able to look beyond it and see any hazards well ahead.

prashna.text: You're driving on a motorway. The car in front shows its hazard warning lights for a short time. What does this tell you?

options.description: A. Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly
B. The driver wants you to overtake
C. There's a police speed check ahead
D. The other car is going to change lanes

questions.explanation: You’ll see the first advance direction sign one mile from a motorway exit. If you’re travelling at 60 mph in the right-hand lane, you’ll only have about 50 seconds before you reach the countdown markers. There'll be another sign at the half-mile point. Move to the left-hand lane in good time. Don’t cut across traffic at the last moment and don’t risk missing your exit.

prashna.text: You're driving on the motorway. Well before you reach your intended exit, where should you position your vehicle?

options.description: A. In the left-hand lane
B. On the hard shoulder
C. In any lane
D. In the middle lane

questions.explanation: You won't be able to drive unaccompanied until you've passed your practical driving test. When you’ve passed, it's a good idea to ask your instructor to take you for a lesson on the motorway. Alternatively, you could take part in the Pass Plus scheme. This has been created for new drivers and includes motorway driving. Ask your instructor for details.

prashna.text: What restrictions apply to new drivers holding a provisional driving licence?

options.description: A. They can't drive over 30 mph
B. They can't drive unaccompanied
C. They can't drive at night
D. They can't drive with more than one passenger

questions.explanation: You should use an emergency telephone when you break down on the motorway; only use your mobile if this isn't possible. The emergency services need to know your exact location so they can reach you as quickly as possible. Look for a number on the nearest marker post beside the hard shoulder. Give this number when you call the emergency services.

prashna.text: Your vehicle breaks down on the hard shoulder of a motorway. You need to use your mobile phone to call for help. What should you do?

options.description: A. Open the bonnet to help the emergency services know you've broken down
B. Stand at the rear of the vehicle while making the call
C. Phone a friend and ask them to come and collect you
D. Check your location from the marker posts on the left

questions.explanation: If you're towing a caravan or trailer, you mustn't use the right-hand lane of a motorway with three or more lanes except in certain specified circumstances, such as when lanes are closed.

prashna.text: You're towing a trailer along a three-lane motorway. When may you use the right-hand lane?

options.description: A. When large vehicles are in the left and centre lanes
B. When there's slow-moving traffic
C. When there are lane closures
D. When you can maintain a high speed

questions.explanation: When approaching a contraflow system, reduce speed in good time and obey all speed limits. You may be travelling in a narrower lane than normal, with no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic. Be aware that the hard shoulder may be used for traffic and the road ahead could be obstructed by slow-moving or broken-down vehicles.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. There's a contraflow system ahead. What would you expect to find?

options.description: A. Wider lanes than normal
B. Lower speed limits
C. Speed humps
D. Temporary traffic lights

questions.explanation: You should only stop on the hard shoulder in a genuine emergency. Don't stop there to have a rest or picnic, pick up hitchhikers, answer a mobile phone or check a map. If you miss your intended exit, carry on to the next. Never reverse along the hard shoulder.

prashna.text: When may you stop on the hard shoulder of a motorway?

options.description: A. If you miss the exit that you wanted
B. To pick up a hitchhiker
C. If you feel tired and need to rest
D. In an emergency

questions.explanation: This sign doesn’t tell you the speed limit in figures. You should know the speed limit for the type of road that you’re on and the type of vehicle that you're driving. Study your copy of The Highway Code.

prashna.text: What's the meaning of this sign?

options.description: A. No waiting on the carriageway
B. National speed limit applies
C. No entry for vehicles
D. Local speed limit applies

questions.explanation: Make sure that you know the speed limit for the road that you’re on. The speed limit on a dual carriageway or motorway is 70 mph for cars and motorcycles, unless signs indicate otherwise. The speed limits for different types of vehicle are listed in The Highway Code.
