prashna.text: What's the national speed limit for cars and motorcycles on a dual carriageway?

options.description: A. 30 mph
B. 60 mph
C. 50 mph
D. 70 mph

questions.explanation: There's a 30 mph speed limit where there are street lights unless signs show another limit.

prashna.text: There are no speed-limit signs on the road. How is a 30 mph limit indicated?

options.description: A. By double or single yellow lines
B. By street lighting
C. By hazard warning lines
D. By pedestrian islands

questions.explanation: The presence of street lights generally indicates that there's a 30 mph speed limit, unless signs tell you otherwise.

prashna.text: You see street lights but no speed-limit signs. What will the speed limit usually be?

options.description: A. 40 mph
B. 30 mph
C. 60 mph
D. 50 mph

questions.explanation: The red slash through the sign indicates that the restriction has ended. In this case, the restriction was a minimum speed limit of 30 mph.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. End of minimum speed
B. End of maximum speed
C. Maximum speed 30 mph
D. Minimum speed 30 mph

questions.explanation: Following a tractor can be frustrating, but never overtake if you’re unsure whether it’s safe. Ask yourself: 'Can I see far enough down the road to ensure that I can complete the manoeuvre safely?' It's better to be delayed for a minute or two than to take a chance that may cause a collision.

prashna.text: There's a tractor ahead. You want to overtake but you aren't sure whether it's safe. What should you do?

options.description: A. Follow another vehicle as it overtakes the tractor
B. Sound your horn to make the tractor pull over
C. Speed past, flashing your lights at oncoming traffic
D. Stay behind the tractor if you're in any doubt

questions.explanation: Long vehicles might have to take a slightly different position when approaching the roundabout or going around it. This is to stop the rear of the vehicle cutting in and mounting the kerb.

prashna.text: Which vehicle is most likely to take an unusual course at a roundabout?

options.description: A. Milk float
B. Estate car
C. Delivery van
D. Long lorry

questions.explanation: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You mustn't stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

prashna.text: When mustn't you stop on a clearway?

options.description: A. In the rush hour
B. When it's busy
C. During daylight hours
D. At any time

questions.explanation:
This sign indicates that there are waiting restrictions. It's normally accompanied by details of when the restrictions are in force.
Details of most signs in common use are shown in The Highway Code. For more comprehensive coverage, see Know Your Traffic Signs.

prashna.text: What's the meaning of this sign?

options.description: A. National speed limit
B. School crossing patrol
C. Waiting restrictions
D. No entry

questions.explanation: Red rear reflectors show up when headlights shine on them. These are useful when you're parked at night, but they'll only reflect if you park in the same direction as the traffic flow. Normally you should park on the left, but in a one-way street you may also park on the right-hand side.

prashna.text: When can you park on the right-hand side of a road at night?

options.description: A. When you're in a one-way street
B. When you have your sidelights on
C. When you're under a lamppost
D. When you're more than 10 metres (32 feet) from a junction

questions.explanation:
You should normally use the left-hand lane on any dual carriageway unless you're overtaking or turning right.
When overtaking on a dual carriageway, look for vehicles ahead that are turning right. They may be slowing or stopped. You need to see them in good time so that you can take appropriate action.

prashna.text: On a three-lane dual carriageway, what can the right-hand lane be used for?

options.description: A. Overtaking only, never turning right
B. Fast-moving traffic only
C. Turning right only, never overtaking
D. Overtaking or turning right

questions.explanation: There are times when road markings are obscured by queuing traffic, or you're unsure which lane to use. If, at the last moment, you find you're in the wrong lane, don’t cut across or bully other drivers to let you in. Follow the lane you’re in and find somewhere safe to turn around and rejoin your route.

prashna.text: You're approaching a busy junction. What should you do when, at the last moment, you realise you're in the wrong lane?

options.description: A. Use clear arm signals to cut across
B. Force your way across
C. Continue in that lane
D. Stop until the area has cleared

questions.explanation: You can overtake other traffic on either side when travelling in a one-way street. Make full use of your mirrors and ensure it’s clear all around before you attempt to overtake. Look for signs and road markings, and use the most suitable lane for your destination.

prashna.text: Where may you overtake on a one-way street?

options.description: A. On either the right or the left
B. Only on the left-hand side
C. Only on the right-hand side
D. Overtaking isn't allowed

questions.explanation: When going straight ahead at a roundabout, don’t signal as you approach it. Indicate left just after passing the exit before the one you wish to take.

prashna.text: How should you signal when going straight ahead at a roundabout?

options.description: A. Indicate right when approaching the roundabout
B. Don't indicate at any time
C. Indicate left when approaching the roundabout
D. Indicate left before leaving the roundabout

questions.explanation:
A long vehicle may have to straddle lanes either on or approaching a roundabout so that the rear wheels don’t hit the kerb.
If you’re following a long vehicle, stay well back and give it plenty of room.

prashna.text: Which vehicle might have to take a different course from normal at roundabouts?

options.description: A. Long vehicle
B. Sports car
C. Estate car
D. Van

questions.explanation: Yellow box junctions are marked on the road to prevent the road becoming blocked. Don’t enter the box unless your exit road is clear. You may wait in the box if you want to turn right and your exit road is clear but oncoming traffic or other vehicles waiting to turn right are preventing you from making the turn.

prashna.text: On which occasion may you enter a box junction?

options.description: A. When traffic signs direct you
B. When there are fewer than two vehicles ahead
C. When your exit road is clear
D. When signalled by another road user

questions.explanation: The purpose of yellow box markings is to keep junctions clear of queuing traffic. You may only wait in the marked area when you’re turning right and your exit lane is clear but you can’t complete the turn because of oncoming traffic or other traffic waiting to turning right.

prashna.text: When may you stop and wait in a box junction?

options.description: A. When oncoming traffic prevents you from turning right
B. When you're in a queue of traffic turning left
C. When you're on a roundabout
D. When you're in a queue of traffic going ahead

questions.explanation: You must obey signals to stop given by police and traffic officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrols. Failure to do so is an offence and could lead to prosecution.

prashna.text: Which person's signal to stop must you obey?

options.description: A. A pedestrian
B. A bus driver
C. A motorcyclist
D. A police officer

questions.explanation: By standing on the pavement, the pedestrian is showing an intention to cross. By looking well ahead, you'll give yourself time to see the pedestrian, check your mirrors and respond safely.

prashna.text: You see a pedestrian waiting at a zebra crossing. What should you normally do?

options.description: A. Stop to let them cross and wait patiently
B. Go on quickly before they step onto the crossing
C. Ignore them as they're still on the pavement
D. Stop before you reach the zigzag lines and let them cross

questions.explanation: Toucan crossings are similar to pelican crossings but there's no flashing amber phase. Cyclists share the crossing with pedestrians and are allowed to cycle across when the green cycle symbol is shown.

prashna.text: Who can use a toucan crossing?

options.description: A. Trams and trains
B. Buses and lorries
C. Cyclists and pedestrians
D. Cars and motorcycles

questions.explanation: This light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side in their own time, without being rushed. Don’t rev your engine or start to move off while they’re still crossing.

prashna.text: You’re waiting at a pelican crossing. What does it mean when the red light changes to flashing amber?

options.description: A. Wait for the green light before moving off
B. Move off immediately without any hesitation
C. Get ready and go when the continuous amber light shows
D. Wait for pedestrians on the crossing to clear

questions.explanation: You mustn't park or stop on a road marked with double white lines (even where one of the lines is broken) except to pick up or set down passengers.

prashna.text: When can you park on the left opposite these road markings?

options.description: A. During daylight hours only
B. To pick up or set down passengers
C. When there are no yellow lines
D. If the line nearest to you is broken

questions.explanation: When turning right at a crossroads where oncoming traffic is also turning right, it’s generally safer to turn behind the approaching vehicle. This allows you a clear view of approaching traffic and is called ‘turning offside to offside’. However, some junctions, usually controlled by traffic-light filters - are marked for vehicles to turn nearside to nearside.

prashna.text: You're turning right at a crossroads. An oncoming driver is also turning right. What's the advantage of turning behind the oncoming vehicle?

options.description: A. You'll have more time to turn
B. You'll use less fuel because you can stay in a higher gear
C. You'll have a clearer view of any approaching traffic
D. You'll be able to turn without stopping

questions.explanation:
Travel slowly and carefully near parked vehicles. Beware of
• vehicles pulling out, especially bicycles and motorcycles
• pedestrians, especially children, who may run out from between cars
• drivers opening their doors.

prashna.text: You're travelling along a street with parked vehicles on the left-hand side. Why should you keep your speed down?

options.description: A. Children may run out from between the vehicles
B. There may be delivery lorries on the street
C. So that oncoming traffic can see you more clearly
D. You may set off car alarms

questions.explanation: Take care if you have to pass a parked vehicle on your side of the road. Give way to oncoming traffic if there isn’t enough room for you both to continue safely.

prashna.text: What should you do when you meet an obstruction on your side of the road?

options.description: A. Accelerate to get past first
B. Carry on, as you have priority
C. Wave oncoming vehicles through
D. Give way to oncoming traffic

questions.explanation: Normally you should travel in the left-hand lane and only use the right-hand lane for overtaking or turning right. Move back into the left lane as soon as it’s safe but don’t cut in across the path of the vehicle you’ve just passed.

prashna.text: You're on a two-lane dual carriageway. Why would you use the right-hand lane?

options.description: A. For normal progress
B. To keep driving at a constant high speed
C. When staying at the minimum allowed speed
D. To overtake slower traffic

questions.explanation: Practise good observation in all directions before you emerge or make a turn. Proceed only when you’re sure it’s safe to do so.

prashna.text: Who has priority at an unmarked crossroads?

options.description: A. The larger vehicle
B. The smaller vehicle
C. The faster vehicle
D. No-one has priority

questions.explanation: Don’t park within 10 metres (32 feet) of a junction (unless in an authorised parking place). This is to allow drivers emerging from, or turning into, the junction a clear view of the road they're joining. It also allows them to see hazards such as pedestrians or cyclists at the junction.

prashna.text: What's the nearest you may park to a junction?

options.description: A. 20 metres (66 feet)
B. 15 metres (49 feet)
C. 12 metres (39 feet)
D. 10 metres (32 feet)

questions.explanation: It may be tempting to park where you shouldn’t while you run a quick errand. Careless parking is a selfish act and could endanger other road users. It’s important not to park at or near a bus stop, as this could inconvenience passengers and may put them at risk as they get on or off the bus.

prashna.text: Where shouldn't you park?

options.description: A. Within 20 metres (65 feet) of a junction
B. Where there's no pavement
C. On a road with a 40 mph speed limit
D. At or near a bus stop

questions.explanation: If the lights at a level crossing keep flashing after a train has passed, you should continue to wait, because another train might be coming. Time seems to pass slowly when you’re held up in a queue. Be patient and wait until the lights stop flashing.

prashna.text: You're waiting at a level crossing. A train passes but the lights keep flashing. What must you do?

options.description: A. Carry on waiting
B. Phone the signal operator
C. Park and investigate
D. Edge over the stop line and look for trains

questions.explanation: The blue-and-red circular sign on its own means that waiting restrictions are in force. This sign shows that you're leaving the controlled zone and waiting restrictions no longer apply.

prashna.text: What does this sign tell you?

options.description: A. No-waiting zone ends
B. No through road
C. Free-parking zone ends
D. End of traffic-calming zone

questions.explanation: Where there are extra hazards, such as at roadworks, it’s often necessary to slow traffic down by imposing a lower speed limit. These speed limits aren’t advisory; they must be obeyed.

prashna.text: What must you do when entering roadworks where a temporary speed limit is displayed?

options.description: A. Obey the speed limit
B. Use your own judgment; the limit is only advisory
C. Obey the limit, but only during rush hour
D. Ignore the displayed limit

questions.explanation: You may be difficult to see when you’re travelling at night, even on a well-lit road. If you use dipped headlights rather than sidelights, other road users should be able to see you more easily.

prashna.text: You're on a well-lit road at night, in a built-up area. How will using dipped headlights help?

options.description: A. You can switch to main beam quickly
B. You can see further along the road
C. You can be easily seen by others
D. You can go at a much faster speed

questions.explanation: When the central reservation is narrow, you should treat a dual carriageway as one road. Wait until the road is clear in both directions before emerging to turn right. If you try to treat it as two separate roads and wait in the middle, you're likely to cause an obstruction and possibly a collision.

prashna.text: The dual carriageway you're turning right onto has a very narrow central reservation. What should you do?

options.description: A. Wait until the road is clear in both directions
B. Stop in the first lane so that other vehicles give way
C. Proceed to the central reservation and wait
D. Emerge slightly to show your intentions

questions.explanation: Exceeding the speed limit is dangerous and can result in you receiving penalty points on your licence. It isn’t worth it. You should know the speed limit for the road that you’re on by observing the road signs. Different speed limits apply if you're towing a trailer.

prashna.text: What's the national speed limit on a single carriageway road for cars and motorcycles?

options.description: A. 60 mph
B. 70 mph
C. 50 mph
D. 30 mph

questions.explanation: You must use parking lights when parking at night on a road or in a lay-by on a road with a speed limit greater than 30 mph. You must also park in the direction of the traffic flow and not close to a junction.

prashna.text: You park at night on a road with a 40 mph speed limit. What should you do?

options.description: A. Park with dipped headlights on
B. Park with parking lights on
C. Park facing the traffic
D. Park near a street light

questions.explanation: If there's a bend just before a level crossing, you may not be able to see the level-crossing barriers or waiting traffic. These signs give you an early warning that you may find these hazards just around the bend.

prashna.text: Where will you see these red and white markers?

options.description: A. Approaching the end of a motorway
B. Approaching the end of a dual carriageway
C. Approaching a concealed level crossing
D. Approaching a concealed speed-limit sign

questions.explanation: You’ll find traffic officers on England’s motorways. They work in partnership with the police, helping to keep traffic moving and helping to make your journey as safe as possible. It's an offence not to comply with the directions given by a traffic officer.

prashna.text: You're travelling on a motorway in England. You must stop when signalled to do so by which of these?

options.description: A. A driver who has broken down
B. A traffic officer
C. Flashing amber lights above your lane
D. Pedestrians on the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: To go straight ahead at a roundabout, you should normally approach in the left-hand lane, but check the road markings. At some roundabouts, the left lane on approach is marked ‘left turn only’, so make sure you use the correct lane to go ahead. You won't normally need to signal as you approach, but signal before you leave the roundabout, as other road users need to know your intentions.

prashna.text: You're going straight ahead at a roundabout. How should you signal?

options.description: A. Signal right on the approach and then left to leave the roundabout
B. Signal right on the approach to the roundabout and keep the signal on
C. Signal left after you leave the roundabout and enter the new road
D. Signal left just after you pass the exit before the one you're going to take

questions.explanation: It's illegal to drive on or over a footpath, except to gain access to a property. If you need to cross a pavement, give priority to pedestrians.

prashna.text: When may you drive over a footpath?

options.description: A. If there are no pedestrians nearby
B. When the pavement is very wide
C. To overtake slow-moving traffic
D. To get onto a property

questions.explanation: When you're towing a trailer, a reduced speed limit also applies on dual carriageways and motorways. These lower speed limits apply to vehicles pulling all sorts of trailers, including caravans and horse boxes.

prashna.text: A single carriageway road has this sign. What's the maximum permitted speed for a car towing a trailer?

options.description: A. 50 mph
B. 40 mph
C. 60 mph
D. 30 mph

questions.explanation: The speed limit for cars towing caravans or trailers on dual carriageways or motorways is 60 mph. Due to the increased weight and size of the combination, you should plan further ahead. Take care in windy weather, as a strong side wind can make a caravan or large trailer unstable.

prashna.text: What's the speed limit for a car towing a small caravan along a dual carriageway?

options.description: A. 50 mph
B. 40 mph
C. 60 mph
D. 70 mph

questions.explanation: Parking restrictions apply in a variety of places and situations. Make sure you know the rules and understand where and when restrictions apply. Controlled parking areas will be indicated by signs and road markings. Parking in the wrong place could cause an obstruction and danger to other traffic. It can also result in a fine.

prashna.text: You want to park and you see this sign. What should you do on the days and times shown?

options.description: A. Park in a bay and not pay
B. Park in a bay and pay
C. Park on yellow lines and pay
D. Park on yellow lines and not pay

questions.explanation: Leave the lane free for cyclists. At other times, when the lane isn't in operation, you should still be aware that there may be cyclists about. Give them plenty of room as you pass and allow for their movement from side to side, especially in windy weather or on a bumpy road.

prashna.text: A cycle lane, marked by a solid white line, is in operation. What does this mean for car drivers?

options.description: A. You mustn't drive in that lane
B. The lane may be used when necessary
C. You may drive in the lane at any time
D. The lane may be used for parking your car

questions.explanation: Your road position can help other road users to anticipate your actions. Keep to the left as you approach a left turn and don't swing out into the centre of the road in order to make the turn easier. This could endanger oncoming traffic and may cause other road users to misunderstand your intentions.

prashna.text: You intend to turn left from a main road into a minor road. What should you do as you approach it?

options.description: A. Keep in the middle of the road
B. Swing out to the right just before turning
C. Keep just left of the middle of the road
D. Keep well to the left of the road

questions.explanation: At a level crossing, flashing red lights mean you must stop. If the train passes but the lights keep flashing, wait. Another train may be coming.

prashna.text: You're waiting at a level crossing. The red warning lights continue to flash after a train has passed by. What should you do?

options.description: A. Get out and investigate
B. Continue to wait
C. Telephone the signal operator
D. Drive across carefully

questions.explanation: Keep going; don’t stop on the crossing. If the amber warning lights come on as you’re approaching the crossing, you must stop unless it's unsafe to do so. Red flashing lights together with an audible signal mean you must stop.

prashna.text: You're driving over a level crossing. The warning lights come on and a bell rings. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stop and reverse back to clear the crossing
B. Stop immediately and use your hazard warning lights
C. Get everyone out of the vehicle immediately
D. Keep going and clear the crossing

questions.explanation: Don’t turn around in a busy street or reverse from a side road into a main road. Find a quiet side road and choose a place where you won’t obstruct an entrance or exit. Look out for pedestrians and cyclists as well as other traffic.

prashna.text: You're on a busy main road and find that you're travelling in the wrong direction. What should you do?

options.description: A. Turn into a side road on the right and reverse into the main road
B. Make a U-turn in the main road
C. Make a ‘three-point’ turn in the main road
D. Turn around in a side road

questions.explanation: You may remove your seat belt while you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing. However, you must remember to put it back on again before you resume driving.

prashna.text: During which manoeuvre may you remove your seat belt?

options.description: A. Emergency stop
B. Driving slowly
C. Reversing
D. Hill start

questions.explanation: You mustn't reverse further than is necessary. You may decide to turn your vehicle around by reversing into an opening or side road. When you reverse, always look all around you, and watch for pedestrians. Don’t reverse from a side road into a main road.

prashna.text: Over what distance are you allowed to reverse?

options.description: A. The length of a residential street
B. No more than a car’s length
C. As far as it takes to reverse around a corner
D. No further than is necessary

questions.explanation: A small child could be hidden directly behind you, so, if you can’t see all around your vehicle, get out and have a look. You could also ask someone reliable outside the vehicle to guide you.

prashna.text: What should you do when you're unsure whether it's safe to reverse your vehicle?

options.description: A. Rev your engine
B. Get out and check
C. Sound your horn
D. Reverse slowly

questions.explanation: Don’t reverse into a main road from a side road. The main road is likely to be busy and the traffic on it moving quickly.

prashna.text: When may you reverse from a side road into a main road?

options.description: A. Only if both roads are clear of traffic
B. Not at any time
C. Only if the main road is clear of traffic
D. At any time

questions.explanation: You can wait in the box junction as long as your exit is clear. At some point there'll be a gap in the oncoming traffic, or the traffic lights will change, allowing you to proceed.

prashna.text: You want to turn right at a box junction. There's oncoming traffic. What should you do?

options.description: A. Drive slowly into the box junction when signalled by oncoming traffic
B. Drive on; you can't turn right at a box junction
C. Wait before the junction until it's clear of all traffic
D. Wait in the box junction if your exit is clear

questions.explanation: Always check in all directions before reversing into a side road. Keep a good lookout throughout the manoeuvre. Act on what you see and wait if necessary.

prashna.text: You're reversing your vehicle into a side road. When would the greatest hazard to passing traffic occur?

options.description: A. When the front of your vehicle swings out
B. After you’ve completed the manoeuvre
C. After you’ve entered the side road
D. Just before you actually begin to manoeuvre

questions.explanation: If you have a garage, use it. Your vehicle is less likely to be a victim of car crime if it’s in a garage. Also, in winter, the windows will be kept free from ice and snow.

prashna.text: Where's the safest place to park your vehicle at night?

options.description: A. On a busy road
B. Near a red route
C. In a garage
D. In a quiet car park

questions.explanation: Urban clearways have their times of operation clearly signed. You may stop only for as long as is reasonable to pick up or set down passengers. You should ensure that you're not causing an obstruction for other traffic.

prashna.text: When may you stop on an urban clearway?

options.description: A. To load or unload goods
B. To use a mobile telephone
C. To set down and pick up passengers
D. To ask for directions

questions.explanation: It's illegal to park in a space reserved for disabled users unless you're permitted to do so. These spaces are provided for people with limited mobility, who may need extra space to get in and out of their vehicle.

prashna.text: You're looking for somewhere to park your vehicle. The area is full except for spaces marked ‘disabled use’. What can you do?

options.description: A. You can use these spaces when elsewhere is full
B. You can't park there, unless you're permitted to do so
C. You can park in one of these spaces if you stay with your vehicle
D. You can use one of the spaces as long as one is kept free

questions.explanation: Pull into the nearest passing place on the left if you meet another vehicle on a narrow road. If the nearest passing place is on the right, wait opposite it.

prashna.text: You're on a road that's only wide enough for one vehicle. A car is coming towards you. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pull into a passing place if your vehicle is wider
B. Force the other driver to reverse
C. Pull into a passing place on your left
D. Pull into a passing place on your right

questions.explanation: On full beam, your lights could dazzle the driver in front. Dip your lights as soon as the driver passes you and drop back so that the dipped beam falls short of the other vehicle.

prashna.text: You're driving at night with your headlights on full beam. A vehicle is overtaking you. When should you dip your lights?

options.description: A. Before the vehicle starts to pass you
B. As soon as the vehicle passes you
C. Only if the other driver dips their headlights
D. Some time after the vehicle has passed you

questions.explanation: Some bus lanes operate only during peak hours and other vehicles may use them outside these hours. Make sure you check the sign for the hours of operation before driving in a bus lane.

prashna.text: When may you drive a motor car in this bus lane?

options.description: A. To overtake slow-moving traffic
B. Outside its hours of operation
C. You may not use it at any time
D. To get to the front of a traffic queue

questions.explanation: Your brake lights will give an indication to traffic behind that you’re slowing down. Good anticipation will allow you time to check your mirrors before slowing.

prashna.text: Other than direction indicators, how can you give signals to other road users?

options.description: A. By using brake lights
B. By using interior lights
C. By using sidelights
D. By using fog lights

questions.explanation: Make sure you carry out the manoeuvre without causing a hazard to other vehicles. Choose a place to turn that's safe and convenient for you and for other road users.

prashna.text: You're parked in a busy high street. What's the safest way to turn your vehicle around so you can go the opposite way?

options.description: A. Get someone to stop the traffic
B. Do a U-turn
C. Drive into a side road and reverse into the main road
D. Find a quiet side road to turn around in

questions.explanation: Whenever possible, park in an area that will be well lit at night.

prashna.text: To help keep your vehicle secure at night, where should you park?

options.description: A. In a quiet road
B. In a well-lit area
C. Near a police station
D. On a red route

questions.explanation:
Keep a lookout for traffic signs. If you’re directed to change lanes, do so in good time. Don’t
• push your way into traffic in another lane
• try to gain advantage by delaying changing lanes.

prashna.text: You're driving in the right-hand lane of a dual carriageway. You see signs showing that the right-hand lane is closed 800 yards ahead. What should you do?

options.description: A. Keep in that lane until you reach the queue
B. Wait and see which lane is moving faster
C. Move to the left immediately
D. Move to the left in good time

questions.explanation: Cycle lanes are marked with either a solid or a broken white line. If the line is solid, you should check the times of operation shown on the signs, and not drive or park in the lane during those times. If the line is broken, you shouldn't drive or park in the lane unless it's unavoidable.

prashna.text: You're driving on a road that has a cycle lane. The lane is marked by a broken white line. What does this mean?

options.description: A. You shouldn't drive in the lane unless it's unavoidable
B. The lane must be used by motorcyclists in heavy traffic
C. There's a reduced speed limit for motor vehicles using the lane
D. Cyclists can travel in both directions in that lane

questions.explanation: Don’t park in a space reserved for disabled people unless you or your passenger are a disabled badge holder. The badge must be displayed in your vehicle, in the bottom left-hand corner of the windscreen.

prashna.text: What must you have to park in a disabled space?

options.description: A. An adapted vehicle
B. A Blue Badge
C. A wheelchair
D. An advanced driver certificate

questions.explanation:
You must stop your vehicle when signalled to do so by a
• police or traffic officer
• traffic warden
• school crossing patrol
• red traffic light.
You must also stop if you're involved in an incident which causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property.

prashna.text: When must you stop your vehicle?

options.description: A. Before merging onto a motorway
B. If you’re involved in an incident that causes damage or injury
C. At a junction where there are ‘give way’ lines
D. At the end of a one-way street

questions.explanation: There are three basic types of traffic sign: those that warn, those that inform and those that give orders. Generally, triangular signs warn, rectangular signs give information or directions and circular signs give orders. An exception is the eight-sided ‘stop’ sign.

prashna.text: How can you identify traffic signs that give orders?

options.description: A. They're square with a brown border
B. They're rectangular with a yellow border
C. They're triangular with a blue border
D. They're circular with a red border

questions.explanation: Road signs in the shape of a circle give orders. Those with a red circle are mostly prohibitive. The ‘stop’ sign is octagonal to give it greater prominence. Signs giving orders must always be obeyed.

prashna.text: Traffic signs giving orders are generally which shape?

questions.explanation: Signs in the shape of a circle give orders. A sign with a red circle means that you aren’t allowed to do something. Study Know Your Traffic Signs to ensure that you understand what the different traffic signs mean.

prashna.text: Which type of sign tells you not to do something?

questions.explanation:
If you’re in a place where there are likely to be pedestrians (for example, outside a school, near a park, in a residential area or in a shopping area), you should be cautious and keep your speed down.
Many local authorities have taken steps to slow traffic down by creating traffic-calming measures such as speed humps. They're there for a reason; slow down.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. ‘20 cars only’ parking zone
B. Maximum speed limit with traffic calming
C. Minimum speed limit with traffic calming
D. Only 20 cars allowed at any one time

questions.explanation: You'll generally see this sign at the approach to a pedestrian-only zone.

prashna.text: Which sign means no motor vehicles are allowed?

questions.explanation: Where you see this sign, the 20 mph restriction ends. Check all around for possible hazards and only increase your speed if it’s safe to do so.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Minimum speed limit 30 mph
B. New speed limit 20 mph
C. End of 20 mph zone
D. No vehicles over 30 tonnes

questions.explanation: A sign will indicate which types of vehicles are prohibited from certain roads. Make sure that you know which signs apply to the vehicle you’re using.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Cars and motorcycles only
B. No motor vehicles
C. No overtaking
D. Clearway (no stopping)

questions.explanation: ‘No entry’ signs are used in places such as one-way streets to prevent vehicles driving against the traffic. To ignore one would be dangerous, both for yourself and for other road users, as well as being against the law.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No road markings
B. No entry
C. No through road
D. No parking

questions.explanation: The ‘no right turn’ sign may be used to warn road users that there's a ‘no entry’ prohibition on a road to the right ahead.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No right turn
B. Bend to the right
C. Road on the right closed
D. No traffic from the right

questions.explanation: Look for and obey traffic signs. Disobeying or not seeing a sign could be dangerous. It may also be an offence for which you could be prosecuted.

prashna.text: Which sign means ‘no entry’?

questions.explanation: Avoid blocking tram routes. Trams are fixed on their route and can’t manoeuvre around other vehicles or pedestrians. Modern trams travel quickly and are quiet, so you might not hear them approaching.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Route for trams only
B. Parking for buses only
C. Route for buses only
D. Parking for trams only

questions.explanation: The triangular shapes above and below the dimensions indicate a height restriction that applies to the road ahead.

prashna.text: Which type of vehicle does this sign apply to?

options.description: A. Wide vehicles
B. Heavy vehicles
C. Long vehicles
D. High vehicles

questions.explanation: This sign is used to enable pedestrians to walk free from traffic. It’s often found in shopping areas.

prashna.text: Which sign means no motor vehicles allowed?

questions.explanation: Road signs that prohibit overtaking are placed in locations where passing the vehicle in front is dangerous. If you see this sign, don’t attempt to overtake. The sign is there for a reason; you must obey it.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. You have priority
B. No motor vehicles
C. Two-way traffic
D. No overtaking

questions.explanation: There'll be a plate or additional sign to tell you when the restrictions apply.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Waiting restrictions apply
B. Waiting permitted
C. Clearway (no stopping)
D. National speed limit applies

questions.explanation: Even though you've left the restricted area, make sure that you park where you won’t endanger other road users or cause an obstruction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. End of clearway
B. End of cycle route
C. End of restricted speed area
D. End of restricted parking area

questions.explanation: Stopping where this clearway restriction applies is likely to cause congestion. Allow the traffic to flow by obeying the signs.

prashna.text: Which sign means ‘no stopping’?

questions.explanation: Clearways are stretches of road where you aren’t allowed to stop unless it’s an emergency. Stopping where these restrictions apply may be dangerous and is likely to cause an obstruction. Restrictions might apply for several miles and this may be indicated on the sign.

prashna.text: You see this sign ahead. What does it mean?

options.description: A. No entry
B. Waiting restrictions apply
C. No stopping
D. National speed limit applies

questions.explanation: If you intend to stop and rest, this sign allows you time to reduce speed and pull over safely.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Distance to public house ahead
B. Distance to public telephone ahead
C. Distance to parking place ahead
D. Distance to passing place ahead

questions.explanation: In order to keep roads free from parked cars, there are some areas where you’re allowed to park on the verge. Only do this where you see the sign. Parking on verges or footways anywhere else could lead to a fine.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Vehicles may park fully on the verge or footway
B. Vehicles may park on the right-hand side of the road only
C. Vehicles may park on the left-hand side of the road only
D. Vehicles may not park on the verge or footway

questions.explanation:
Priority signs are normally shown where the road is narrow and there isn’t enough room for two vehicles to pass. Examples are narrow bridges, roadworks and where there’s a width restriction.
Make sure you know who has priority; don’t force your way through. Show courtesy and consideration to other road users.

prashna.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

options.description: A. Give priority to oncoming traffic
B. Two-way traffic
C. One-way traffic only
D. No overtaking allowed

questions.explanation: Don’t force your way through. Show courtesy and consideration to other road users. Although you have priority, make sure oncoming traffic is going to give way before you continue.

prashna.text: What's the meaning of this traffic sign?

options.description: A. End of two-way road
B. Bus lane ahead
C. You have priority over vehicles coming towards you
D. Give priority to vehicles coming towards you

questions.explanation: To make it easy to recognise, the ‘stop’ sign is the only sign of this shape. You must stop and take effective observation before proceeding.

prashna.text: What shape is a 'stop' sign at a junction?

questions.explanation: The 'stop' sign is the only road sign that's octagonal. This is so that it can be recognised and obeyed even if it's obscured (for example, by snow).

prashna.text: At a junction, you see this sign partly covered by snow. What does it mean?

options.description: A. Turn right
B. Crossroads
C. Give way
D. Stop

questions.explanation: This sign is shown where slow-moving vehicles would impede the flow of traffic; for example, in tunnels. However, if you need to slow down or even stop to avoid an incident or potential collision, you should do so.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Service area 30 miles ahead
B. Maximum speed 30 mph
C. Lay-by 30 miles ahead
D. Minimum speed 30 mph

questions.explanation: These signs are often seen in one-way streets that have more than one lane. When you see this sign, use the route that’s the most convenient and doesn’t require a late change of direction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Turn off at the next available junction
B. Give way to oncoming vehicles
C. Pass either side to get to the same destination
D. Approaching traffic passes you on both sides

questions.explanation: Take extra care when you encounter trams. Look out for road markings and signs that alert you to them. Modern trams are very quiet and you may not hear them approaching.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Route for buses
B. Route for trams
C. Give way to trams
D. Give way to buses

questions.explanation: Signs with blue circles mostly give a positive instruction. These are often found in urban areas and include signs for mini-roundabouts and directional arrows.

prashna.text: What does a circular traffic sign with a blue background do?

options.description: A. Give directions to a car park
B. Give an instruction
C. Give warning of a motorway ahead
D. Give motorway information

questions.explanation: The traffic permitted to use a contraflow lane travels in the opposite direction to traffic in the other lanes on the road.

prashna.text: Where would you see a contraflow bus and cycle lane?

options.description: A. On a one-way street
B. On an urban motorway
C. On a dual carriageway
D. On a roundabout

questions.explanation: There will also be markings on the road surface to indicate the bus lane. You mustn't use this lane for parking or overtaking.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. With-flow bus lane
B. Contraflow bus lane
C. Give way to buses
D. Bus station on the right

questions.explanation: Signs with a brown background give directions to places of interest. They're often seen on a motorway, directing you along the easiest route to the attraction.

prashna.text: What does a sign with a brown background show?

options.description: A. Minor roads
B. Tourist directions
C. Motorway routes
D. Primary roads

questions.explanation: These signs indicate places of interest and are designed to guide you by the easiest route. They're particularly useful when you're unfamiliar with the area.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Level crossing
B. Tourist attraction
C. Beware of trains
D. Beware of trams

questions.explanation: This type of sign warns you of hazards ahead. Make sure you look at each sign that you pass on the road, so that you don't miss any vital instructions or information.

prashna.text: What are triangular signs for?

options.description: A. To give warnings
B. To give directions
C. To give information
D. To give orders

questions.explanation: This type of sign warns you of hazards ahead. Make sure you look at each sign and road marking that you pass, so that you don't miss any vital instructions or information. This particular sign shows there's a T-junction with priority over vehicles from the right.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No through road
B. Turn left ahead
C. T-junction
D. Give way

questions.explanation: It will take up to ten times longer to stop when it’s icy. Where there's a risk of icy conditions, you need to be aware of this and take extra care. If you think the road may be icy, don’t brake or steer harshly, as your tyres could lose their grip on the road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Risk of ice
B. Six roads converge
C. Place of historical interest
D. Multi-exit roundabout

questions.explanation: The priority through the junction is shown by the broader line. You need to be aware of the hazard posed by traffic crossing or pulling out onto a major road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Level crossing without gate
B. Crossroads
C. Ahead only
D. Level crossing with gate

questions.explanation: As you approach a roundabout, look well ahead and check all signs. Decide which exit you wish to take and move into the correct position as you approach the roundabout, signalling as required.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Ring road
B. No vehicles
C. Mini-roundabout
D. Roundabout

questions.explanation: Warning signs are there to make you aware of potential hazards on the road ahead. Take note of the signs so you're prepared and can take whatever action is necessary.

prashna.text: What information would be shown in a triangular road sign?

options.description: A. Keep left
B. Minimum speed
C. Ahead only
D. Road narrows

questions.explanation: Where there’s a cycle route ahead, a sign will show a bicycle in a red warning triangle. Watch out for children on bicycles and cyclists rejoining the main road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Cycles aren't allowed
B. Cycle in single file
C. Cyclists must dismount
D. Cycle route ahead

questions.explanation: When you pass pedestrians in the road, leave plenty of room. You might have to use the right-hand side of the road, so look well ahead, as well as in your mirrors, before pulling out. Take great care if a bend in the road obscures your view ahead.

prashna.text: Which sign means that pedestrians may be walking along the road?

questions.explanation: Triangular signs give you a warning of hazards ahead. They're there to give you time to prepare for the hazard; for example, by adjusting your speed.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means there's a double bend ahead?

questions.explanation: Obey the ‘give way’ signs. Trams are unable to steer around you if you misjudge when it's safe to enter the junction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Give way to trams
B. Give way to farm vehicles
C. Wait at the crossroads
D. Wait at the barriers

questions.explanation: These humps have been put in place to slow the traffic down. They’re usually found in residential areas. Slow down to an appropriate speed.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Hump bridge
B. Humps in the road
C. Soft verges
D. Entrance to tunnel

questions.explanation: If you’re overtaking, make sure you move back safely into the left-hand lane before you reach the end of the dual carriageway.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means the end of a dual carriageway?

questions.explanation: Don’t wait until the last moment before moving into the left-hand lane. Plan ahead and don’t rely on other traffic letting you in.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Tall bridge
B. End of dual carriageway
C. Road narrows
D. End of narrow bridge

questions.explanation: A warning sign with a picture of a windsock indicates that there may be strong side winds. This sign is often found on exposed roads.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Road noise
B. Adverse camber
C. Side winds
D. Airport

questions.explanation: This sign is there to alert you to the likelihood of danger ahead. It may be accompanied by a plate indicating the type of hazard. Be ready to reduce your speed and take avoiding action.

prashna.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

options.description: A. Tyres liable to punctures ahead
B. Slippery road ahead
C. Danger ahead
D. Service area ahead

questions.explanation:
You won’t be able to see any hazards that might be hidden in the dip. As well as oncoming traffic, the dip may conceal
• cyclists
• horse riders
• parked vehicles
• pedestrians
in the road.

prashna.text: You’re about to overtake. What should you do when you see this sign?

options.description: A. Hold back until you can see clearly ahead
B. Move to the right to get a better view
C. Overtake the other driver as quickly as possible
D. Switch your headlights on before overtaking

questions.explanation: Some crossings have gates but no attendant or signals. You should stop, look both ways, listen and make sure that no train is approaching. If there's a telephone, contact the signal operator to make sure it’s safe to cross.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Gated road ahead
B. Level crossing without gate or barrier
C. Level crossing with gate or barrier
D. Cattle grid ahead

questions.explanation: This sign tells you to beware of trams. If you don’t usually drive in a town where there are trams, remember to look out for them at junctions and look for tram rails, signs and signals.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Trams only
B. No trams ahead
C. Oncoming trams
D. Trams crossing ahead

questions.explanation: This sign gives you an early warning that the road ahead will slope downhill. Prepare to alter your speed and gear. Looking at the sign from left to right will show you whether the road slopes uphill or downhill.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Adverse camber
B. Steep hill upwards
C. Uneven road
D. Steep hill downwards

questions.explanation: This sign is found where a shallow stream crosses the road. Heavy rainfall could increase the flow of water. If the water looks too deep or the stream has spread over a large distance, stop and find another route.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Bridge over the road
B. Uneven road surface
C. Water across the road
D. Road ahead ends

questions.explanation: This sign shows you that you can’t get through to another route by turning left at the junction ahead.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No through road on the left
B. Turn left for ferry terminal
C. Turn left for parking area
D. No entry for traffic turning left

questions.explanation: You won't be able to find a through route to another road. Use this road only for access.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. T-junction
B. Toilet ahead
C. Telephone box ahead
D. No through road

questions.explanation: Ring roads are designed to relieve congestion in towns and city centres.

prashna.text: Which is the sign for a ring road?

questions.explanation: Yellow-and-black temporary signs may be used to inform you about roadworks or lane restrictions. Look well ahead. If you have to change lanes, do so in good time.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Right-hand lane for buses only
B. The right-hand lane ahead is narrow
C. Right-hand lane for turning right
D. The right-hand lane is closed

questions.explanation: If you use the right-hand lane in a contraflow system, you’ll be travelling with no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic. Observe speed limits and keep a good distance from the vehicle ahead.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Contraflow system
B. One-way street
C. Leave at the next exit
D. Change to the left lane

questions.explanation: Where there’s a long, steep, uphill gradient on a motorway, a crawler lane may be provided. This helps the traffic to flow by diverting the slower heavy vehicles into a dedicated lane on the left.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Lane for heavy and slow vehicles
B. Leave motorway at next exit
C. All lorries use the hard shoulder
D. Rest area for lorries

questions.explanation: Whatever light is showing, you should know which light is going to appear next and be able to take appropriate action. For example, when amber is showing on its own, you’ll know that red will appear next. This should give you ample time to anticipate and respond safely.

prashna.text: What does a red traffic light mean?

options.description: A. You must stop and wait behind the stop line
B. Proceed with care
C. Stop, if you're able to brake safely
D. You should stop unless turning left

questions.explanation: When the amber light is showing on its own, the red light will follow next. The amber light means stop, unless you've already crossed the stop line or you're so close to it that stopping may cause a collision.

prashna.text: At traffic lights, what does it mean when the amber light shows on its own?

options.description: A. Go if the way is clear
B. Go if no pedestrians are crossing
C. Prepare to go
D. Stop at the stop line

questions.explanation: As you approach the lights, look into the road you wish to take. Only proceed if your exit road is clear. If the road is blocked, hold back, even if you have to wait for the next green signal.

prashna.text: You're at a junction controlled by traffic lights. When shouldn't you proceed at green?

options.description: A. When pedestrians are waiting to cross
B. When you think the lights may be about to change
C. When you intend to turn right
D. When your exit from the junction is blocked

questions.explanation: At some junctions, there may be separate signals for different lanes. These are called ‘filter’ lights. They’re designed to help traffic flow at major junctions. Make sure that you’re in the correct lane and proceed if the way is clear and the green light shows for your lane.

prashna.text: You're in the left-hand lane at traffic lights, waiting to turn left. At which of these traffic lights mustn't you move on?

questions.explanation: You might see this sign where traffic lights are out of order. Proceed with caution, as nobody has priority at the junction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. New traffic lights ahead
B. Temporary traffic lights ahead
C. Amber signal out of order
D. Traffic lights out of order

questions.explanation: When traffic lights are out of order, you should treat the junction as an unmarked crossroads. Be cautious, as you may need to give way or stop. Look for traffic attempting to cross the junction, unaware that it doesn’t have priority.

prashna.text: When traffic lights are out of order, who has priority?

options.description: A. Nobody
B. Traffic turning left
C. Traffic going straight on
D. Traffic turning right

questions.explanation: These signals are found at level crossings, swing or lifting bridges, some airfields and emergency access sites. The flashing red lights mean stop whether or not the way seems to be clear.

prashna.text: These flashing red lights mean that you must stop. Where would you find them?

options.description: A. Zebra crossings
B. Motorway exits
C. Pelican crossings
D. Level crossings

questions.explanation: The approach to, and exit from, a pedestrian crossing is marked with zigzag lines. You mustn't park on them or overtake the leading vehicle when approaching the crossing. Parking here would block the view for pedestrians and approaching traffic.

prashna.text: What do these zigzag lines at pedestrian crossings mean?

options.description: A. Sounding horns isn't allowed
B. No parking at any time
C. Slow down to 20 mph
D. Parking allowed only for a short time

questions.explanation: You may cross the solid white line to pass a stationary vehicle or to pass a pedal cycle, horse or road maintenance vehicle if it's travelling at 10 mph or less. You may also cross the solid white line to enter a side road or access a property.

prashna.text: When may you cross a double solid white line in the middle of the road?

options.description: A. To pass a road maintenance vehicle travelling at 10 mph or less
B. To pass a vehicle that's towing a trailer
C. To pass a car signalling to turn left ahead
D. To pass traffic that's queuing back at a junction

questions.explanation: Road markings will warn you of a hazard ahead. A single broken line along the centre of the road, with long markings and short gaps, is a hazard warning line. Don’t cross it unless you can see that the road is clear well ahead.

prashna.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.description: A. Don't cross the line
B. You're approaching a hazard
C. No stopping allowed
D. No overtaking allowed

questions.explanation: Because the road has a dark colour, changes in level aren’t easily seen. White triangles painted on the road surface give you an indication of where there are road humps.

prashna.text: Where would you see this road marking?

options.description: A. On road humps
B. At traffic lights
C. At a box junction
D. Near a level crossing

questions.explanation: You need to know the difference between the normal centre line and a hazard warning line. If there's a hazard ahead, the markings are longer and the gaps shorter. This gives you advance warning of an unspecified hazard.

prashna.text: Which of these is a hazard warning line?

questions.explanation: If your view at a road junction is restricted, you must stop. There may also be a ‘stop’ sign. Don’t emerge until you’re sure no traffic is approaching. If you don't know, don't go.

prashna.text: At this junction, there's a 'stop' sign and a solid white line on the road surface. Why is there a 'stop' sign here?

options.description: A. Speed on the major road is derestricted
B. It's a busy junction
C. There are hazard warning lines in the centre of the road
D. Visibility along the major road is restricted

questions.explanation: Slow down as you approach the roundabout and check for traffic from the right. If you need to stop and give way, stay behind the broken line until it's safe to emerge onto the roundabout.

prashna.text: You see this line across the road at the entrance to a roundabout. What does it mean?

options.description: A. You have right of way
B. Give way to traffic from the right
C. Stop at the line
D. Traffic from the left has right of way

questions.explanation: You must obey signals given by the police. If a police officer in a patrol vehicle wants you to pull over, they'll indicate this without causing danger to you or other traffic.

prashna.text: How will a police officer in a patrol vehicle normally get you to stop?

options.description: A. Use the siren, overtake, cut in front and stop
B. Flash the headlights, indicate left and point to the left
C. Pull alongside you, use the siren and wave you to stop
D. Wait until you stop, then approach you

questions.explanation: When a police officer or traffic warden is directing traffic, you must obey them. They'll use the arm signals shown in The Highway Code. Learn what these signals mean and obey them.

prashna.text: You're approaching a junction where the traffic lights aren't working. What should you do when a police officer gives this signal?

options.description: A. Stop at the stop line
B. Continue ahead only
C. Turn left only
D. Turn right only

questions.explanation: There might be an occasion where another driver uses an arm signal. This may be because the vehicle’s indicators are obscured by other traffic. In order for such signals to be effective, all drivers should know their meaning. Be aware that the ‘left turn’ signal might look similar to the ‘slowing down’ signal.

prashna.text: The driver of the car in front is giving this arm signal. What does it mean?

options.description: A. The driver wishes to overtake
B. The driver is slowing down
C. The driver intends to turn right
D. The driver intends to turn left

questions.explanation: When driving on a motorway or slip road, you mustn't enter an area marked with chevrons and bordered by a solid white line for any reason, except in an emergency.

prashna.text: Where would you see these road markings?

options.description: A. On a single-track road
B. At a level crossing
C. On a motorway slip road
D. At a pedestrian crossing

questions.explanation:
On the motorway, signs sometimes show temporary warnings due to traffic or weather conditions. They may be used to indicate
• lane closures
• temporary speed limits
• weather warnings.

prashna.text: What does this motorway sign mean?

options.description: A. Leave the motorway at the next exit
B. Change to the lane on your left
C. Pull up on the hard shoulder
D. Change to the opposite carriageway

questions.explanation: Look out for signs above your lane or on the central reservation. These will give you important information or warnings about the road ahead. To allow for the high speed of motorway traffic, these signs may light up some distance from any hazard. Don’t ignore the signs just because the road looks clear to you.

prashna.text: What does this motorway sign mean?

options.description: A. Obstruction 50 metres (164 feet) ahead
B. Temporary minimum speed 50 mph
C. Temporary maximum speed 50 mph
D. No services for 50 miles

questions.explanation: You should change lanes as directed by the sign. Here, the right-hand lane is closed but the left-hand and centre lanes are available. Merging in turn is recommended when it’s safe and traffic is going slowly; for example, at roadworks or a road traffic incident. When vehicles are travelling at speed, this isn't advisable and you should move into the appropriate lane in good time.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Right-hand lane closed ahead
B. 11 tonne weight limit
C. Right-hand lane T-junction only
D. Through traffic to use left lane

questions.explanation: Before you set out on your journey, use a road map to plan your route. When you see an advance warning of your junction, make sure you get into the correct lane in plenty of time. Last-minute harsh braking and cutting across lanes at speed is extremely hazardous.

prashna.text: What does ‘25’ mean on this motorway sign?

options.description: A. The number of the next junction
B. The distance to the nearest town
C. The speed limit on the slip road
D. The route number of the road

questions.explanation: You should stay in the left-hand lane of a motorway unless you're overtaking another vehicle. The right-hand lane of a motorway is an overtaking lane; it isn't the ‘fast lane’. After overtaking, move back to the left when it's safe to do so.

prashna.text: How should the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway be used?

options.description: A. As a right-turn lane
B. As an acceleration lane
C. As a high-speed lane
D. As an overtaking lane

questions.explanation: At night or in poor visibility, reflective studs on the road help you to judge your position on the carriageway.

prashna.text: Where can you find reflective amber studs on a motorway?

options.description: A. Separating the slip road from the motorway
B. On the right-hand edge of the road
C. Separating the lanes
D. On the left-hand edge of the road

questions.explanation: Knowing the colours of the reflective studs on the road will help you judge your position, especially at night, in foggy conditions or when visibility is poor.

prashna.text: Where on a motorway would you find green reflective studs?

options.description: A. Between the carriageway and the central reservation
B. Separating driving lanes
C. At slip-road entrances and exits
D. Between the hard shoulder and the carriageway

questions.explanation: You’ll see this sign if the motorway is closed ahead. Pull into the left-hand lane as soon as it's safe to do so. Don’t wait until the last moment before you move across, because the lane may be busy and you'll have to rely on another driver making room for you.

prashna.text: What should you do when you see this sign as you travel along a motorway?

options.description: A. Turn left immediately
B. Leave the motorway at the next exit
C. Move onto the hard shoulder
D. Change lane

questions.explanation: When you leave the motorway, make sure that you check your speedometer. You may be going faster than you realise. Slow down and look for speed-limit signs.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No through road
B. End of bus lane
C. End of motorway
D. No motor vehicles

questions.explanation: You should know the speed limit for the road on which you're travelling and the vehicle that you're driving. The different speed limits are shown in The Highway Code.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means that the national speed limit applies?

questions.explanation: If you’re travelling on a dual carriageway that becomes a single carriageway road, reduce your speed gradually so that you aren’t exceeding the limit as you enter. There might not be a sign to remind you of the limit, so make sure you know the speed limits for different types of road and vehicle.

prashna.text: What's the maximum speed on a single carriageway road?

options.description: A. 50 mph
B. 40 mph
C. 70 mph
D. 60 mph

questions.explanation: Temporary restrictions on motorways are shown on signs that have flashing amber lights. At the end of the restriction, you'll see this sign without any flashing lights.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. End of restriction
B. Lane ends ahead
C. End of motorway
D. Free recovery ends

questions.explanation: When a diversion route has been put in place, drivers are advised to follow a symbol, which may be a black triangle, square, circle or diamond shape on a yellow background.

prashna.text: What does this sign indicate?

options.description: A. A cycle route
B. A pedestrian zone
C. A diversion route
D. A picnic area

questions.explanation: In the interests of road safety, temporary mandatory speed limits are imposed at all major roadworks. Signs like this, giving advance warning of the speed limit, are normally placed about three-quarters of a mile ahead of where the speed limit comes into force.

prashna.text: What does this temporary sign indicate?

options.description: A. A mandatory speed-limit change ahead
B. The speed-limit change at the end of the motorway
C. A variable speed limit ahead
D. An advisory change of speed limit ahead

questions.explanation: The sign gives you an early warning of a speed restriction. If you're travelling at a higher speed, slow down in good time. You could come across queuing traffic due to roadworks or a temporary obstruction.

prashna.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

options.description: A. Advised separation distance
B. Compulsory maximum speed limit
C. Advisory maximum speed limit
D. Compulsory minimum speed limit

questions.explanation: When traffic lights are out of order, treat the junction as an unmarked crossroads. Be very careful and be prepared to stop; no-one has priority.

prashna.text: What should you do when you see this sign at a crossroads?

options.description: A. Find another route
B. Maintain the same speed
C. Carry on with great care
D. Telephone the police

questions.explanation: In some situations, you may feel your indicators can't be seen by other road users. If you think you need to make your intention more obvious, give the arm signal shown in The Highway Code.

prashna.text: You're signalling to turn right in busy traffic. How would you confirm your intention safely?

options.description: A. Position over the centre line
B. Sound the horn
C. Give an arm signal
D. Flash your headlights

questions.explanation: You must comply with all traffic signs and be especially aware of those signs that apply specifically to the type of vehicle you're using.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Cars only
B. No cars
C. No motorcycles
D. Motorcycles only

questions.explanation: Sometimes work is carried out on the motorway without closing the lanes. When this happens, signs are mounted on the back of lorries to warn other road users of the roadworks ahead.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. A lorry has stopped in the right-hand lane. What should you do when you see this sign on the lorry?

options.description: A. Stop behind the flashing lights
B. Leave the motorway at the next exit
C. Move into the right-hand lane
D. Pass the lorry on the left

questions.explanation: Flashing red lights above your lane show that your lane is closed. You should move into another lane as soon as you can do so safely.

prashna.text: You're on a motorway. Red flashing lights appear above your lane only. What should you do?

options.description: A. Continue in that lane and look for further information
B. Stop and wait for an instruction to proceed
C. Move into another lane in good time
D. Pull onto the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: Never sound the horn aggressively. You mustn't sound it when driving in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am, or when you're stationary, unless another road user poses a danger. Don't scare animals by sounding your horn.

prashna.text: When may you sound the horn?

options.description: A. To warn others of your presence
B. To make slower drivers move over
C. To attract a friend’s attention
D. To give you right of way

questions.explanation: When your vehicle is stationary, only sound the horn if you think there's a risk of danger from another road user. Don’t use it just to attract someone’s attention. This causes unnecessary noise and could be misleading.

prashna.text: Your vehicle is stationary. When may you use its horn?

options.description: A. When the road is blocked by queuing traffic
B. When it's used only briefly
C. When signalling that you've just arrived
D. When another road user poses a danger

questions.explanation: Urban clearways are provided to keep traffic flowing at busy times. You may stop only briefly to set down or pick up passengers. Times of operation will vary from place to place, so always check the signs.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. No parking at all from Monday to Friday
B. End of the urban clearway restrictions
C. No parking on the days and times shown
D. You can park on the days and times shown

questions.explanation: You should be careful in these locations, as the road surface is likely to be wet and slippery. There may be a steep drop to the water, and there may not be a barrier along the edge of the road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Road liable to flooding
B. Quayside or river bank
C. Steep hill downwards
D. Uneven road surface

questions.explanation: The centre of the road is usually marked by a broken white line, with lines that are shorter than the gaps. When the lines become longer than the gaps, this is a hazard warning line. Look well ahead for these, especially when you're planning to overtake or turn off.

prashna.text: What does this white line along the centre of the road mean?

options.description: A. Give way warning
B. Lane marking
C. Bus lane marking
D. Hazard warning

questions.explanation: Yellow ‘box junctions’ like this are often used where it’s busy. Their purpose is to keep the junction clear for crossing traffic. Don’t enter the painted area unless your exit is clear. The one exception is when you're turning right and are only prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic or by other vehicles waiting to turn right.

prashna.text: What's the reason for the yellow crisscross lines painted on the road here?

options.description: A. To mark the entrance lane to a car park
B. To prevent queuing traffic from blocking the junction on the left
C. To warn you of the tram lines crossing the road
D. To mark out an area for trams only

questions.explanation: Areas of ‘hatched markings’ such as these separate traffic streams that could be a danger to each other. They're often seen on bends or where the road becomes narrow. If the area is bordered by a solid white line, you mustn't enter it except in an emergency.

prashna.text: What's the reason for the hatched area along the centre of this road?

options.description: A. It separates traffic flowing in opposite directions
B. It separates the two sides of the dual carriageway
C. It's a temporary marking to warn of the roadworks
D. It marks an area to be used by overtaking motorcyclists

questions.explanation: If other drivers flash their headlights, this isn’t a signal to show priority. The flashing of headlights has the same meaning as sounding the horn: it’s a warning of their presence.

prashna.text: Other drivers may sometimes flash their headlights at you. In which situation are they allowed to do this?

options.description: A. To show that they're giving way to you
B. To let you know there's a fault with your vehicle
C. To warn of a radar speed trap ahead
D. To warn you of their presence

questions.explanation: In some built-up areas, you may find the speed limit reduced to 20 mph. Driving at a slower speed will help give you the time and space to see and deal safely with hazards such as pedestrians and other vulnerable road users.

prashna.text: What speed limit is often found in narrow residential streets?

options.description: A. 35 mph
B. 20 mph
C. 25 mph
D. 40 mph

questions.explanation: The white light shows that trams must stop. The green light shows that other vehicles can go if the way is clear. Trams are being introduced into more cities, so you're likely to come across them and you should learn which signs apply to them.

prashna.text: What does this signal mean?

options.description: A. Cars must stop
B. Trams must stop
C. Both trams and cars can continue
D. Both trams and cars must stop

questions.explanation: These markings show the direction in which the traffic should go at a mini-roundabout.

prashna.text: Where would you find these road markings?

options.description: A. On a pedestrian crossing
B. On a motorway
C. At a mini-roundabout
D. At a railway crossing

questions.explanation: You must pull up on the left as soon as it’s safe to do so and switch off your engine.

prashna.text: A police car is following you. The police officer flashes the headlights and points to the left. What should you do?

options.description: A. Move over to the left
B. Stop immediately
C. Pull up on the left
D. Turn left at the next junction

questions.explanation:
At junctions controlled by traffic lights, you must stop behind the white line until the lights change to green. A red light, an amber light, and red and amber lights showing together all mean stop.
You may proceed when the light is green unless your exit road is blocked or pedestrians are crossing in front of you.
If you’re approaching traffic lights that are visible from a distance and the light has been green for some time, be ready to slow down and stop, because the lights are likely to change.

prashna.text: You see this amber traffic light ahead. Which light, or lights, will come on next?

options.description: A. Red alone
B. Green alone
C. Green and amber together
D. Red and amber together

questions.explanation:
You'll see this sign if there has been an incident ahead and the motorway is closed. You must obey the sign. Make sure that you prepare to leave in good time.
Don’t cause drivers to take avoiding action by cutting in at the last moment.

prashna.text: You see this signal overhead on the motorway. What does it mean?

options.description: A. Leave the motorway at the next exit
B. All vehicles use the hard shoulder
C. Sharp bend to the left ahead
D. Stop: all lanes ahead closed

questions.explanation:
'Stop' signs are situated at junctions where visibility is restricted or where there's heavy traffic. They must be obeyed: you must stop.
Take good all-round observation before moving off.

prashna.text: What must you do when you see this sign?

options.description: A. Stop only if children are waiting to cross
B. Stop only if traffic is approaching
C. Stop only if a red light is showing
D. Stop even if the road is clear

questions.explanation: Other warning signs are the same shape and colour, but the ‘give way’ triangle points downwards. When you see this sign, you must give way to traffic on the road that you're about to enter.

prashna.text: Which shape is used for a ‘give way’ sign?

questions.explanation: When you see this sign, look out for any direction signs and judge whether you need to signal your intentions. Do this in good time so that other road users approaching the roundabout know what you’re planning to do.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Buses turning
B. Ring road
C. Keep right
D. Mini-roundabout

questions.explanation: Be prepared for traffic approaching from junctions on either side of you. Try to avoid unnecessary changing of lanes just before the junction.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Two-way traffic straight ahead
B. Two-way traffic crosses a two-way road
C. Two-way traffic over a bridge
D. Two-way traffic crosses a one-way road

questions.explanation: This sign may be at the end of a dual carriageway or a one-way street. It's there to warn you of oncoming traffic.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Traffic approaching you has priority
B. Motorway contraflow system ahead
C. Two-way traffic crosses a one-way road
D. Two-way traffic straight ahead

questions.explanation: You'll need to slow down. At hump bridges, your view ahead will be restricted and the road will often be narrow. If the bridge is very steep, sound your horn to warn others of your approach. Going over the bridge too fast is highly dangerous to other road users and could even cause your wheels to leave the road, with a resulting loss of control.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Low bridge
B. Hump bridge
C. Uneven road
D. Traffic-calming hump

questions.explanation:
To ease the congestion in town centres, some cities and towns provide park-and-ride schemes. These allow you to park in a designated area and ride by bus into the centre.
Park-and-ride schemes are usually cheaper and easier than car parking in the town centre.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Parking area for cars and coaches
B. No parking for buses or coaches
C. Direction to bus and coach park
D. Direction to park-and-ride car park

questions.explanation: Be aware that other traffic might still be clearing the junction as you approach. A green light means you may go on, but only if the way is clear.

prashna.text: What should you do when approaching traffic lights where red and amber are showing together?

options.description: A. Take care because there's a fault with the lights
B. Pass the lights if the road is clear
C. Wait for the green light
D. Stop because the lights are changing to red

questions.explanation: This road marking means you should give way to traffic on the main road. It might not be used at junctions where there isn't much traffic. However, if there's a double broken line across the junction, the ‘give way’ rules still apply.

prashna.text: Where does this marking normally appear on a road?

options.description: A. Just before a 'no through road' sign
B. Just before a 'stop' sign
C. Just before a 'no entry' sign
D. Just before a 'give way' sign

questions.explanation: You must always obey red flashing stop lights. If a train passes but the lights continue to flash, another train will be passing soon. Cross only when the lights go off and the barriers open.
