prashna.text: At a railway level crossing, the red lights continue to flash after a train has gone by. What should you do?

options.description: A. Proceed with caution
B. Phone the signal operator
C. Wait
D. Alert drivers behind you

questions.explanation: If you have to leave your vehicle and get out of a tunnel by an emergency exit, do so as quickly as you can. Follow the signs directing you to the nearest exit point. If there are several people using the exit, don’t panic but try to leave in a calm and orderly manner.

prashna.text: You're in a tunnel and you see this sign. What does it mean?

options.description: A. No access for pedestrians
B. Beware of pedestrians: no footpath ahead
C. Beware of pedestrians crossing ahead
D. Direction to emergency pedestrian exit

questions.explanation: If the road has two lanes, you can use either lane and overtake on either side. Use the lane that’s more convenient for your destination unless signs or road markings indicate otherwise.

prashna.text: Which of these signs shows that you're entering a one-way system?

questions.explanation: Buses and cycles can travel in this lane. In this example, they'll flow in the same direction as other traffic. If it’s busy, they may be passing you on the left, so watch out for them. Times on the sign will show the lane's hours of operation; if no times are shown, or there's no sign at all, this means the lane is in operation 24 hours a day. In some areas, other vehicles, such as taxis and motorcycles, are allowed to use bus lanes. The sign will show if this is the case.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Contraflow bus and cycle lane
B. With-flow bus and cycle lane
C. No waiting for buses and cycles
D. No buses and cycles allowed

questions.explanation: Look well ahead and be ready to stop for any pedestrians crossing, or about to cross, the road. Also check the pavements for anyone who looks like they might step or run into the road.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Zebra crossing ahead
B. School crossing patrol
C. Pedestrian zone – no vehicles
D. No pedestrians allowed

questions.explanation: There may be occasions when drivers need to give an arm signal to confirm their intentions. This could include in bright sunshine, at a complex road layout, when stopping at a pedestrian crossing or when turning right just after passing a parked vehicle. You should understand what each arm signal means. If you give arm signals, make them clear, correct and decisive.

prashna.text: Which arm signal tells you that the car you're following is going to pull up?

questions.explanation: Blue circles tell you what you must do and this sign gives a clear instruction to turn left ahead. You should be looking out for signs at all times and know what they mean.

prashna.text: Which of these signs means turn left ahead?

questions.explanation: If you know which light is going to show next, you can plan your approach accordingly. This can help prevent excessive braking or hesitation at the junction.

prashna.text: You're approaching a red traffic light. What will the signal show next?

options.description: A. Red and amber
B. Amber alone
C. Green alone
D. Green and amber

questions.explanation: When approaching a tunnel, switch on your dipped headlights. Be aware that your eyes might need to adjust to the sudden darkness. You may need to reduce your speed.

prashna.text: What does this sign mean?

options.description: A. Tunnel ahead
B. Ancient monument ahead
C. Low bridge ahead
D. Traffic danger spot ahead

questions.explanation: A continuous white line is used on many roads to indicate the edge of the carriageway. This can be useful when visibility is restricted. The line is discontinued at junctions, lay-bys, and entrances to or exits from private drives.

prashna.text: What does the white line along the side of the road indicate?

options.description: A. No parking
B. The approach to a hazard
C. The edge of the carriageway
D. No overtaking

questions.explanation: Don’t attempt to overtake here, as there might be unseen hazards over the brow of the hill. Keep to the left.

prashna.text: What does this white arrow on the road ahead mean?

options.description: A. Keep left of the hatched markings
B. Road bends to the left
C. Entrance on the left
D. All vehicles turn left

questions.explanation: There may be occasions when other road users are unable to see your indicator, such as in bright sunlight or at a busy, complicated junction. In these cases, an arm signal will help others to understand your intentions.

prashna.text: How should you give an arm signal to turn left?

questions.explanation: Other road users may give misleading signals. When you’re waiting at a junction, don’t emerge until you’re sure of their intentions.

prashna.text: You're waiting at a T-junction. A vehicle is coming from the right, with its left indicator flashing. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pull out before the vehicle reaches the junction
B. Wait until the vehicle starts to turn in
C. Move out and accelerate hard
D. Move out slowly

questions.explanation: When there’s queuing traffic ahead and you have to slow down or even stop, briefly showing your hazard warning lights will help alert following traffic to the hazard.

prashna.text: When may you use hazard warning lights while you're driving?

options.description: A. On a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway, to warn of a hazard ahead
B. On the approach to toucan crossings where cyclists are waiting to cross
C. On rural routes, after a sign warning of animals
D. Instead of sounding the horn in a built-up area between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am

questions.explanation: You shouldn't stop on yellow zigzag lines outside schools, not even to set down or pick up children or other passengers. This is to make sure passing drivers and pedestrians have an unobstructed view.

prashna.text: When can you park on these markings outside a school?

options.description: A. When there's nowhere else available
B. Not under any circumstances
C. When you're picking up children
D. When you're dropping off children

questions.explanation: Leaving your indicators on could confuse other road users and may even lead to a crash. Be aware that if you haven’t taken a sharp turn, your indicators may not self-cancel and you'll need to turn them off manually.

prashna.text: Why should you make sure that your indicators are cancelled after turning?

options.description: A. To avoid misleading other road users
B. To avoid flattening the battery
C. To avoid damage to the indicator relay
D. To avoid dazzling other road users

questions.explanation: You need to signal to let other drivers know your intentions. However, if you indicate too early, they may think you're turning left into the junction. Correct timing of the signal is very important to avoid misleading others.

prashna.text: You're driving in busy traffic. You want to pull up on the left just after a junction on the left. When should you signal?

options.description: A. It would be better not to signal at all
B. Well before you reach the junction
C. Just before you reach the junction
D. As you're passing or just after the junction

questions.explanation: Some garages will remind you that your vehicle is due for its annual MOT test, but not all do. To ensure continuous cover, you may take your vehicle for its MOT up to one month before its existing MOT certificate runs out. The expiry date on the new certificate will be 12 months after the expiry date on the old certificate.

prashna.text: For how long is an MOT certificate normally valid?

options.description: A. Three years after the date it was issued
B. 10,000 miles
C. 30,000 miles
D. One year after the date it was issued

questions.explanation: Sometimes an insurance company will issue a temporary insurance certificate called a cover note. It gives you the same insurance cover as your certificate but lasts for a limited period, usually one month.

prashna.text: What is a cover note?

options.description: A. A document issued before you receive your driving licence
B. A document issued before you receive your MOT certificate
C. A document issued before you receive your registration document
D. A document issued before you receive your insurance certificate

questions.explanation: If you accumulate six or more penalty points within two years of gaining your first full licence, it will be revoked. The six or more points include any gained due to offences you committed before passing your test. If this happens, you may only drive as a learner until you pass both the theory and practical tests again.

prashna.text: You've just passed your practical test. You don't hold a full licence in another category. Within two years you get six penalty points on your licence. What will you have to do?

options.description: A. Reapply for your full licence immediately
B. Retake only your theory test
C. Retake only your practical test
D. Retake your theory and practical tests

questions.explanation: A SORN allows you to keep a vehicle off-road and untaxed. SORN will end when the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

prashna.text: For how long is a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) valid?

options.description: A. Until the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped
B. Until the vehicle is used on the road
C. Until the vehicle is repaired or modified
D. Until the vehicle is insured and MOT’d

questions.explanation: If you want to keep a vehicle untaxed and off the public road, you must make a SORN. It's an offence not to do so. Your SORN is valid until your vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

prashna.text: What is a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN)?

options.description: A. Information held by insurance companies to check a vehicle is insured
B. A notification to tell DVLA that a vehicle isn't being used on the road
C. A notification to tell DVSA that a vehicle doesn't have a current MOT
D. Information kept by the police about the owner of a vehicle

questions.explanation: Driving without insurance is a serious offence. As well as an unlimited fine, you may be disqualified or incur penalty points.

prashna.text: What's the maximum fine for driving without insurance?

options.description: A. Unlimited

questions.explanation: It's your legal responsibility to keep the details on your vehicle registration certificate (V5C) up to date. You should tell the licensing authority about any changes. These include your name, address or vehicle details. If you don’t do this, you may have problems when you try to sell your vehicle.

prashna.text: Who's legally responsible for ensuring that a vehicle registration certificate (V5C) is updated?

options.description: A. Your insurance company
B. The licensing authority
C. The registered vehicle keeper
D. The vehicle manufacturer

questions.explanation: You must produce a valid insurance certificate when requested by a police officer. If you can’t do this immediately, you may be asked to take it to a police station. Other documents you may be asked to produce are your driving licence and the vehicle's MOT certificate.

prashna.text: In which of these circumstances must you show your insurance certificate?

options.description: A. When a police officer asks you for it
B. When having an MOT inspection
C. When making a SORN
D. When buying or selling a vehicle

questions.explanation:
Using a vehicle on the road illegally carries a heavy fine and can lead to penalty points on your driving licence. You must have
• a valid driving licence
• paid the appropriate vehicle tax
• proper insurance cover.

prashna.text: Which of these is needed before you can legally use a vehicle on the road?

options.description: A. Proof of your identity
B. A vehicle handbook
C. Breakdown cover
D. A valid driving licence

questions.explanation: You can renew your vehicle tax online, at post offices and vehicle registration offices, or by phone. When applying, make sure you have all the relevant valid documents, including a valid MOT test certificate where applicable.

prashna.text: What must you have when you apply to renew your vehicle tax?

options.description: A. Valid insurance
B. A valid driving licence
C. The vehicle's chassis number
D. The handbook

questions.explanation: You don’t have to carry around your vehicle's documents wherever you go. If a police officer asks to see them and you don’t have them with you, you may be asked to produce them at a police station within 7 days.

prashna.text: A police officer asks to see your documents. You don't have them with you. Within what time must you produce them at a police station?

options.description: A. 14 days
B. 7 days
C. 5 days
D. 21 days

questions.explanation: Driving a vehicle without insurance cover is illegal, so be sure that, whoever's car you drive, you're insured – whether on their policy or on your own. If you need to take out insurance, it's worth comparing several quotes before you decide which insurance provider best meets your needs.

prashna.text: What must you make sure of before you drive someone else's vehicle?

options.description: A. That the vehicle is insured for your use
B. That the vehicle owner has third-party insurance cover
C. That the insurance documents are in the vehicle
D. That your own vehicle has insurance cover

questions.explanation: If your vehicle requires an MOT certificate, it’s illegal to drive it without one and your insurance may be invalid if you do so. The only exceptions are that you may drive to a pre-arranged MOT test appointment, or to a garage for repairs required for the test.

prashna.text: Your car needs to pass an MOT test. What may be invalidated if you drive the car without a current MOT certificate?

options.description: A. Your insurance
B. The vehicle tax
C. The vehicle service record
D. Your vehicle registration document

questions.explanation: It's your responsibility to make sure you're properly insured for the vehicle you're driving. This is the case regardless of whether you're a newly qualified driver or one with more experience.

prashna.text: What must a newly qualified driver do?

options.description: A. Be accompanied on a motorway
B. Display green L plates
C. Keep under 40 mph for 12 months
D. Have valid motor insurance

questions.explanation: Third-party insurance doesn’t cover damage to your own vehicle or injury to yourself. If you have a crash and your vehicle is damaged, you might have to carry out the repairs at your own expense.

prashna.text: You have third-party insurance. What does this cover?

options.description: A. Flood damage to your vehicle
B. Damage to your vehicle
C. Damage to other vehicles
D. Fire damage to your vehicle

questions.explanation: The registered keeper of the vehicle is responsible for paying the vehicle tax or making a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) if the vehicle is to be kept untaxed and off the road.

prashna.text: Who's responsible for paying the vehicle tax?

options.description: A. The registered keeper of the vehicle
B. The car dealer
C. The driver of the vehicle
D. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)

questions.explanation: Every vehicle used on the road has a registration document. This shows the vehicle’s details, including date of first registration, registration number, registered keeper, previous keeper, make of vehicle, engine size, chassis number, year of manufacture and colour.

prashna.text: What information is found on a vehicle registration document?

options.description: A. The date of the MOT
B. The type of insurance cover
C. The service history details
D. The registered keeper

questions.explanation: The licensing authority needs to keep its records up to date. It sends out a reminder when a vehicle's tax is due for renewal. To do this, it needs to know the name and address of the registered keeper. Every vehicle in the country is registered, so it’s possible to trace its history.

prashna.text: When must you contact the vehicle licensing authority?

options.description: A. When your vehicle's insurance is due
B. When you change your vehicle
C. When you take your vehicle abroad on holiday
D. When you use your vehicle for work

questions.explanation: The licensing authorities hold the records of all vehicles, drivers and riders in Great Britain and Northern Ireland. They need to know if you have a medical condition that might affect your ability to drive safely. You must tell them if your health deteriorates and you become unfit to drive.

prashna.text: When must you notify the licensing authority?

options.description: A. When your health affects your driving
B. When you have to work abroad
C. When your vehicle needs an MOT certificate
D. When you lend your vehicle to someone

questions.explanation:
The cost of insurance varies with your age and how long you've been driving. Usually, the younger you are, the more expensive it is, especially if you're under 25.
Pass Plus provides additional training to newly qualified drivers. The scheme is recognised by many insurance companies, and taking this extra training could give you reduced insurance premiums, as well as improving your skills and experience.

prashna.text: When may the cost of your insurance come down?

options.description: A. When you pass the driving test first time
B. When you're under 25 years old
C. When you don't wear glasses
D. When you complete the Pass Plus scheme

questions.explanation: Learner drivers benefit by combining professional driving lessons with private practice. However, you need to be at least 21 years old and have held your driving licence for at least 3 years before you can supervise a learner driver.

prashna.text: Which of these is a requirement before you can supervise a learner driver?

options.description: A. You must have held a licence for at least a year
B. You must hold an advanced driving certificate
C. You must be an approved driving instructor
D. You must be at least 21 years old

questions.explanation:
When a car is three years old (four years old in Northern Ireland), it must pass an MOT test and have a valid MOT certificate before it can be used on the road. Exceptionally, you may
•  drive to a pre-arranged test appointment or to a garage for repairs required for the test
•  drive vehicles made before 1960 without an MOT test, but they must be in a roadworthy condition before being used on the road.

prashna.text: Your car requires an MOT certificate. When is it legal to drive it without an MOT certificate?

options.description: A. When driving to an MOT centre to arrange an appointment
B. Up to seven days after the old certificate has run out
C. When driving to an appointment at an MOT centre
D. When driving the car with the owner’s permission

questions.explanation: The vehicle you drive must be roadworthy and in good condition. If it’s over three years old, it must pass an MOT test to remain in use on the road (unless it’s exempt from the MOT test - see GOV.UK).

prashna.text: A new car will need its first MOT test when it's how old?

options.description: A. Five years
B. One year
C. Three years
D. Seven years

questions.explanation: New drivers are far more vulnerable on the road and more likely to be involved in incidents. The Pass Plus scheme has been designed to improve new drivers’ basic skills and help widen their driving experience.

prashna.text: The Pass Plus scheme has been created for new drivers. What's its main purpose?

options.description: A. To allow you to drive faster
B. To improve your basic skills
C. To let you drive on motorways
D. To allow you to carry passengers

questions.explanation: Third-party insurance cover is usually cheaper than comprehensive cover. However, it doesn’t cover any damage caused to your own vehicle or property. It only covers damage and injury you cause to others.

prashna.text: Your vehicle is insured third-party only. What does this cover?

options.description: A. Damage to your vehicle
B. Damage to other vehicles
C. Injury to yourself
D. All damage and injury

questions.explanation: The minimum insurance required by law is third-party cover. This covers your liability to others involved in a collision but not damage to your vehicle. Basic third-party insurance also won’t cover theft or fire damage. Ask your insurance company for advice on the best cover for you and make sure that you read the policy carefully.

prashna.text: What's the legal minimum insurance cover you must have to drive on public roads?

options.description: A. Comprehensive
B. Third party only
C. Personal injury cover
D. Third party, fire and theft

questions.explanation: Having an excess on your policy will help to keep the premium down. However, if you make a claim, you'll have to pay the excess yourself – in this case, £100.

prashna.text: You claim on your insurance to have your car repaired. Your policy has an excess of £100. What does this mean?

options.description: A. Your vehicle is insured for a value of £100 if it's stolen
B. You'll have to pay the first £100 of the cost of repairs to your car
C. The insurance company will pay the first £100 of any claim
D. You'll be paid £100 if you don't claim within one year

questions.explanation: After passing your practical driving test, you can take further training. One option is known as the Pass Plus scheme. It's designed to improve your basic driving skills and involves a series of modules, including night-time and motorway driving.

prashna.text: What's the purpose of the Pass Plus scheme?

options.description: A. To increase your mechanical knowledge
B. To improve your basic driving skills
C. To allow you to drive anyone else’s vehicle
D. To give you a discount on your MOT

questions.explanation: The Pass Plus scheme was created for newly qualified drivers. It aims to widen their driving experience and improve basic skills. After passing the practical driving test, additional professional training can be taken with an approved driving instructor (ADI). Some insurance companies also offer discounts to holders of a Pass Plus certificate.

prashna.text: What does the Pass Plus scheme enable newly qualified drivers to do?

options.description: A. Increase their insurance premiums
B. Widen their driving experience
C. Supervise a learner driver
D. Avoid mechanical breakdowns

questions.explanation: If a disabled driver’s vehicle breaks down and they're unable to walk to an emergency phone, they're advised to stay in their car and switch on the hazard warning lights. They may also display a 'help' pennant in their vehicle.

prashna.text: You see a car on the hard shoulder of a motorway with a 'help' pennant displayed. What does this mean?

options.description: A. The driver is a rescue patrol officer
B. The driver is a foreign visitor
C. The driver is first-aid trained
D. The driver is likely to be a disabled person

questions.explanation:
Hazard warning lights are fitted to all modern cars and some motorcycles. They should be used to warn
•   other road users when your vehicle is causing a temporary obstruction; for example, after a collision or when it’s broken down
•  following drivers on a motorway of a hazard or obstruction ahead.
They shouldn’t be used as an excuse for dangerous or illegal parking.

prashna.text: When should you use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When you wish to stop on double yellow lines
B. When you leave your car at the roadside to visit a shop
C. When you slow down quickly on a motorway because of a hazard ahead
D. When you need to park on the pavement

questions.explanation:
You mustn't use hazard warning lights while moving, except to warn traffic behind when you slow suddenly on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway.
Never use hazard warning lights to excuse dangerous or illegal parking.

prashna.text: When are you allowed to use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When travelling slowly because you're lost
B. When travelling during darkness without headlights
C. When stopped and temporarily obstructing traffic
D. When parked on double yellow lines to visit a shop

questions.explanation: It’s important to keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front at all times. This still applies in congested tunnels, even if you're moving very slowly or have stopped. If the vehicle in front breaks down, you may need room to manoeuvre past it.

prashna.text: You're going through a congested tunnel and have to stop. What should you do?

options.description: A. Ignore any message signs, as they're never up to date
B. Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front
C. Make a U-turn and find another route
D. Pull up very close to the vehicle in front to save space

questions.explanation: The hard shoulder should only be used in a genuine emergency. If possible, and if it's safe, use a roadside telephone to call for help. This will give your exact location to the operator. Never cross the carriageway or a slip road to use a telephone on the other side of the road.

prashna.text: On a motorway, when should the hard shoulder be used?

options.description: A. When checking a road map
B. When answering a mobile phone
C. When an emergency arises
D. When taking a short rest

questions.explanation: If possible, lay the casualty down. Protect yourself from exposure to blood and, when you're sure there's nothing in the wound, apply firm pressure to it using clean material.

prashna.text: You arrive at the scene of a crash where someone is bleeding heavily from a wound in their arm. Nothing is embedded in the wound. What could you do to help?

options.description: A. Walk them around and keep them talking
B. Apply pressure over the wound
C. Get them a drink
D. Dab the wound

questions.explanation: If a casualty is unconscious, you need to check that they're breathing normally. Look for chest movements, look and listen for breathing, and feel for breath on your cheek.

prashna.text: You're at an incident. What could you do to help a casualty who's unconscious?

options.description: A. Move them to somewhere more comfortable
B. Splash their face with cool water
C. Take photographs of the scene
D. Check that they're breathing normally

questions.explanation: Check the casualty for shock and, if possible, try to cool the burn for at least 10 minutes using clean, cool water.

prashna.text: Following a collision, someone has suffered a burn. The burn needs to be cooled. What's the shortest time it should be cooled for?

options.description: A. 10 minutes
B. 5 minutes
C. 15 minutes
D. 20 minutes

questions.explanation: If a casualty isn't breathing normally, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may be needed to maintain circulation. Place two hands on the centre of the chest and press down hard and fast –  around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

prashna.text: A casualty isn't breathing normally and needs CPR. At what rate should you press down and release on the centre of their chest?

options.description: A. 120 times per minute
B. 240 times per minute
C. 60 times per minute
D. 10 times per minute

questions.explanation: The effects of shock may not be immediately obvious. Warning signs are rapid pulse, sweating, pale grey skin and rapid shallow breathing.

prashna.text: A person has been injured. They may be suffering from shock. What are the warning signs to look for?

options.description: A. Pale grey skin
B. Warm dry skin
C. Flushed complexion
D. Slow pulse

questions.explanation: After a casualty has been placed in the recovery position, make sure their airway remains open and monitor their condition until medical help arrives. Where possible, don't move a casualty unless there’s further danger.

prashna.text: An injured person has been placed in the recovery position. They're unconscious but breathing normally. What else should be done?

options.description: A. Press firmly between their shoulders
B. Check their airway remains open
C. Place their arms by their side
D. Give them a hot sweet drink

questions.explanation: If someone has been injured, the sooner proper medical attention is given the better. Ask someone to phone for help or do it yourself. An injured person should only be moved if they’re in further danger. An injured motorcyclist’s helmet shouldn't be removed unless it's essential.

prashna.text: An injured motorcyclist is lying unconscious in the road. The traffic has stopped and there's no further danger. What should you do to help?

options.description: A. Seek medical assistance
B. Move the person off the road
C. Remove their safety helmet
D. Remove their leather jacket

questions.explanation: Lorry drivers can be unaware of objects falling from their vehicles. If you see something fall onto a motorway, look to see if the driver pulls over. If they don’t stop, don't attempt to retrieve the object yourself. Pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and report the hazard.

prashna.text: What should you do if you see a large box fall from a lorry onto the motorway?

options.description: A. Stop close to the box until the police arrive
B. Go to the next emergency telephone and report the hazard
C. Pull over to the hard shoulder, then remove the box
D. Catch up with the lorry and try to get the driver’s attention

questions.explanation: Follow the instructions given by the signs or by tunnel officials. In congested tunnels, a minor incident can soon turn into a major one, with serious or even fatal results.

prashna.text: You're going through a long tunnel. What will warn you of congestion or an incident ahead?

options.description: A. Areas with hatch markings
B. Variable message signs
C. Other drivers flashing their lights
D. Hazard warning lines

questions.explanation: An adult casualty isn't breathing normally. To maintain circulation, place two hands on the centre of the chest. Then press down hard and fast – around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

prashna.text: An adult casualty isn't breathing. To maintain circulation, CPR should be given. What's the correct depth to press down on their chest?

options.description: A. 10 to 15 centimetres
B. 15 to 20 centimetres
C. 1 to 2 centimetres
D. 5 to 6 centimetres

questions.explanation: At a crash scene you can help in practical ways, even if you aren’t trained in first aid. Call the emergency services and make sure you don't put yourself or anyone else in danger. The safest way to warn other traffic is by switching on your hazard warning lights.

prashna.text: You're the first to arrive at the scene of a crash. What should you do?

options.description: A. Leave as soon as another motorist arrives
B. Drag all casualties away from the vehicles
C. Flag down other motorists to help you
D. Call the emergency services promptly

questions.explanation: If you’re the first to arrive at a crash scene, the first concerns are the risk of further collision and fire. Ensuring that vehicle engines are switched off will reduce the risk of fire. Use hazard warning lights so that other traffic knows there’s a need for caution. Make sure the emergency services are contacted; don’t assume this has already been done.

prashna.text: You're the first person to arrive at an incident where people are badly injured. You’ve switched on your hazard warning lights and checked all engines are stopped. What else should you do?

options.description: A. Make sure that an ambulance is called for
B. Move the people who are injured clear of their vehicles
C. Try and get people who are injured to drink something
D. Stop other cars and ask the drivers for help

questions.explanation: Don't remove a motorcyclist’s helmet unless it's essential. Remember they may be suffering from shock. Don’t give them anything to eat or drink, but do reassure them confidently.

prashna.text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. The rider is injured. When should their helmet be removed?

options.description: A. Only when it's essential
B. Always, unless they're in shock
C. Always straight away
D. Only when the motorcyclist asks

questions.explanation: At the scene of an incident, always be aware of danger from further collisions or fire. The first priority when dealing with an unconscious person is to ensure they're breathing normally. If they’re having difficulty breathing, follow the DR ABC code.

prashna.text: You arrive at an incident. There's no danger from fire or further collisions. What's your first priority when attending to an unconscious motorcyclist?

options.description: A. Check whether they have any broken bones
B. Check whether they're breathing normally
C. Check whether they have any bruising
D. Check whether they're bleeding

questions.explanation: Remember this procedure by saying DR ABC. This stands for Danger, Response, Airway, Breathing, Circulation. Give whatever first aid you can and stay with the injured person until the emergency services arrive.

prashna.text: At an incident, someone is unconscious. What would your priority be?

options.description: A. Make them comfortable
B. Wake them up
C. Check their airway is open
D. Find out their name

questions.explanation: There are a number of things you can do to help, even without expert training. Be aware of further danger from other traffic and fire; make sure the area is safe. People may be in shock. Don’t give them anything to eat or drink. Keep them warm and comfortable and reassure them. Don’t move injured people unless there’s a risk of further danger.

prashna.text: You've stopped at an incident to give help. What should you do?

options.description: A. Give injured people something to eat
B. Give injured people a warm drink
C. Keep injured people on the move by walking them around
D. Keep injured people warm and comfortable

questions.explanation: A casualty suffering from shock may have injuries that aren't immediately obvious. Call the emergency services, then stay with the person in shock, offering reassurance until the experts arrive.

prashna.text: There's been a collision. A driver is suffering from shock. What should you do?

options.description: A. Ask who caused the incident
B. Reassure them
C. Give them a drink
D. Offer them a cigarette

questions.explanation: The motorcyclist is in an extremely vulnerable position, exposed to further danger from traffic. Approaching vehicles need advance warning in order to slow down and safely take avoiding action or stop. Don’t put yourself or anyone else at risk. Use the hazard warning lights on your vehicle to alert other road users to the danger.

prashna.text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. No other vehicle is involved. The rider is unconscious and lying in the middle of the road. What's the first thing you should do at the scene?

options.description: A. Move the rider out of the road
B. Give the rider reassurance
C. Clear the road of debris
D. Warn other traffic

questions.explanation: If a young child has stopped breathing, first check that their airway is open and then begin CPR. With a young child, you may only need to use one hand and you shouldn’t press down as far as you would with an adult. Continue the procedure until the child is breathing again or until a medical professional takes over.

prashna.text: At an incident, a small child isn't breathing. What should you do to try and help?

options.description: A. Put them in the recovery position and slap their back
B. Talk to them confidently until an ambulance arrives
C. Open their airway and begin CPR
D. Find their parents and get permission to help

questions.explanation: It’s important to ensure that the airway is open before you start CPR. To open the casualty’s airway, place your fingers under their chin and lift it forward.

prashna.text: At an incident, a casualty isn't breathing. What should you do while helping them to start breathing again?

options.description: A. Shake them firmly
B. Roll them onto their side
C. Put their arms across their chest
D. Tilt their head back gently

questions.explanation: Your priority is to cool the burns with clean, cool water. Its coolness will help take the heat out of the burns and relieve the pain. Keep the wound doused for at least 10 minutes. If blisters appear, don’t attempt to burst them, as this could lead to infection.

prashna.text: At an incident, someone is suffering from severe burns. What should you do to help them?

options.description: A. Douse the burns with clean, cool water
B. Burst any blisters
C. Apply lotions to the injury
D. Remove anything sticking to the burns

questions.explanation: If there’s nothing in the wound, applying firm pressure using a pad of clean cloth or bandage will help stem the bleeding. Don’t tie anything tightly round the leg, as this will restrict circulation and could result in long-term injury.

prashna.text: You arrive at an incident. A pedestrian is bleeding heavily from a leg wound. The leg isn't broken and there's nothing in the wound. How could you help?

options.description: A. Fetch them a warm drink
B. Keep the casualty's legs flat on the ground
C. Apply firm pressure over the wound
D. Dab the wound to stop the bleeding

questions.explanation: Don't move a casualty unless there's further danger; for example, from other traffic or fire. They may have unseen or internal injuries. Moving them unnecessarily could cause further injury. Don't remove a motorcyclist’s helmet unless it’s essential.

prashna.text: At an incident, a casualty is unconscious but breathing. When should you move them?

options.description: A. When there's further danger
B. When an ambulance is on its way
C. When bystanders advise you to
D. When bystanders will help you

questions.explanation: When the area is safe and there’s no danger from other traffic or fire, it’s better not to move casualties. Moving them may cause further injury.

prashna.text: At an incident, it's important to look after any casualties. What should you do with them when the area is safe?

options.description: A. Move them away from the vehicles
B. Keep them where they are
C. Ask them how it happened
D. Give them something to eat

questions.explanation: There will be an orange label on the side and rear of the tanker. Look at this carefully and report what it says when you phone the emergency services. Details of hazard warning plates are given in The Highway Code.

prashna.text: A tanker is involved in a collision. Which sign shows that it's carrying dangerous goods?

questions.explanation: You must stop if you've been involved in a collision which results in injury or damage. The police may ask to see your driving licence and insurance details at the time or later at a police station.

prashna.text: You're involved in a collision. Afterwards, which document may the police ask you to produce?

options.description: A. Driving licence
B. Theory test certificate
C. Vehicle registration document
D. Vehicle service record

questions.explanation: It's important to make sure that the emergency services arrive as soon as possible. When a person is unconscious, they could have serious injuries that aren't immediately obvious.

prashna.text: After a collision, someone is unconscious in their vehicle. When should you call the emergency services?

options.description: A. Only as a last resort
B. After checking for broken bones
C. After you've woken them up
D. As soon as possible

questions.explanation: The most immediate danger is further collisions and fire. You could warn other traffic by switching on hazard warning lights, displaying an advance warning triangle or sign (but not on a motorway), or by any other means that doesn’t put you or others at risk.

prashna.text: A collision has just happened. An injured person is lying in a busy road. What’s the first thing you should do to help?

options.description: A. Warn other traffic
B. Make sure the injured person is kept warm
C. Place them in the recovery position
D. Treat the person for shock

questions.explanation: The DR ABC code has been devised by medical experts to give the best outcome until the emergency services arrive and take care of casualties.

prashna.text: At an incident, what should you do with a casualty who has stopped breathing?

options.description: A. Keep their head tilted forwards as far as possible
B. Follow the DR ABC code
C. Try to give them something to drink
D. Raise their legs to help with circulation

questions.explanation: If someone is suffering from shock, try to keep them warm and as comfortable as you can. Don’t give them anything to eat or drink but reassure them confidently and try not to leave them alone.

prashna.text: You’re at the scene of an incident. Someone is suffering from shock. How should you treat them?

options.description: A. Give them a warm drink
B. Offer them some food
C. Reassure them confidently
D. Offer them a cigarette

questions.explanation: When someone is injured, any movement that isn't absolutely necessary should be avoided, since it could make the injuries worse. Unless it's essential to remove a motorcyclist's helmet, it’s generally safer to leave it in place.

prashna.text: There's been a collision. A motorcyclist is lying injured and unconscious. Unless it’s essential, why should you not usually attempt to remove their helmet?

options.description: A. You could scratch the helmet
B. This could result in more serious injury
C. They might not want you to
D. They'll get too cold if you do this

questions.explanation: Advance warning triangles fold flat and don’t take up much room. Use one to warn other road users if your vehicle has broken down or if there has been an incident. Place it at least 45 metres (147 feet) behind your vehicle (or the incident), on the same side of the road or verge. Place it further back if the scene is hidden by, for example, a bend, hill or dip in the road. Don’t use warning triangles on motorways.

prashna.text: You've broken down on a two-way road. You have a warning triangle. At least how far from your vehicle should you place the warning triangle?

options.description: A. 45 metres (147 feet)
B. 5 metres (16 feet)
C. 100 metres (328 feet)
D. 25 metres (82 feet)

questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a level crossing, your first priority is to get everyone out of the vehicle and clear of the crossing. Then use the railway telephone, if there is one, to tell the signal operator. If you have time before the train arrives, move the vehicle clear of the crossing, but only do this if alarm signals are not on.

prashna.text: You break down on a level crossing. The lights haven’t yet begun to flash. What's the first thing you should do?

options.description: A. Stay in your car until you're told to move
B. Leave your vehicle and get everyone clear
C. Walk down the track and signal the next train
D. Tell drivers behind what has happened

questions.explanation: A tyre bursting can lead to a loss of control, especially if you’re travelling at high speed. Using the correct procedure should help you to stop the vehicle safely.

prashna.text: Your tyre bursts while you’re driving. What should you do?

options.description: A. Pull on the handbrake
B. Pull up slowly at the side of the road
C. Brake as quickly as possible
D. Continue on at a normal speed

questions.explanation:
Pull up on the hard shoulder and make your way to the nearest emergency telephone to call for assistance.
Don't attempt to repair your vehicle while it's on the hard shoulder, because of the risk posed by traffic passing at high speeds.

prashna.text: Your vehicle has a puncture on a motorway. What should you do?

options.description: A. Drive slowly to the next service area to get assistance
B. Switch on your hazard warning lights. Stop in your lane
C. Pull up on the hard shoulder. Change the wheel as quickly as possible
D. Pull up on the hard shoulder. Use the emergency phone to get assistance

questions.explanation: Try to stay calm, especially if you have passengers with you. If you can’t restart your engine before the warning bells ring, leave the vehicle and get yourself and any passengers well clear of the crossing.

prashna.text: You've stalled in the middle of a level crossing and can't restart the engine. The warning bells start to ring. What should you do?

options.description: A. Get out of the car and clear of the crossing
B. Carry on trying to restart the engine
C. Run down the track to warn the signal operator
D. Push the vehicle clear of the crossing

questions.explanation: Briefly using your hazard warning lights will warn the traffic travelling behind you that there's a hazard ahead. This can reduce the chance of vehicles crashing into the back of each other.

prashna.text: You're driving on a motorway. When can you use hazard warning lights?

options.description: A. When a vehicle is following too closely
B. When you’re towing another vehicle
C. When you slow down quickly because of danger ahead
D. When you’re driving on the hard shoulder

questions.explanation: Have the correct details ready before you use the emergency telephone. The operator will need to know the details of your vehicle and its fault. For your own safety, always face the traffic when you speak on a roadside telephone.

prashna.text: You’ve broken down on a motorway. When you use the emergency telephone, what will you be asked for?

options.description: A. Your driving licence details
B. Your employer's details
C. Details about your vehicle
D. The name of your vehicle's insurance company

questions.explanation: If you're wearing sunglasses, you should remove them before driving into a tunnel. If you don’t, your vision will be restricted, even in tunnels that appear to be well lit.

prashna.text: Before driving through a tunnel, what should you do?

options.description: A. Remove any sunglasses
B. Close your sunroof
C. Switch off your radio
D. Switch on your windscreen wipers

questions.explanation:
Before entering a tunnel, you should switch on your dipped headlights, as this will allow you to see and be seen. In many tunnels, it's a legal requirement.
Don’t wear sunglasses while driving in a tunnel. You may wish to tune your radio to a local channel for traffic information.

prashna.text: You're driving through a tunnel and the traffic is flowing normally. What should you do?

options.description: A. Use parking lights
B. Use rear fog lights
C. Use dipped headlights
D. Use front spotlights

questions.explanation:
The fuel in your vehicle can be a dangerous fire hazard. If you smell fuel, check out where it's coming from. Never
• use a naked flame near the vehicle if you can smell fuel
• smoke when refuelling your vehicle.

prashna.text: What safeguard could you take against fire risk to your vehicle?

options.description: A. Keep water levels above maximum
B. Use fuel additives
C. Avoid driving with a full tank of fuel
D. Check out any strong smell of fuel

questions.explanation: If any object falls onto the motorway carriageway from your vehicle, pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and call for assistance. Don’t stop on the carriageway or attempt to retrieve anything.

prashna.text: You're on the motorway. Luggage falls from your vehicle. What should you do?

options.description: A. Stop on the motorway and switch on hazard warning lights while you pick it up
B. Pull up on the hard shoulder and wave traffic down
C. Walk back up the motorway to pick it up
D. Stop at the next emergency telephone and contact the police

questions.explanation: Make sure you know what the different warning lights mean. An illuminated warning light could mean that your car is unsafe to drive.  If you aren’t sure about the problem, get a qualified mechanic to check it.

prashna.text: While you're driving, a warning light on your vehicle’s instrument panel comes on. What should you do?

options.description: A. Hope that it's just a temporary electrical fault
B. Deal with the problem when there's more time
C. Continue if the engine sounds all right
D. Check out the problem quickly and safely

questions.explanation: A broken-down vehicle in a tunnel can cause serious congestion and danger to other road users. If your vehicle breaks down, get help without delay. Switch on your hazard warning lights, then go to an emergency telephone to call for help.

prashna.text: Your vehicle breaks down in a tunnel. What should you do?

options.description: A. Switch on hazard warning lights, then go and call for help
B. Stand in the lane behind your vehicle to warn others
C. Stay in your vehicle and wait for the police
D. Stand in front of your vehicle to warn oncoming drivers

questions.explanation: If it’s possible, and you can do so without causing further danger, it may be safer to drive a vehicle that's on fire out of a tunnel. The greatest danger in a tunnel fire is smoke and suffocation.

prashna.text: Your vehicle catches fire while driving through a tunnel. It's still driveable. What should you do?

options.description: A. Leave it where it is, with the engine running
B. Park it away from the carriageway
C. Drive it out of the tunnel if you can do so
D. Pull up, then walk to an emergency telephone

questions.explanation: It’s usually better to drive a burning vehicle out of a tunnel. If you can’t do this, pull over and stop at an emergency point if possible. Switch off the engine, use hazard warning lights, and leave the vehicle immediately. Call for help from the nearest emergency point. If you have an extinguisher it may help to put out a small fire, but don't try to tackle a large one.

prashna.text: You're in a tunnel. Your vehicle is on fire and you can’t drive it. What should you do?

options.description: A. Leave the engine running
B. Switch on hazard warning lights
C. Switch off all of your lights
D. Stay in the vehicle and close the windows

questions.explanation: On the approach to tunnels, a sign will usually show a local radio channel. This should give a warning of any incidents or congestion in the tunnel ahead. Many radios can be set to automatically pick up traffic announcements and local frequencies. If you have to tune the radio manually, don’t be distracted while doing so. Incidents in tunnels can lead to serious casualties. The greatest hazard is fire. Getting an advance warning of problems could save your life and others.

prashna.text: What should you do as you approach a long road tunnel?

options.description: A. Make sure your radio is tuned to the frequency shown
B. Change down to a lower gear
C. Put on your sunglasses and use the sun visor
D. Turn your headlights on to main beam

questions.explanation: First, get yourself and anyone else well away from the crossing. If there’s a railway telephone, use that to get instructions from the signal operator. Then, if there’s time, move the vehicle clear of the crossing.

prashna.text: Your vehicle has broken down on an automatic railway level crossing. What should you do first?

options.description: A. Walk along the track to give warning to any approaching trains
B. Get everyone out of the vehicle and clear of the crossing
C. Telephone your vehicle recovery service to move it
D. Try to push the vehicle clear of the crossing as soon as possible

questions.explanation: Various items – such as a first aid kit and a fire extinguisher – can provide invaluable help in the event of a collision or breakdown. They could even save a life.

prashna.text: What should you carry for use in the event of a collision?

options.description: A. Fire extinguisher
B. Road map
C. Can of petrol
D. Jump leads

questions.explanation: If you're in a collision that causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property, by law you must stop. Give your name, the vehicle owner’s name and address, and the vehicle’s registration number to anyone who has reasonable grounds for requesting them.

prashna.text: You have a collision while your car is moving. What's the first thing you must do?

options.description: A. Call the emergency services
B. Stop only if someone waves at you
C. Stop at the scene of the incident
D. Call your insurance company

questions.explanation: Try to keep calm and don’t rush. Make sure that you've shared all the relevant details with the other driver before you leave the scene. If possible, take pictures and note the positions of all the vehicles involved.

prashna.text: You’re in collision with another moving vehicle. Someone is injured and your vehicle is damaged. What information should you find out?

options.description: A. The other driver’s name, address and telephone number
B. Whether the other driver is licensed to drive
C. The destination of the other driver
D. The occupation of the other driver

questions.explanation: If the property owner isn't available at the time, you must inform the police about the incident. This should be done as soon as possible, and in any case within 24 hours.

prashna.text: You lose control of your car and damage a garden wall. No-one is around. What must you do?

options.description: A. Find someone in the area to tell them about it immediately
B. Report the incident to your insurance company when you get home
C. Report the incident to the police within 24 hours
D. Go back to tell the house owner the next day

questions.explanation:
The motorway regulations for towing a trailer state that you mustn't
•  use the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway unless directed to do so (for example, at roadworks or due to a lane closure)
•  exceed 60 mph.

prashna.text: You're towing a small trailer on a busy three-lane motorway. What must you do if all the lanes are open?

options.description: A. Have a stabiliser fitted
B. Not exceed 50 mph
C. Not overtake
D. Use only the left-hand and centre lanes

questions.explanation: Strong winds or buffeting from large vehicles can cause a trailer or caravan to swing from side to side ('snake'). If this happens, ease off the accelerator. Don’t brake harshly, steer sharply or increase your speed.

prashna.text: What should you do if a trailer starts to swing from side to side while you're towing it?

options.description: A. Ease off the accelerator to reduce your speed
B. Accelerate until it stabilises
C. Let go of the steering wheel and let it correct itself
D. Brake hard and hold the pedal down

questions.explanation: Check the vehicle handbook. This should give you guidance on the correct tyre pressures for your vehicle and when you may need to adjust them. If you’re carrying a heavy load, you may need to adjust the headlights as well. Most cars have a switch on the dashboard to do this.

prashna.text: On which occasion should you inflate your tyres to more than their normal pressure?

options.description: A. When carrying a heavy load
B. When the tyre tread is worn below 2 mm
C. When the vehicle is fitted with anti-lock brakes
D. When the roads are slippery

questions.explanation: A heavy load on your roof rack will reduce the stability of the vehicle because it moves the centre of gravity away from that designed by the manufacturer. Be aware of this when you drive round bends and corners. If you change direction at speed, your vehicle and/or load could become unstable and you could lose control.

prashna.text: How will a heavy load on your roof rack affect your vehicle's handling?

options.description: A. It will make the steering lighter
B. It will reduce stability
C. It will improve the road holding
D. It will reduce the stopping distance

questions.explanation: Any load will have an effect on the handling of your vehicle, and this becomes worse as you increase the load. You need to be aware of this when carrying passengers or heavy loads, fitting a roof rack or towing a trailer.

prashna.text: What can be badly affected when you overload your vehicle?

options.description: A. The vehicle's battery
B. The vehicle's gearbox
C. The vehicle's handling
D. The vehicle's ventilation

questions.explanation: Carrying heavy loads will affect control and the vehicle's handling characteristics. If the vehicle you're driving is overloaded, you'll be held responsible.

prashna.text: Who's responsible for making sure that a vehicle isn't overloaded?

options.description: A. The owner of the items being carried
B. The licensing authority
C. The driver of the vehicle
D. The person who loaded the vehicle

questions.explanation: Towing a caravan or trailer affects the way the towing vehicle handles. A stabiliser device is not designed to overcome instability caused by incorrect loading but it can give added security in side winds and from buffeting caused by large vehicles.

prashna.text: You're planning to tow a caravan. Which of these will be the biggest aid to the vehicle handling?

options.description: A. Anti-lock brakes fitted to the towing vehicle
B. Power steering fitted to the towing vehicle
C. A jockey wheel fitted to the towbar
D. A stabiliser fitted to the towbar

questions.explanation: Riding in a towed caravan is highly dangerous. The safety of the entire unit is dependent on the stability of the trailer. Moving passengers would make the caravan unstable and could cause loss of control.

prashna.text: Are passengers allowed to ride in a caravan that's being towed?

options.description: A. Only if all the seats in the towing vehicle are full
B. Yes, if they're over 14
C. No, not at any time
D. Only if a stabiliser is fitted

questions.explanation: In the event that the trailer becomes detached from the towing vehicle, the breakaway cable activates the trailer brakes before snapping. This allows the towing vehicle to get free of the trailer and out of danger.

prashna.text: A trailer must stay securely hitched to the towing vehicle. What additional safety device must be fitted to a trailer braking system?

options.description: A. Stabiliser
B. Jockey wheel
C. Corner steadies
D. Breakaway cable

questions.explanation: You must know how to load your trailer or caravan so that the hitch exerts an appropriate downward force on the tow ball. Information about the maximum permitted noseweight can be found in your vehicle handbook or obtained from your vehicle manufacturer’s agent.

prashna.text: You wish to tow a trailer. Where would you find the maximum noseweight allowed on your vehicle’s tow hitch?

options.description: A. In the vehicle handbook
B. In your vehicle registration certificate
C. In The Highway Code
D. In your licence documents

questions.explanation: Any load must be securely fastened to the vehicle. The safest way to carry items on the roof is in a specially designed roof box. This will help to keep your luggage secure and dry, and it also has less wind resistance than loads carried exposed on a roof rack.

prashna.text: How should a load be carried on your roof rack?

options.description: A. Covered with plastic sheeting
B. Visible in your exterior mirror
C. Securely fastened with suitable restraints
D. Loaded towards the rear of the vehicle

questions.explanation: It’s your responsibility to ensure that all children in your car are secure. Suitable restraints include a child seat, baby seat, booster seat or booster cushion. It’s essential that any restraint used is suitable for the child’s size and weight, and fitted according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

prashna.text: You're carrying a child in your car. They're under three years old. Which of these is a suitable restraint?

options.description: A. An adult seat belt
B. A child seat
C. An adult lap belt
D. An adult holding a child
